The Phone Is EZ to Work but let me admit, I DID come out of another Samsung ( 9S+ 64G). The Folding Function makes it a bit bulkier (when Folded) but not as much as one would think. When Opened?? Its a dream! But the BIG 'pay off' of having a (Mind blowing) DOUBLE Wide Viewing Screen FAR Exceeds the little extra bulkiness. The Camera? Whew!! CRISP! It'll put a professional photographer out of business...SERIOUSLY!! (FYI? I'm a professional photographer!!) The battery life is GREAT! I use the phone ALL day fr 10 -12 hours without losing the initial charge. The Ugly? Obviously the $2k Price tag and the fact it didn't come with a basic case to protect an investment of this price? In my opinion a 'mis step for Samsung. Let me Add that Best Buy Didnt have Case or Screen protector in stock for a $2k Phone? At the point of purchase I was promised that I have both to my home address in 2 days. They took over a week! That to me? Bad business on BOTH Samsungs AND Best Buy. Bottom Line? I ABSOLUTELY LOVE the Phone and I was enticed MOSTLY by the double wide screen & the 256GB of storage. (BTW?) No Memory card slot? Thats another Mis-Step. Buy the phone...You'll love it!

While this phone meets the specs and has good future-proof features, I honestly can't stand this phone. Google has basically taken all the worst features and made them impossible to remove or disable. The camera is fine, the screen is large and very nice, there's no doubt there. However, I can't use my non-gmail email without installing an after-market app that I don't trust, nor do I want to link my real email to a gmail account. The finger sensor is on the back is weird, it works, but that's definitely a poor place to put that. The worst is the inability to alter the home screen because fixes the google search bar at the bottom, which is just a terrible location for it. Even worse, you'll need to watch like 5 tutorials to change how apps look, how the keyboard behaves etc. I'll keep it, but I'm not happy with this purchase. 
  
  Don't buy the Pixel 4a 5g, unless you really want to save 50% off all those very pricy phones! That's the only justification I have for not returning it.
Good quality for the price. Size is not big but okay for 4xl users.

Right off the bat..the cameras are really good. I purchased this for my wife and she upgraded from a Note 9. The screen is objectively just the best. Wish Samsung would dial it down with their over the top software and keep it vanilla stock android but I guess folks that have been buying Samsung products over the years like the extra features and you can set it up to use the app of your preference. So that negates the redundant apps that Samsung puts on there. Software aside, the hardware is amazing. Screen, battery, cameras and even the phantom black color is brilliant. The finish is not a fingerprint magnet.

I've had this phone for a week, and have run into small headaches consistently. The features Samsung chose to take out of Android 11 at the expense of their own are puzzling. The power menu that comes by default on Android 11? Gone. In its place? Samsung SmartThings. The bloat continues from there, with some features forcing you to make a samsung account. 
  
  Simple things like video picture in picture are now limited, so you can't put them in the center of the screen. Multiple games look horribly pixilated, whereas on other Android phones with 90hz displays look amazing. Settings are rearranged from standard android, for no reason. Great camera, fast apps, but many compromises. 
  
  Which leads me back to the title. If you're a Samsung user and are used to being strong-armed into using Samsung features at the expense of Android features, you may love this phone. Me? I can't help but crave the features and simplicity of other flagships.

My first Pixel XL just did not cut it anymore, and I could not afford to spend 1500.00+ on a new phone, when I saw the pixel 4a5g was just 499.00, I decided to give it a try.

  It charges faster as well. 
  
  Was it worth 499.00 ? 
  
  I would have to say YES! 
  
  However please keep in mind, I was coming from the first Google Pixel phone. 
  
  If you're moving up from a more recent device then you might not be happy with the 4a5g. 
  
  But if your device is around the age of the first Pixel phone then you should be happy as it's a good device for the money.

  That said, for users that use one of the other two major lines of phones, do realize there is a bit of a learning curve. This phone can and will run multiple applications at the same time. You will need to get used the swipe functions to switch apps and such.

This phone is overall a bunch of positive aspects, but there are a couple of drawbacks. First, the good. The 5G speed is quite impressive, with a download speed of over 60 Mbps! This, combined with a zippy processor and more than adequate memory makes using this phone a pleasure. This will allow you to blow past your data cap quicker than ever. The built-in speakers are also excellent giving great sound quality and volume for the size. The camera is also impressive, with great low-light performance. In the dark, the preview looks terrible and grainy, when the picture is taken, the results are better than other phones that I have used. My previous phone was a Moto Z4, and this phone is an overall improvement (although the Moto does do marginally better at zooming while in daylight. 
  
  But there are a few negatives with this phone. First is the complete lack of a micro-SD card slot. The included 128GB is generous, but upgrade is not possible. The second issue is the complete lack of an FM radio tuner. Finally, wireless charging would have been nice to include. If none of these issues are a problem, then I can heartily recommend this unit.

*** Summary ***
  
  For $500, you’re getting a superb mid-range phone with a thoughtful balance of hardware components coupled with excellent software directly from Google. The three cameras take top-level photos and videos, and the screen is big, bright, and crisp for an enjoyable multimedia and reading experience. With support for both 4G and 5G connectivity, as well as three years of software updates from Google, the phone is more future-proof than most competing devices. It’s a great bang-for-your-buck and a 5-star win! 
  _____
  *Pros:
  
  -The 6.2" OLED screen is great for videos and games. 
  -All three cameras take good pictures and videos. 
  -Google finally added a wide-lens camera on the back! 
  -The phone is consistently responsive and performant. 
  -The 128GB base storage is UFS 2.1 (i.e., fast). 
  -With built-in 5G support, you won't get left behind later. 
  -Has a 3.5mm audio jack. 
  -The 3,800mAh battery offers great endurance. 
  -Comes with 3 years of software support & Pixel-exclusive features. 
  _____
  *Neutral:
  
  -Still no micro-SD card support. 
  -No wireless charging. 
  -No water-resistance with an IP rating. 
  -The camera cut-out leads to a thick top status bar empty space when watching videos. 
  -The camera auto-focus is a bit slow and gets it wrong once in a while. 
  -No other color choices besides black. 
  _____
  *Cons:
  
  -The slow-motion video at 720p looks bad. 
  
  
  === Design, Build Quality, and Specs ===
  
  The Pixel 4a 5G, like the Pixel 3a mid-range phone from last year, is a simply-looking and unassuming device. The Pixel 4a exudes a clean look, has soft and rounded corners and sides for a comfortable and ergonomic feel in-hand, and although it’s heavily plastic, the fit-and-finish is excellent with no blemishes. Everything from the port to the speaker cut-outs, alignment and texture of the buttons on the right side, the rear camera hump, the slightly recessed fingerprint reader on the back, and all of the seams between the front glass and the phone casing are meticulously even. Although it doesn’t feel “premium” in-hand due to no metal or hardened glass on the back, the plastic material is of higher-than-average quality and it’s dense, smooth, and offers some grip. If the Pixel 4a 5G were a >$800 almost-flagship level phone, I would expect and want more. But at the $500 level, the build materials and quality are more than just fine, especially if you’re just going to put a case on it after the initial unboxing adoration and feel-over sessions are over. :)
  
  I’m quite satisfied with the hardware I’m getting at this price point - a Snapdragon 765G SOC with 6GB of RAM (fast and responsive), 6.2” OLED screen (bright and big), 128GB UFS 2.1 storage (fast file transfers and loading times), 4G & 5G radios (future-proof), a fingerprint sensor (fast and consistent), and three excellent cameras (12.2MP main rear, 16MP ultra-wide rear, 8MP front). 
  
  Do I wish the Pixel 4a 5G offered more? Sure, like wireless charging, an IP water-resistance rating, Wi-Fi 6, and a higher screen refresh rate like 90Hz or 120Hz. But those things would’ve added hundreds of dollars more to the cost and, frankly, they’re nice extras to have but not absolute necessities. 
  
  Looking over the design, build quality, and hardware specs of the Pixel 4a 5G, I think Google performed an excellent balancing act when finalizing the phone for this price point. 
  
  === Hardware & Software Performance ===
  
  The performance and responsiveness levels of the Pixel 4a 5G are nothing to write home about but I was pleasantly surprised by how good it was, especially when compared to my Pixel 3a and Samsung Galaxy S20+ 5G. When the Pixel 4a 5G was put through some benchmarks against the Pixel 3a, it was 70% faster in Geekbench 5 single-core and 30% faster in multi-core. 3DMark Wildlife gave the Pixel 4a 5G a 55% win in both the total score and frame rates. PCMark 2.0 Work 2.0 gave only a slight edge to the Pixel 4a 5G (15%) but the PCMark Storage test saw a huge improvement of 49% (most likely due to UFS 2.1). 
  
  These benchmark numbers, when translated into real-life usage, meant that the Pixel 4a 5G felt much more responsive, snappier, and faster than the Pixel 3a, and not too much slower than my Galaxy S20+ during normal usage (web browsing, watching videos, social media, texting, multi-tasking, etc). When playing graphic-intensive games, however, the Pixel 4a 5G got smoked by the Galaxy S20+, as expected. If you aren’t a hardcore smartphone gamer, then this is a non-issue. 
  
  The phone came preloaded with the latest Android 11 operating system and it’s clean-looking, intuitive, and responsive. Compared to more feature-heavy OS’s like Samsung’s OneUI 2.5, there are fewer bells and whistles, which some may bemoan. For instance, I was frustrated that I couldn’t even create folders inside the app drawer or hide app icons. Thankfully, installing 3rd-party launchers is still an option so I swapped to Novalauncher after putting up with the default launcher for three days. 
  
  Google may not offer many out-of-the-box customization options in general but it offers some Pixel-exclusive features that are quite nice, such as Automatic Call Screening, the most advanced version of Google Assistant AI, and the fancy Recorder app for voice transcriptions and note-taking. 
  
  Besides the lack of customization options from the default launcher, there is nothing else I can fault about Android 11 on the Pixel 4a 5G. It’s fast, stable, and intuitive to use with no major bugs. 
  
  
  === Connectivity ===
  
  The main selling point of the Pixel 4a 5G over the Pixel 4a and other mid-range devices is that it has 5G connectivity. After testing out 5G over both Sprint and T-Mobile’s networks, I walked away both impressed and sort of underwhelmed. I was pleasantly surprised by the reliability and signal strength of 5G around me but I was disappointed that my speeds didn’t improve by much and felt like regular 4G LTE. 5G is still actively rolling out so I’m expecting things to get more exciting later. 
  
  
  === Camera & Video Quality ===
  
  Just as I expected, photos and videos taken from the Pixel 4a 5G were highly satisfactory and competent. The colors were accurate with good dynamic range, and Google’s AI wizardry captured the subject matter with great focus and detail. I turn on HDR mode at all times and Google’s algorithm did a fantastic job highlighting the differences in contrast while preserving natural colors and small details. Google has created a great camera system and I feel confident that most people will be 100% satisfied by its quality and consistency. 
  
  My only gripes are that once in a while, the auto-focus loses track of my subject resulting in a blurry shot (for both photos and videos), and that low-light photo processing times feel a bit too long, resulting in missed opportunities. I’m hopeful that Google will release app updates to improve these areas. 
  
  === Is it a good buy? ===
  
  Yes! If you’re set on spending no more than $500 for a smartphone, then the Pixel 4a 5G is a very compelling choice with good value. You get a decent set of hardware that offers good performance and long battery life, excellent cameras, and the latest version of Android OS and Pixel exclusives straight from Google for three years guaranteed. With 128GB of fast internal storage, 5G connectivity, and a big and bright 6.2” screen, I think it’s both a sensible and worthy investment.

This is a three-star phone at best, on the best day ever. I paid $179.99 for it, but even if this were just a flat $200, I'd call it overpriced. 
  
  This phone lags, and has stuttery animations everywhere, so get ready for that. You can improve the framedrops some by installing a third party launcher like Nova launcher, which I have done. It improves the experience some in that regard, but still doesn't completely mitigate it. Also, it doesn't fix the really bad lag when it comes to opening applications. Just to drive the point home on how bad the stutter and lag is, this phone has a 90Hz refresh rate, but I had no idea that it was on (or even had it) until double checking the settings, because the phone's performance makes it look just like any other 60Hz display on a phone. Even so, I've seen 60Hz displays on phones that look smoother than this one. 
  
  The camera is very mediocre, but does work for taking pictures, and for the price, I can't complain about that. Just be aware that this camera does not take great photos, it just takes photos. 
  
  I don't have any other comments. Really just that the camera is passable, and the performance is really bad, but can be improved slightly by installing a third party launcher. 
  
  If you want a phone in this kind of price range, but want a far superior experience, I would look into something like the Xiaomi Poco X3. All in all, just don't buy this one. It makes OnePlus look bad if you've ever used one of their more expensive phones before.

To start off, all the technical information regarding the Pixel 4a 5G can be found at Google’s store website. Some of the more detailed info can be found at various websites as well with a simple search. It’ll help to better understand some of the things mentioned here. For easier reference, I’ll be using “4a5G” to refer to the Google Pixel 4a 5G. 
  
  The 4a5G positions itself between the Pixel 4a and the Pixel 5. The reason is because of the phone’s support for 5G carrier signals. While you do pay a price premium over the Pixel 4a ($150 worth), the cost is a little more than just 5G support. 
  
  Physically, the 4a5G is a tad larger than the Pixel 5, Google’s latest and highest end model for 2020. While the screen looks good despite a slightly less pixel density (and due to a slightly bigger screen), it lacks the high refresh rate (90Hz) that the Pixel 5 offers. However, the majority of people looking into getting a new phone are using phones that have standard 60Hz screens. Missing out on the 90Hz refresh rate would not be an issue. The biggest disappointment would definitely be the screen glass. The 4a5G uses Gorilla Glass 3 whereas the majority of 2020 phones, uses newer Gorilla Glass 5 (and the high-end using Gorilla Glass 6). Newer iterations of the glass are designed to be more resistant to breaking or cracking on impact, something that tends to happen often enough that people put a screen protector regardless of how good it is. And because it is using an older iteration, it’s recommended to get a protector as soon as possible as well as a decent phone case. 
  
  Inside, the hardware is almost identical to the fancier Pixel 5. There is 6GB of RAM compared to the 5’s 8GB. I also question this as a cost cutting measure. While there is a definite need to differentiate itself from the 5, memory should not be one of them. Software will always grow in complexity and maturity. And in order to bring out the best of the apps that we use, more memory is better. It also helps in keeping some apps open in the background so we can return to it later, saving us a little bit of time because the phone doesn’t need to load the entire app into memory again. I would rather not sacrifice memory to justify meeting the MSRP target. 
  
  Another piece missing is wireless charging. While many people may not care much for wireless charging, you cannot deny that it is becoming a common feature in phones at various price points. The lack of wireless charging is a minus given that Apple’s iPhone SE 2020 even has it, and that costs a single Benjamin less than the 4a5G. 
  
  Lastly, the phone lacks water resistance (or a water resistance certified rating). I think this is a major minus these days because of how we take our phones virtually everywhere. And there’s always that off chance the phone may end up taking a dip in the water. With no certified IP rating for water resistance, it means that bringing the phone to the pool, your bathroom, or wherever is very risky. Again, the fruity competitor’s phone comes with water resistance yet cost less. This is a big no-no for me if you need a practical phone that you can take with you. 
  
  For the past several years, Google has carved a spot in creating the best photos with a phone camera. In the years since its first Pixel phone release, the competition has had time to catch up. Now the gap in image quality and color accuracy has shrunk. It’s to the point where the competition can come close or match what the Pixel phones can do. However, the difference is that you may end up paying more for that competing picture quality. The great thing about Google’s camera system is that the hardware hasn’t changed but rather it’s the software that continues to improve. 
  
  Of the sample photos I’ve taken, the image quality is what I’ve come to expect from Google. The colors are good and the image quality, even in low light, are excellent. Portrait photos taken on the selfie front facing camera is great and recognizes the edges around me well. The only disappointment is perhaps the decision or quality on the wide angle lens. Even though it is supposed to provide a bigger/wider view, the sample photos I’ve taken with its Night Sight feature turned out to be worse. Taking wide angle shots with ample lighting didn’t appear to exhibit this odd quirk/flaw. Seeing that the majority of use cases for wide angle photography will be taken with ample lighting, perhaps this is a non-issue. 
  
  On video recording, I did not see any problem when taking a quick recording. The video stabilization also makes panning your shots smooth. It also can handle 4k 60fps recording which is a nice bonus. Recording at 1080p is limited to either 30fps or 60fps. I’ll nitpick here and say that Google should allow 120fps recording at 1080p since the phone is capable of handling 4k 60fps. At least it’s nice seeing that it can handle 4k 60fps. 
  
  I should not be pointing this out as a feature, as I still hold a grudge with Google on their decisions with the headphone jack. It is there for people who still use the tried and true headphones of their choice. It is convenient as it allows people to use the headphones of choice while also charging at the same time. 
  
  One of the best aspects of a Google Pixel phone is how smooth the experience is. There is no carrier-specific bloatware. No duplicate apps like a certain other major Android phone maker. It is the purest Android experience. Setting up the phone is straightforward and guides you through the steps. Once it’s done, you’re left with a clean home screen and the basic default apps to get started. Having used Android for many years, it has become second nature for me to know how to navigate around it. The experience is just like how I remembered -- smooth, flexible, and customizable. And the perk of using a Pixel phone is being the first to get security updates as well as major Android updates. But comparing it to a certain fruity competitor, Google still falls way short in this regard. That competitor is able to support hardware that dates back 5 years, which is 2 years longer than Google’s offering. Google should provide the same level of support if it wants to be competitive in the smartphone market. Aside from that, there are things within its stock Android software that sets it apart from other Android phones -- Pixel specific features. There's one that I tried for the first time on a Pixel phone -- call screening. It allows you to let Google Assistant to answer the call for you and transcribe in real time so you don't have to answer it yourself. And if the call is legit, you can pick it up and speak to the caller yourself. It's one of the perks to owning a Pixel phone that makes it worthwhile to have. 
  
  Testing the phone’s 5G capability has been rather tricky and at times difficult. Attempting to test this at home turned out to be a bad idea. For a baseline reference, 4G LTE speed varies between 20-30Mbps for download speed and 1.5 to 5Mbps for upload. This was done using T-Mobile’s network. At home, speeds vary between 45Mbps to 57Mbps for download and 3Mbps to 4.8Mbps for upload. To me that’s a very small gain and didn’t seem indicative of what 5G is supposed to be. On the way back from a small errand, I ran a single speed test. The result is 159Mbps for download and 16.3Mbps for upload. This is a drastic improvement and shows the potential for 5G. The wireless tech is still new and thus it will take time to proliferate and propagate. This isn’t to say that it’s not worth getting the phone for 5G. Rather, it’s a nice feature to have and adds a bit of future proofing to the phone. And conditions for 5G will only improve as time passes. 
  
  Overall, the Pixel 4a 5G is a nice phone that brings most of the basic necessities at an affordable price. However, I question the omission of water resistance and wireless charging as well as its use of Gorilla Glass 3 as the reason to differentiate itself from the flagship model. If a certain competitor is able to include wireless charging and water resistance at a lesser cost, I failed to see why it’s not included. Yet if you omit these flaws, the 4a 5G is a great phone for taking pictures without having to spend a lot. And with 3 years of major Android updates, the value becomes better and will help stem the need to upgrade the phone every so often. 
  
  The Good: Camera and image quality, stock Android, Pixel-only features, first to get major updates and monthly security patches, 3 years of major Android updates (from release date)
  
  The Bad: old Gorilla Glass tech compared to other 2020 phones, 3 years of Android update vs 5+ years on Apple phone, no wireless charging, no water resistant rating/certification
  
  The Ugly: Google’s design choices over the years
  
  Verdict: Buy if you’re an Android user but it’s generally a coin flip to me

Genuinely good phone. For significantly less than the Pixel 5, you lose wireless charging, a full metal body, a bit of ram and framerate, and a bit of battery size. You do gain a dedicated headphone jack, or rather you don't lose it. Practically the same phone, and its great as it is.
Phone screen became blue. Within 2 months phone became unusable.

I miss the flip phone days when you charged your phone once a week. Unfortunately, we've gone from that to charging daily. The Pixel 4a 5G is a huge improvement. I'm not a really heavy user, but I can go almost three days on a charge. That's about a day better than the best smartphones out there. It could be because of Android 11, which installed on day one. Since we don't have 5G in my area, I haven't been able to test battery life on the new network, but I'm pretty sure it will decrease slightly. 
  
  Speaking of Android 11, one of the nice things about Google phones is you get completely stock Android--no launchers or other software that can slow the phone down. And this phone is fast. I've not seen any lag at all. 
  
  The camera is excellent, giving accurate colors in good light, and good pictures in low light situations, as well. 
  
  The AMOLED screen is bright and colors pop. And I've been very impressed with the speaker. It gives sufficient volume without sounding tinny like most smartphone speakers. 
  
  The only issue I've noticed so far is that sometimes apps open in landscape mode and there is a lag before rotation is corrected. I'm sure that's a software issue and will be fixed in the near future. 
  
  In my opinion, this phone has all the features you could want in current smartphones. And it's half the price of other flagship phones.
Great device for the price. Love pixel devices. Quick and easy set up.

This phone is really a great value compared to other flagship phones. I originally had a Pixel 5, but decided for the money this phone is a better value. I really like having wireless charging, but for the extra money it wasn't worth it. I'm using a USB-C wireless charging coil under my case and it is great. Another feature that would have been nice to have is for it to be water resistant, but I can't remember the last time I really needed it. The phone takes great pictures and it is the total Google experience. If you are looking to save some money and get a great phone with a slightly bigger screen than the Pixel 5, then this is the one.

I picked this one up not expecting much with it being OnePlus' lowest-end offering, but I was pleasantly surprised by how much of what I'd assume is the flagship OnePlus experience had carried over to their most affordable offering. Haven't used a OnePlus phone since the One, but this wasn't as bad of a second first impression as the reviews online lead me to believe at first. Almost everything I'd like to see out of a phone is present and accounted for here. There's a surprisingly pretty 90hz display up front, the back panel is absolutely beautiful and looks very premium, and the main camera's performance is actually quite decent for a device in this price range. There's a charger in the box, a headphone jack, and an SD card slot, none of which you really see these days- not even the last two are present in OnePlus' more expensive devices! 
  
  My main peeves with this device are the limited software support, the unsightly chin on the display, the awful vibration motor, and the lack of an ultra-wide angle camera. This phone is only going to get one update to Android 11 and after that it'll only receive security updates until 2022. The vibration motor is flubby and weak, which is a shame considering some phones in a similar price range have much better motors with strong and tight vibration feedback. Finally, the lack of an ultra-wide camera really rubs me the wrong way- I mean, really? Instead of a nearly useless depth camera, they probably could've added an ultra-wide lens at a lower resolution. The macro camera is alright and does make for some fun shots, but I'd rather only have the regular and ultrawide cameras on the back so the camera bump can be smaller/slimmer.

Google nailed it with this phone. Google phones at first glance seem to not make sense when compared to the specs of other phones released in their class but when you put them to real life use, they are so relevant.

  -Speedy and snappy. The 765g processor is efficient and more than enough for everyday usage. 
  -Headphone jack! 
  -Fast fingerprint scanner which is really appreciated in this era of face masks. 
  -128gb of onboard storage. 
  -Smooth UI with no added bloatware like other android phones. 
  -Always had great still shot cameras but video footage is ridiculously high quality (4k 30/60 on rear cameras). Stabilization is among the best in any high end flagship. 
  
  Only con for me is no 4k 30/60 on front facing camera which is not a deals breaker at all. Also 5g is overrated so I leave it on LTE which makes the battery even better. I'm getting over 10hrs screen on time consistently. Best part is only paid $400 out the door for mine but this phone is a great value even at $499

I really wanted to like this phone. I love that it has a headphone jack, I love that it runs a mostly bloat-free and ad-free version of Android (in recent years, many Android phonemakers have basically ruined Android on their phones by filling it with needless apps and features), I love the camera quality (despite it lacking a telephoto camera),and I love that the bootloader can be unlocked meaning you can root the phone or flash custom ROMs. This is super useful for people that like more control over their device or intend to keep their phone past the window of provided software support. 
  
  The problem is that this phone is simply built like trash. It's made from plastic. I personally don't think any phone, budget or flagship, should be made from plastic. I simply refuse to understand why this phone is $500 and made from plastic when the iPhone SE (2020) is made from premium aluminum and glass and actually costs less and has a faster processor. There is no excuse for making an appliance that most people use everyday out of such a cheap material. Google is absolutely taking their customers for a ride and overcharging for their devices. 
  
  What else is wrong with this phone? The screen is absurdly dim. I could barely make out icons or text on a sunny day without maxing the brightness and after a few moments, the autobrightness would lower it back to a point of unreadability. 
  
  I also very much dislike the hole punch camera cutout. I think notches and camera cutouts are a solution in search of a problem. It's a hideous black dot marring the otherwise edge-to-edge display. The only positive thing I can say about the camera cutout is that it is in the left corner rather than the center of the screen. Many other phonemakers have started putting hole punch cameras right in the middle of the phone and it's immensely distracting when gaming or watching videos. Thank you to Google for at least putting it in the corner where it's less obtrusive. 
  
  I think Google deserves praise for software support, cameras, and allowing bootloader unlocking. Everything else about this phone is pretty bad. I returned it.

This phone is an excellent balance between display quality, sound quality, processing speed, and everything else. This phone is fast, faster than how fast you would think a 765 chip is. The cameras are the absolute highlight of this phone. While many others with a phone try to take good pictures, I'd find it hard for anyone to be able to take a bad one with this phone. The night mode and the astrophotography mode are absolutely ridiculous. I would only be able to count out a few stars with my eyes and after snapping a picture with this phone it captured hundreds of stars. This phone has it all. You won't be missing the wireless charging because it charged faster with the wired 18W charging. This battery lasts me all day easily. The display gets bright and the OLED panel is great. You can easily get 7-8 hours out of this phone to last you throughout the whole day. This phone is the best value for money out there right now. If you can get it while discounted it'll be an absolute steal. Would recommend this phone to anyone who wants a big screen, incredible cameras, fast processing speeds, and good battery life.

Cell phones. Can't be without one, but you can't seem to pocket them easily anymore. Sleek, shiny glass backs also "feel premium" but what's the point when you slap a case on them to prevent them from getting damaged? So, I say, thank you Google for making phones that are simple, yet very functional with exceptional cameras. 
  
  I moved the 4a 5G from a Pixel 3a. More RAM, Storage and the Pixel 5 camera, what's not too like? 5G? Well, guess it depends on where you live, and it really wasn't a factor for me. I do happen to get a consistent 5G signal, which is nice, but I don't do a lot f things where I notice the speed difference. 
  
  Build quality is nice. You know the drill with Pixels. Gorilla Glass up front, plastic on the back. Nothing fancy, and it doesn't need to be. Stock Android (mine already updated to 11) with no trash apps preinstalled. Camera? Well, it's a Pixel, so you know it's going to be good. No crazy amount of lenses that you will likely never use, just. standard and wide angle and that's enough. Unbeatable low light images. 
  
  Battery life? In a word....EXCELLENT. Now, I am not what you would call a power user. I make a few calls, send txt messages, watch youtube, facebook and plenty of random google searches. I can easily charge every other day. So is this phone for you? If you want a solid phone that just works and like to take some pretty amazing pictures

There is a lot to like about this phone and I believe it’s probably the best US flagship 5G smartphone on the market currently. Build quality is excellent, the phone’s beautiful exterior is lovingly crafted with metal and glass, no cheap plastic materials. Specs are among the best of any Android smartphone and OnePlus has designed a new cooling system for the device to keep it cool. 
  
  Cameras are excellent, and this is coming from somebody who’s last phone was a Pixel device. I’ve owned previous OnePlus phones as well (OnePlus 7 Pro and OnePlus 8T) and the camera is in another league. Way less shutter lag that previous phones, clearer photos, excellent portrait mode, and support for 4k 120FPS video (which is stunning). Optical image stabilization works wonderfully as well. A minor grievance is that I don’t like the Hasselblad logo on the camera bump, I understand that the two companies have a partnership but I’m not a fan of excessive branding on my devices (especially if it’s from a partner company). It’s worth noting that Sony (not Hasselblad) actually supplies the camera sensors for this phone. 
  
  The phone supports 60w wired charging and is absurdly fast to charge. 15w EPP Qi charging and 50w proprietary wireless charging are also supported. Personally, I have no interest in the 50w proprietary wireless charger (it’s expensive and gets the phone quite toasty from what I’ve heard) but Qi support is a nice touch for people who enjoy using wireless charging as a mere supplement to wired charging or for the rare event that you have a mishap with your charging port. Battery life has been slightly better than I’ve experienced on previous OnePlus devices with 6 hours or more screen on time before I feel the need to plug in. 
  
  Device stability is good, I have not experienced any issues with bugs, overheating, or crashes. The underscreen fingerprint sensor works flawlessly every time (OnePlus has the best optical fingerprint readers in the industry as far as I’m concerned) and is very convenient. Sound from the phone’s speakers is loud and crisp. Haptic feedback feels good. 
  
  Despite this praise, the phone isn’t perfect. For one, it lacks a headphone (3.5mm audio) jack. I listen to a lot of music, especially in my truck which has a custom sound system. My previous phone, the Google Pixel XL, had a headphone jack and outputs clean audio. When I connected my new OnePlus 9 Pro to my truck’s stereo using Bluetooth it sounded TERRIBLE. Bluetooth simply does not have good enough sound quality to substitute for a wired connection. OnePlus should put a quality DAC in their next phones and bring the jack back like Sony does with their Xperia series of phones. I refuse to be gaslit and told that a headphone jack isn’t viable on a water resistant phone; Samsung built water resistant phones with jacks for years and Sony still does. The inability to use wired headphones is also very annoying. I understand that USB-C to 3.5mm adapters exist but USB-C passthrough audio quality very rarely matches a direct 3.5mm connection (in fact, poor sound quality through USB-C passthrough audio and Bluetooth is one of the reasons I returned a previous OnePlus phone, the 8T). I’m going to force myself to live with it because I don’t have much of a choice (can’t find any suitable alternative phones with a jack that would work well on my network) but I’m very unhappy about it and will continue noting this as a complaint whenever possible. 
  
  Another thing I dislike about the phone is the ugly hole punch camera. I can at least praise OnePlus for putting it in the top left corner rather than the center of the display (corner hole punches are always going to be better than centered ones) but I still hate looking at it. The screen is vibrant and beautiful to look at but every time I see the ugly black dot for the camera I’m a little disgusted. This is coming from the same company that made the OnePlus 7 Pro, a phone with a full edge-to-edge display with no interruptions, notches, or hole punches. Hole punch cameras are such a downgrade from bezel-mounted cameras and pop up cameras. They are terrible. 
  
  OnePlus’ Visual Voicemail still doesn’t work on Mint Mobile (hasn’t since at least the OnePlus 7 Pro) which is very frustrating, especially considering I’ve seen OnePlus phones for sale on their website before! I would really appreciate if this could be addressed sometime. 
  
  The phone does come with some bloatware. You have the typical Google stuff which I can mostly give a pass, but then you have a few other weird software quirks like the inability to uninstall the Netflix app. Now personally I use Netflix, but what if I didn’t? I wouldn’t want an app on my phone I don’t use. This is the problem with bloatware, it takes choices away from the customer. All this being said, OnePlus does allow the phone’s bootloader to be unlocked to if you want to root the phone or flash a custom ROM, you can. I really appreciate that functionality as it has become very rare on US model Android smartphones. More and more manufacturers have decided to lock their phones down and disallow customer tinkering. Thank you, OnePlus, for being a part of the solution rather than the problem. 
  
  My last concern is software support. While OnePlus may be better than some Android manufacturers when it comes to updates and continued product support, in recent years they have been slacking off. Browse the OnePlus subreddit or the OnePlus community forum and you’ll see tons of complaints from customers with phones less than 3 years old who have no longer been receiving timely security or OS updates. While I can’t say how good software support will be for the OnePlus 9 Pro yet, it is something I’m a bit worried about. 
  
  Overall, I think this is a great device if slightly flawed. If you need a US 5G Android flagship, don’t hesitate. Buy the OnePlus 9 Pro.

  One minor negative are the buttons' build quality, but I wouldn't sway away from the phone because I would expect minor build choices like that for such an inexpensive phone (compared to flagships). 
  
  I'm not a heavy phone user anymore, but a full charge will last well over 24 hrs, so I charge while I'm getting ready for work and I'm good for the rest of the day and repeat the cycle; I'm not having to charge to 100% to get a full day out of it... I am very impressed with this phone. I came from an iphone SE 2020 after having a pixel 2 before that. I am one of those that prefers Android ( specifically pixel Android) over iOS. Although the SE was a good phone for the price there were some things that would irritate me over using the pixel. Things like notifications, the app drawer, call screening and spam blocking, the battery, and Google assistant vs siri were all things that made me switch back to the pixel line of phones. Also I am not in the apple ecosystem. I use majority of Google services and windows, although both play nice with the iPhone, the baked in features of Android with other Google products that use assistant is much nicer. 
  
  Things I like about this phone are the cameras, the battery life (very good! ), Bloat free Android, Google services and screen quality. 
  
  Things I wish I had are a 3 lens camera system, IP water resistance, wireless charging, and louder speakers ( although they don't sound bad). 
  
  Things I could care less about are really just the higher end processor. The Snapdragon 765 in this phone is more than fine. I may notice a slight delay in processing a photo or launch of an app but it's really a half second or a second nothing that is crazy in fact I notice similar delays in using the iPhone SE with the bionic 13 chip. Plus the battery savings is a great trade off in my opinion. Also I could care less about a high refresh screen and this screen is very nice too look at. 
  
  I know the things I wish it had could be had if I bought the pixel 5 but I think the price difference is too great for wireless charging and IP rating. If the pixel 5 was around $100 more I might have bit but I got this phone for $450 while the pixel 5 is $699. In my opinion it's not worth the difference when most of the experience will be practically identical. 
  
  TL/DR: buy this phone! It's a great buy, extremely smooth in use, great cameras, headphone jack, timely updates, great battery, good screen.

I purchased a Pixel 4a 5G a couple of weeks ago. This was a big transition from a Galaxy S9, and the several other Galaxy devices prior. I was pretty excited to try a new phone. I went with an unlocked version instead of my cell carrier's. I was very happy with this decision. Getting all the apps and settings over from my S9 was complicated. Not the usual Samsung Switch process, so I invested lots of time setting it up. Here is what I liked about the Pixel 4a 5G:
  
  - The clean Android OS without all the carrier apps and Samsung apps. 
  - The phone ran smooth and fast enough for a non-gamer. 
  - The phone is light and a great size
  - The back mounted fingerprint reader was awesome. It runs circles around my Galaxy devices. 
  -Battery life was the best I've had in a long time. 
  
  The simplicity of the 4a 5G was nice, but maybe too simple in a couple ways, which is why I gave it 4 stars instead of 5, and returned my Pixel:
  
  - No gallery app built in. I did easily remedy this by finding a highly rated app that functioned well. 
  - The ring and notification volume controls are as one. This was a deal breaker for me. I could hear my ringtones, but I was missing all kinds of notifications. To hear my notifications, I had to turn up the volume too much and the ringtones were obnoxious. 
  - The screen was crisp but not nearly as bright as my older phones. I would have been ok with this difference. 
  
  I ended up returning the phone only because of the volume control issue. This may not be a problem for many people but there are plenty of reviews out here asking Google to fix this. I ended up with another S21 5G and I really wish the Pixel would have worked out... I feel like I am back to carrying the same old phone for 8 years now.

I bought the Pixel to replace my 5-year-old iPhone, which suddenly quit working. But frankly, I wonder why I waited so long. Switching was virtually seamless as I transferred all the apps used on the iPhone to the Pixel 4A in just minutes. The Pixel's operation is faster and more intuitive, while screen images are sharper and more vivid. The phone's Bluetooth connected easily with my car, Bose portable speaker and stereo, and the audio is exquisite. This may be considered a budget buy, but to me it beats flagship phones that cost nearly twice as much and simply didn't measure up to the Pixel 4a.

Battery life is great. Speed and images are very good. Camera is great except for flash photography. Very slow to focus and take picture. You can miss a lot of important shots. (example: child blowing out birthday candles) Low light is great but if their is much movement the shots are blurry.

I'll confess that I typically buy budget phones. This is by far the most "premium" phone that I've ever owned. 
  
  So far, I'm very impressed by it. 
  
  Setup was an absolute breeze. The phone comes with a USB type-C to type-A adapter, and it guides you through hooking up your old phone to migrate everything over. With the exception of needing to log into a few apps, the transition was seamless. Even my custom wallpaper and ringtone carried over. 
  
  The camera quality is fantastic. The lens angle is a bit wider than I was expecting, but it's very user friendly. It's an absolute joy to use. 
  
  This latest version of android has NO navigation buttons at the bottom of the screen. I was managing well enough with this, but I was having an awful time trying to switch apps. The whole "press the bottom of the screen (but not the middle or far right) + hold + swipe + hold" to switch between apps is awful. Why they couldn't have just set it up as a 3-finger swipe up is beyond me. Fortunately, you can bring the buttons back by going into settings and searching for "gestures." Once I did that, things went much more smoothly. 
  
  The only other "problem" I've had with this phone is with its screen during calls. The screen automatically blacks out while you're in a call to prevent you from accidently dialing things with your face. This is generally a good thing. I find that the phone is slow to wake back up when you pull it away from your face though. I'll be ready to hang up the call, but it's a good couple seconds before the screen wakes up for me to do that. 
  
  This is more an annoyance than anything. 
  
  Call quality is phenomenal. Everything sounds great on my end, and I've received no complaints from the people that I talk to. 
  I live in an area with solid 5G coverage, and the data speeds are quite good as well. 
  
  This is a great phone.

This phone is just astonishing beautiful when you hold it in your own hands. The plastic back actually feels so premium, contrary to what I initially thought. The phone fits just like a glove in my hands, and I don't have big hands at all. The phone is very snappy and shows no glitches at all. I am really happy with my purchase. Best Buy shipped it to my address in virtually no time, I ordered it like today at 8 pm and I got it home by next day at 10 am.
This is my second Google Pixel phone. I have been very happy with Google Pixel, such a dependable, effective phone.

There are some great things I really like about the Google phone platform. Their phones have minimal to no bloatware, the phone is the first to receive android updates, the cameras have always taken great photos. They seem to have pivoted with their strategy. They are no longer trying to compete with high end pricey phones, they would rather make a real solid mid-tier level mobile. This is one of those devices. 
  
  As a heavy Gmail user this phone seamlessly works with everything google offers. The apps all sync wonderfully together. Mail syncs to my calendar, documents to the drive/cloud, and lots of other things that make a super smooth experience. Love that they included the fingerprint reader. It's always a faster unlock than facial recognition with zero fails. 
  
  Here's a strange issue I personally found. The screen doesn't get dark enough. For those bedtime moments when everyone uses their phone, the one's where all the lights are off and the phone is the only source of illumination, it just doesn't go low enough for my liking. But not a common issue for most people. Brightness isn't an issue, even in direct sunlight. Sound comes in loud and punchy. 
  
  The crowning jewel of the phone has to be the 5G ability. So much faster than 4G LTE. Downloaded a 2.5 Gb file from my Google drive, took well less than a minute to download. This device habitually tests at around 80- 100mbps speed in areas I got 5G coverage (see attached photo). Heck, I can hot spot my Chromebook and at times it's faster than my home internet. Battery life is pretty good to. A day of heavy use with hot spot and Bluetooth running, I still had 60sih percent battery left. 
  
  Today it seems like phone users want great photos and long battery life. Not that this is all they look for but they are always at the top of most people's checklist in a phone. I can say that this device offers both.

I was a previously an owner of a Pixel 3a. After about the 30th drop within a year, the screen shattered. I bought a kit on Amazon and replaced it myself, but the adhesive was never the same, resulting in the replacement screen popping out every now and then. It was this and the limited 4gb of ram that ultimately let me to the upgrading to the Pixel 4a (5G). 
  
  I chose this model because of the faster processor and added wide-angle lens. The phone is just as you'd expect it to be. I love how Google has finally been able to create the iPhone equivalent on the Android platform. I knew I would get a great device with a great camera and everything would "just work". 
  
  I have not taken many photos with the 4a yet, however, I will say that for some reason, it just doesn't feel like Night Sight is as "poppy" sometimes lacking a little contrast and saturation that I came to expect from the 3a. 
  
  Also, coming from the smaller 3a to a 4a (5G), the screen is much larger, although the phone itself isn't far from the size of a 3a, thanks to the near non-existent bezels on the top and bottom. The larger screen is 100% more difficult to navigate with one hand, however. 
  
  All in all, I'm very happy with my choice of the Pixel 4a (5G)

If you are lucky enough to get a phone with no issues, then you may be really happy with the Pixel 4a 5G. The battery life alone was phenomenal. If you're a light user like me, this really should have been a 5 star phone. I was not so lucky. 
  
  I had the misfortune of getting a phone that had audio problems (static noise on every phone call) right out of the box. A few months later, it developed more severe problems where the phone would restart randomly during calls. 
  
  Now, normally, this would not be enough to warrant a one star review. But Google's technical support process was, well, comically bad. How bad? Negative 10 stars bad. 
  
  Without getting too far into the details, after four months of back-and-forth with Google Support emails and chats, we did not reach a satisfactory conclusion and I basically gave up. 
  
  Their support process was an absolute nightmare and feels like it was DESIGNED to waste your time. They escalated through 4 or 5 levels of support managers, always apologizing, but never really addressing the questions or issues raised. They usually just copy-pasted the same replies and said "this is our policy". 
  
  RMAs are usually no big deal. But Google sent me on a fool's errand involving factory resets, Safe Mode experiments, visiting a local repair shop (that didn't stock the right the parts), going back to Best Buy, and then, and then, and then... Felt like I had a full time job trying to get this darn phone fixed or replaced. 
  
  Just know going in that if anything goes wrong with your phone outside of the Best Buy return window, Google can make it VERY HARD to solve the problem and is more focused on their own policies than on customer satisfaction. The only thing that got their attention was to post on Twitter, and then they eventually escalated the case and provided some RMA options for a refurbished replacement. 
  
  It's kind of a shame. I wanted to like this phone, but the terrible customer service experience really put me off of Google hardware, probably for awhile.

The Google Pixel 4a 5G falls in between the Pixel 4a and Pixel 5 in terms of features. If you don’t need all the bells and whistles of the Pixel 5, you can save some money with the 4a 5G. At the same time, it’s worth paying extra for the 4a 5G over the 4a. As the name implies, 5G capability is the most obvious upgrade over the 4a, but the real value is the excellent camera. It’s the same camera hardware and software that’s in the flagship Pixel 5. 
  
  PROs
  • 2 cameras on the back plus 1 in front. It’s the same Pixel camera hardware and software as the flagship Pixel 5. Photos are excellent though a bit undersaturated and with less dynamic range than my iPhone 11 Pro (I know, unfair comparison). 
  • Headphone port which is great because my earbuds aren’t always charged and ready to go
  • Large 6.2” screen yet doesn’t feel heavy
  • Decent speaker sound for a phone
  • Fingerprint sensor on the back
  • 128 GB storage is standard 
  • 3 years worth of Android updates directly from Google
  • Good price for the feature set
  
  CONs
  • No wireless charging
  • No SD card slot for adding storage space
  • Not water or dust resistant
  • 60Hz refresh makes the display not as smooth as the 90Hz on the Pixel 5 (or 120Hz on higher end phones of other brands). This is noticeably mostly in action games. For general texting, email, web surfing, etc… you won’t notice it. 
  
  Since 5G is still in early rollouts and not available everywhere, the standout feature here is the camera. For most people, a general purpose phone with a good camera is all they really need. And the Pixel 4a 5G delivers on that.

The Pixel 4a5g is the best of the new Google Pixel devices. While it may cost $150 more than the regular 4a, the amount of added features can't be understated. It has a battery of 3800 mah over the pixel 4a's 3085 (It might be 3185). Furthermore, this phone has the same processor as the $700 pixel 5: The snapdragon 765g. The chipset is complemented perfectly by the larger battery, so the higher consumption is negligible. Furthermore, its screen is significantly bigger than the 4a, and the main reason why I chose this device. While it may have larger bezzels than its 700 dollar counterpart, the 4a5g has a larger screen than the 5. Additionally, it has the same camera system as the 5, including the ultrawide which the 4a is missing. 
  
  Now that the differences are out of the way, the 4a5g as a standalone device is amazing. It has excellent battery life, a clear 1080p OLED display, a clean software experience, great integration with google services, and the best camera on a phone for its price. Google's image software can turn mediocre hardware into titan-levels of incredible. 
  The headphone jack and rear fingerprint scanner are the cherries on top. 
  I can't recommend this device enough to those who just want a standard phone that can do everything really well. I can't find a single flaw with it.

The Google Pixel 4a 5G is the next step up from the standard 4a and older 3a, with this model offering 5G (where available) and a slightly larger OLED screen at 6.2 inches (at 1080p resolution). With 128 gigs of storage (no card slot for more, though), 6 gigs of RAM, and a new Snapdragon 765G processor, you will see a bump in speed over the previous Pixel 3a for sure. While considered a mid-range processor and while the screen is 60hz in a time where many phone are updating to 90 or 120 hz screens, I still find everything to flow smoothly when using this new model. The OLED screen is very nice, showing true blacks and good viewing angles, with a noticeable bump in brightness over the Pixel 3a before it. Sound has received a boost as well with stereo speakers being louder than the previous model – a very welcome update. Charging is via USB-C but unfortunately, there is no wireless charging on this model (Boo). 
  
  There are now two cameras on the back of the Pixel 4a 5G – one is the standard 12.2 megapixel variant which is still excellent but hasn’t changed much in the last couple of versions of the Pixel series. A 16 megapixel extra-wide camera is now also on back, so you can get more into your photos as needed. HDR, high dynamic range, where you see more details in darker and lighter areas, has always been a strength in the Pixel line, and is just as excellent in these cameras, as well as the amount of detail captured in the photos. Details appear in the shadows without blown-out bright areas in most photos, which not all phone cameras are good at. The 8 megapixel front facing camera (now in the upper-corner of the front) is also very good, though not quite as wide angle as some may like. Portrait modes are available on the cameras. Again, while they haven’t evolved much, they haven’t really had to – they are still really, really, good cameras. Software offers Panoramic shots (which unfortunately I found only average, not showing as much detail as standard shots, a photo sphere feature, and Google Lens (to ID objects, etc). The built-in flash does a decent job when needed. 
  
  Movies can be taken in 1080p or 4K at 30 or 60 frames per second. Slower motion features offer faster frames in 1080p. While the still photo capability of the Pixel phones has been the or among the best of all smart phones for the last few years, I’m not quite as pleased with the video quality. It’s “ok”, but many times lacks details, and when zooming even a small amount, can get very pixelated very quick. Again, NOT the case with the still shots. If photos are your thing, this is a phone to strongly consider. If video is your top priority, there may be better options available. 
  
  I tested The 4a 5G out using Good Fi’s cell service. Call quality was good – the speaker and microphones had no problem allowing me to hear others clearly, and for them to hear me clearly as well. The 5G antenna kicked in when it detected service in the area(s) I was in, but even now it’s still hit-or-miss. The best 5G speed I clocked was at 103mbs download and only just above 12mbs upload – and those speeds varied greatly depending on whether I was inside, outside, what room I was in, or if I was near larger objects. So while 5G services in general have a way to go, the antennas in the phone itself for 5G as well as WiFi seemed to be strong and do just fine. 
  
  I can only find two things to gripe about on this phone: First, the fingerprint reader on the back is flush with the body, and sits near the camera module; it’s VERY hard to “feel” with your finger, much more so than the 3a was. I strongly suggest getting a case that has a raised area around the reader button so it help guide your finger to it (and provides extra grip). The second complaint is battery life; the 3885 mAh battery charges quick enough with the 18 watt charger that comes with the phone, but it drains pretty quickly – I dare say, it seems at least, to drain even more quickly than the 3a, which wasn’t great on it’s own. If you are a light to medium user, you can get through a standard work day with this, but if your use falls into the high-medium to high use category, you may want to have a battery bank, or chargers around to top off as the day progresses. Things may improve slightly as the battery conditions itself with multiple chargings, or if you turn off the always-on part of the display which shows you your time and notification icons (but that’s part of the convenience of this phone – having that on). 
  
  Phone makers are pushing the boundaries of price these days with some niche phones reaching close to the $2,000 mark (!!) and the average flagship phone being at or close to $1,000.00. So to find something with all of the features of the 4a 5G for an average price of $499 (often on sale further) is wonderful. For most people, I personally think this phone would be all they need so long as you do not have a very specific need for a very long-life battery or must have the very top processor for special games or apps that need it. Pixels get updates before all other Androids, and again, the camera (for photos) is still extremely hard to beat. Recommended.

This is a great phone that offers premium features for half the price of a iPhone or Samsung Galaxy. The OLED display has a beautiful image quality, the cameras are extremely high quality, it has run every app I have tried on it extremely well, it is a premium product for a mid-range price. 
  
  I would highly recommend this phone for anyone who is looking for the best value for what they pay. The phones that cost less than this one generally are of much lower quality, while there are iPhone's and Galaxy's that may beat this in certain specs they don't beat it by enough to justify their much higher price tags. The Pixel 4a 5G is the latest iteration of the "lite" version of its flagship phone, though I find it difficult finding what makes it the lesser product. There are features that the 4a 5G has that I would have gladly paid more for over the Pixel 5, like the headphone jack and slightly larger 6.2" screen, though the wireless charging (and reverse wireless charging) features didn't make the cut. 
  
  Coming from a Pixel 3, the larger phone is obviously heavier, and the huge camera panel in the back practically begs for a case as the camera does not sit flush with the back panel. A larger screen means that reaching for the edges of the screen, where most of the UI elements that my thumbs are used to, now sit just out of reach, requiring a slight hand adjustment every time. That might be why the stock UI default is the gesture style instead of the old three button. Not being a fan of the gesture style since it is one extra movement to use the back button (as well as swiping in from the left already being a gesture for many apps that I already use), I changed back to the three button mode post haste. 
  
  The centerpiece of the phone has got to be the camera. Double-tapping the power button brings up the camera in an instant. Zero shutter lag means you capture the exact image you intend. This 5G version of the 4a also borrows the ultrawide angle lens found in the Pixel 5, something the regular 4a lacks. The ultrawide lens lets you capture more of a scene, but also gives subjects that distorted funhouse mirror look. 
  
  I think that the best thing about this phone is just how unremarkable it is. While that may sound bad, it's honestly refreshing to have a phone behave the way you expect with nothing extra. Apps start up quickly, security updates come regularly directly from Google. Unless you really need the waterproofing and wireless charging, or some kind of gimmick like a folding screen or a pen, this is the phone to get. So long as you are using a provider that offers it in a supported location, the 5G download speeds are blazing fast. In my area I was pulling down 185 Mbps using the Speedtest app, and 200 Mbps according to Netflix's FAST app. 
  
  I received the fabric case to review, and while it does the job of protecting the back of the phone, especially the protruding camera, I find it too scratchy to use.

I was specifically looking for an inexpensive Android phone that can be used primarily as a music player and occasionally as a backup phone / GPS for my car. The phone will not win any speed records, and using it through Android Auto can be sluggish at times. But for the price point, the advantages (large battery, bright display) outweigh the drawbacks (speed). I will likely buy a second one in the next few months, since I will need two Android music players before the end of the year.

This is going to be a rough one. As a company, OnePlus has been built on offering fantastic, flagship performing smartphones for many years. This phone was a massive mis-step for them, regardless of the price. Let's dive in:
  
  Screen: After taking the phone out of the box and using it for awhile, the first thing that confused me was OnePlus' decision on display tech. While an LCD display in this price category isn't unusual, the choice to have it at only 720p HD vs 1080p on similar phones in this price segment (Moto G) was confusing. Moreover, it's also a 90hz refresh rate display. This would usually mean the phone would feel silky smooth while using it, but not in this case. This is likely due to the processor choice OnePlus made here, which brings us to our next point. 
  
  Processor: This phone is equipped with a Snapdragon 460 chipset. In real-world terms, this is the bottom of the barrel as far as performance goes. I don't understand why OnePlus didn't at least opt for a Snapdragon 660 for this one. This would have made a WORLD of difference. Even with the 90hz display on this phone, it CRAWLS. It's extremely disappointing and unbecoming of OnePlus and deals a blow to their brand image. Even casual users that don't game or anything will notice this lag. 
  
  Cameras: They're there, they're passable, but that's it. Don't expect any nice shots out of these. 
  
  All in all, as I said earlier, the fact that this phone exists is very confusing to me. OnePlus could have done so much more to make this phone at least passable for it's price range, but as it stands it's a massive flop and the worst phone I've used in many, many years; and I've used many, many phones. If you're shopping in this price range, I would pass on this and go for something like the Moto G Power 2021. You'll get a lot more bang for your buck going that route.

I decided to take a chance and get this phone. I've been a loyal Android fan for as long as I can remember, but it seems that so many people have and love their iPhones. So, I thought I'd give it a try. Here are my findings:
  
  1) This design is worse than the Pixel 3 with the chin and forehead. They really should have spent some money updating the design. 
  
  2) The camera is poor at night or in dark shots. I'm pretty confident it is merely a software thing and Apple could easily update it, so it is frustrating that it would not be available at launch. I did install Neural Night Cam and that helped a lot. 
  
  3) TouchID - it's not even remotely the same as on an Android with a fingerprint reader. I did not like how it functioned as the back button or that you had to hard press it. Maybe some people do, but it just wasn't for me. I prefer gestures. 
  
  4) iOS - lacks so much ability to customize as you can with Android. This is probably the major reason I returned the phone. It is just not the same experience, despite what skin you use with Android.

Overall I think this phone is a good deal if you can get it on sale like I did. In general I think samsung has chosen the right hardware points to compromise on, but I find Samsung's approach to android extremely frustrating. 
  
  I bought this phone as an upgrade to my 3 year old OnePlus 5t. I think this phone is in a similar place in the market as that phone when it was new. I like the hardware of this phone. It seems to have all the useful features (wireless charging, water resistance, sd card) with none of the gimmicks. The notable exceptions are the battery life and and the lack of 3.5mm headphone jack. Reviews I read led me to believe that this phone would have above average battery life with over a day on the tank. In reality I find it much worse than my old phone. I can just squeak out one day with the phone typically under 10% at the end. The 5t would easily go 2 days. I use the phone a lot during the day for streaming music, podcasts, and/or audio books to bluetooth earbuds. On top of the mediocre battery life, the phone is much slower to charge than my old OnePlus 5t and the included power brick is not even the fastest charging one for the phone. You have to buy that separately, lol. The one other hardware(?) Related gripe I have is that this phone has no ability to turn itself on for an alarm. The 5t could wake itself for the alarm, this phone cannot. So if you plan to use it as an alarm, you will need to leave it on all night. Otherwise the hardware is great and I am happy with it. The expandable storage is a nice touch. 
  
  My main gripe is with Samsung's take on android. This is my first samsung phone and I find One UI buggy and frustrating. Samsung really wants you to use their ecosystem but it seems like it offers realtively few actually useful features. A lot of the features seemed geared towards allowing you to interact with other people with samsung phones. This approach works with apple because iPhones are ubiquitous enough, but literally none of my friends have samsung phones so most of these features are useless wastes of space to me. Samsung does allow you to uninstall some of the apps that come with the phone, but not enough in my opinion. Some of the default samsung apps have ads in them which feels extremely cheap when you have already bought a premium device from the company. 
  
  What's really frustrating is how hard they make it for you to opt out of the samsung ecosystem. For example, I use the microsoft launcher, but every time I reboot the phone it changes the default launcher app back to Samsung's One UI. I have to go into settings to change it back and then also wipe the cache and storage for the one UI app to get the phone to use the microsoft launcher again (a bit strange for a company that does a lot of partnerships with microsoft). Additionally, I use the Google messages app for texting, but the phone app/combo has difficulting downloading MMSs that were sent while the phone was disconnected (airplane mode or off). I have to switch the default messaging app back to the samsung one, download the MMS to read it, and then change back to the messaging app I prefer. As a final example, a long press of the power button by default launches bixby, Samsung's personal assistant. If you change your personal assistant app (to, say, google) the power button still launches bixby. You can change the power button to instead bring up the power menu, but there is no way to have it bring up the personal assistant of your choice. Seriously? All of this seems like manipulative and coercive attempts to get you to use their apps so thay they can profit off you via ad revenue. It's against the spirit of android. If I had wanted to be forced into an ecosystem I would have bought an iphone; they do a better job with that if only because the have a larger market share. 
  
  There are some software features that are nice touches though. The link to windows feature is cool and useful, allowing you to pull up apps from your phone on your windows 10 pc. Samsung Dex seems like some cool innovation and I like the idea of it, though at the moment I don't really have a use case for it. 
  
  So overall my advice is: if you have already owned galaxy phones and like Samsung's software, this phone is a great deal for you. Otherwise I would advise a purer android experience like a pixel phone or a OnePlus. If you want an ecosystem but haven't bought into samsung yet, get an iPhone.

I'm coming from android, and I do like android more (I miss being able to pop videos/maps, etc., to the screen as a pop-up while you're doing other stuff on the phone, and doing things like downloading gifs from the internet (like reddit downloading is multi-step on the iphone, having to use an alternative site, etc. Cannot download the videos, like you can on android). Its ease-of-use is far outclassed by android, and if you're looking for a great phone, with FAR more to do, and far cooler tricks, definitely go android instead. Otherwise, if yuo're a dead-set apple fan, this isn't a bad phone. it just has a lot limited, in comparison to what can be done on android. But for an iphone, it's very good!

Be warned- the unlocked S20FE 5G is not compatible with Verizon’s mmWave 5G, only sub-6, which has yet to be rolled-out by Verizon. I honestly don’t understand why Samsung would release an unlocked version that does not provide full functionality on all carriers, what is the point? 
  
  Although I was able to get a great deal on this phone, I will have to return it, as I use Xfinity Mobile and they operate on Verizon’s towers, thus requiring the S20FE 5G UW (Ultra Wide) model that is currently only produced for Verizon contracts. 
  
  What a confusing mess for the average consumer that purchases this expecting to take full advantage of 5G capability across all carriers.

While overall this is a very nice phone, and I especially love the display and some of the other features, I just come to the conclusion, before I return this thing, that is just not worth the money. 
  
  In the first place the dual screen display is for all practical purposes useless - a gimmick. The mere fact of being able to look at two different screens while running two different apps is not necessary at all except in the most extreme situations. It really doesn't do what it claims it does even when sliding one app from the main screen over to the second screen - in most cases it doesn't work! The battery life is not good either especially if you use the dual screen a lot. 
  
  What I also found out was that shortly after I bought it LG released the upgrade to android 10, which totally wiped out the dual screen feature. It was later on in the day a second firmware update was released to correct the dual screen issue and which also removed a couple of the default dual screen apps! When I called LG support, apparently they weren't even aware of this and told me to just reset the phone! 
  
  The other very annoying thing is, not being able to find another case for the phone. The dual screen does come with a case to mount the main unit into, but it's not a very good case. The outside or third screen and the camera area which is very exposed for some reason, are very susceptible to being scratched or damaged in any situation of being dropped! The outside vendor screen protectors do not work! 
  
  I've noticed in many reviews people loved this phone, and frankly I'd like it too, but there's just too many things that can go wrong, while not having a lot of things that go right! I thought getting this phone would allow me to go on Facebook for example, look at the image or video of what I was responding to, and being able to type it in on the other screen. In reality that is not what happens and even if there is an app to do that, how much work would it be to get it to work. 
  
  The concept of this phone is wonderful, it just needs to be more refined, and more standard. 
  
  The other problem is when using the dual screen, the magnetic connector that connects the USB – C cord, is a totally bad idea, and does not allow this when the dual screen is mounted to use a USB- C adapter to connect anything else such as a separate hard drive, although it will allow you to connect to a computer. 
  
  Overall for me, the phone is impractical. I do not carry my phone in my hand as many do nor do I carry my phone in my butt pocket as many do. The third screen is going to get scratched! If you carry it in a holster is too much trouble to keep pulling it out thereby increasing the chances of it being dropped! Because it is a dual screen apparently nobody is going to make a holster on which to carry it. And although you can fold the dual screen back 180° against the main phone, now you make that dual screen susceptible to being damaged or scratched! 
  
  Just not practical!

I have this phone since the beginning of last December. It is a perfect phone for me as I like multitasking, reading chats when reading news, looking up google map for spots while google for facts. It was unbelievably cheap and reliable when compared with the other fold phones. It is fast no doubt but the screen is the single factor that was a 'love at first sight'! There are minor issues which I get used to: charging using the magnetic dongle-type adapter (but I can just throw and it sticks in the dark) , holding a heavier phone (but you can't complain when you have dual), flipping to get the main camera (but you get a perfect stand for self-fie), etc.
  Another plus side is that my wife like the dual screen to see what she would look like before I snap the pictures on the other screen /side. 
  The battery life is good as I have never ran out of juice for a day's use. It has enormous space to store and it even can have an expansion slot for micro SD (up to 1tB). 
  I went for a trip to San Francisco over the last Christmas and the Golden Gate Bridge looks perfect taken by this phone! 
  Overall, I think it is a gem that is unknown to many others.

As much as I live the performance and easy upgrade setup, I am disappointed in the lack of features and accessories included with this latest version of the Galaxy S series. First, I had not realized that Samsung did away with the SD card option. Had I realized this I would have gone for the S20. My other disappointment is the lack of included accessories. This phone is for my wife since I just bought the S20 last year. My phone came with a headset, charging block and USB wire. The S21 only included a short USB-C wire. It seems to me that either Samsung is getting cheap or they're trying to emulate Apple's cost-cutting measures. In either case, I wish they would stop following Apple. If I liked Apple products I would have bought an iPhone instead of a Galaxy. If they continue in this manner, my next phone may be a Google or LG.

I like this phone. The phone itself works well and the dual screen is the added bonus that tipped it over the scales for me. The foldable screen makes a great stand while watching vids. Good speaker and microphone. The front display is really nothing more than the clock. Great battery power. The phone is no bigger than the Samsung line and only slightly heavier with the dual case but you do need to open the case to answer the call. The speakerphone is a problem as others have stated; when on it lasts about a minute then drops the call. I hate large phones. I felt the previous SE, at 4.87in tall, was the PERFECT size for my hands, one-handed browsing, pocket real estate, and several other benefits. So imagine my dismay when Apple announced the next SE was going with the 7/8 size. My old SE started getting slow and I was looking into other non-Apple, similarly sized alternatives. But hearing that this had the same guts as the top of the line XI, and it still had the physical button and absence of the "notch" (no offense to fans of that style, it's just not for ME), at a price point of $399, for 64GB MINIMUM, well, I dove in. Not disappointed so far. Blazing fast, razor sharp, easy to hold. The adjustment to the larger dimension was not as much as I'd feared, and the VALUE. Oh my goodness, dollar for dollar, this might be the greatest Apple phone value EVER (i get it, Android fanboys, there's probably a Google phone or Samsung Device that has more value than this product, but for Apple users, this is the BEST). I'll always miss and love the old SE, but this is a worthy, gorgeous, powerful, and "budget-friendly" successor well worth your time.
