I have been a samsung person since day one. Everything i own is samsung. I saw this LG phone and HAD to have it. So this is my review of this phone, ive owned it for aobut 2 days now. 
  
  Pros:
  Really fast phone, everything seems to open and run quickly, i had a galaxy s8+, so this seems much faster. 
  The dual screen is amazing, love that i can do 2 things at once, very helpful & quality is nice. 
  The wallpapers for the dual screen are nice. 
  Videos look great, watched a couple of them, love that i can switch from screen to screen. 
  Memory is good, but you end up with about 96 gigs after all the installs. Thankfully you can add i believe up to 2tb in a memory card. 
  Calls are clear and crisp. 
  The bulky and feel of it isnt at bad as some reviewers say. 
  Battery life is amazing
  Sound is amazing!!!!! 
  
  Cons:
  Its a different android, u cant swipe up for apps. All the apps are on the main screen, took awhile to figure out how to hide them all and only have my apps. 
  No screen protectors for the front of the dual screen case, u can see fingerprints really good and needs to wipe off often. Bought a universal protector to put on it. 
  Fm radio is good, but you need to take phone out of case for headphones to go into phone directly unless you buy an adapter. 
  Limited wallpaper for dual screens and no live wallpapers, assuming this will change. 
  Found a couple wallpapers, but have to use paypal to purchase instead of adding credit card. Hoping this will change in time as well. 
  Screen is deff 1080p, not 4k unfortunally. Screens and videos look nice, but not as vibrant as a 4k screen, ive noticed such as on pokemon go, colors sometimes seem washed and not as whoa as they were on the samsung screen. 
  
  Over all, very happy with this phone. It seems good and solid, the hinge on the case is sturdy and good for leveling out for pics and videos. Its cheaper then the single screen foldable phones which is also a + in my book. I got it for 699 unlocked, works with no issues with my carrier. So for the price and quality, deff worth getting. 4 stars is only cause the android not being as user friendly as with other phones. You have to go into settings to "hide" the apps from the main screen you dont like instead of just clicking, then hitting remove.

Here are my first impressions after having the phone for three days. 
  
  Pros
  - Nice camera. It's not professional grade, but for the average consumer, it's great. 
  - Widgets! This is my first time using a android device, and I still have a lot to learn about the OS, but so far I've really enjoyed being able to customize the screen with various widgets. 
  
  Cons
  -The finger print reader could be better. It requires a second scan about 1/3 of the time
  -Not a quality speaker for music. This isn't a problem if you plan on listening to music with your headphones, (Bluetooth, as there is no audio jack), but if you like to Jam with your friends you should get a separate Bluetooth speaker. 
  -Too big for hands and pockets. 
  
  Additional Notes
  - Bixby vs Google Assistant. Similar to Siri, Bixby and Google Assistant allow you to search things and access various phone features by voice, such as adding an event to your google calendar in a single sentence. However, they work in very different ways and having two options is confusing. 
  
  Bixby is optimized to work with Samsung/Microsoft features, and will only work with pre-made 'capsules', like Netflix or Spotify. For example, if I say 'Play the Duck Tales theme song', Bixby asks me to add a Spotify account and will not play my music from YouTube Music or Apple Music. 
  
  Google Assistant operates more like Google. It has better search functions and will play music from any app I ask. However, Google Assistant and Bixby have different apps for their reminders, and when I add a reminder using Google Assistant it does not add it to the Samsung 'Reminders' widgets. 
  
  It is nice to have options, but it feels like Samsung, Microsoft, and Google are all fighting for your attention on the same device.

This review is just my opinion on what I experienced while I was using this Samsung S20 FE 5g phone, I'm not a License Professional nor a Tech person just a consumer. What I like about Samsung S20 FE 5g are the features of the phone it was fast, & it has expandable memory like microSD slot, NFC, water resistance (as long as you don't dip it in a pool for a long time lol! ), For internet connections it has a Wi-Fi 802.11 a/b/g/n/ac/ax 2.4g+5ghz Awesome! , Bluetooth, and for the Camera this one has a rear Triple Camera 12MP Ultra Wide (back) while in a (Front) for Selfie ones it has 32MP Camera perfect for taking pictures and use it in a mini photo box studio. When you open any Applications & scroll it… You'll see how smooth & fast if you try one. For a display screen, I was amazed how clear it was for watching a video in a 6.5-inch 6 Infinity-O Super AMOLED display screen with a super smooth 120Hz. 
  The only thing that I don' t like is that this model does not have a dual sim for the price that I paid. I know all phones are very expensive but for the phone that is a hefty price they should have put that features as well. 
  If you're looking for a dual sim make sure to double-check at the store first if they carry one. I was looking for a dual SIM, but unfortunately I have no other choice back then because they only have 1 phone available in their store. I'm not sure if all best buy carry a single sim model only since mine that I bought from the store was just a single sim model. Double check to the store if you need a dual sim instead because not all models has a double SIM card or a Hybrid SIM Slot, I'm sure some of them carry those double sim card model.

I was finally ready to move up from the smaller screen original iPhone SE and this was the obvious next phone to have. I'm delighted with it. 
  
  The screen is not just bigger but has a better picture quality so it's easier to see what's happening. Watching small figures and a ball during football highlights is a whole new experience. The sound quality is better too, I can now clearly hear individual instruments when listening to good quality recordings. 
  
  Colleagues have commented on how much clearer the camera is during video conferencing. Also the quality of taken photos is so much clearer. There are new features such as portrait mode that blurs the background to emphasise the subject. 
  
  Essentially it's similar to earlier IPhones but better is many ways.

My old phone was an iPhone 6s and by the generation, you can tell I was in the need of a new phone. I contemplated the pixel 4a between the iPhone SE because I am on a budget and did not desire high specs. Long story short the Pixel 4a was back-ordered and canceled so I did more searching and discovered the Galaxy FE. It has an attractive price with the specs of a flagship phone. After researching other phones I knew it was worth it to shovel out an extra $200 to get this phone. Not to mention, it is already on sale for $150 off! This is my first android phone and here are my first impressions:
  
  1. Extremely customizable, make it functional to your liking. One of my favorite features is reducing the screen size to reach all buttons with one hand. 
  2. The screen is big, which makes watching videos and playing games more immersive and enjoyable. 
  3. The picture quality is amazing. You have various modes to capture the right picture. The night mode is especially good. It does a good job and brightening dark areas without over saturating. 
  4. The OLED screen is crisp. Also, the 120Hz refresh rate makes navigating through the phone smooth and seamless. 
  5. The sound quality is surprisingly good. It has Dolby Atmos, which boosts sound quality and clarity. 
  
  These are just my first impressions. But this phone is probably the best phone for the money.

So far so good. Easy to transfer stuff from my other phone. Disappointed it didn't come with the tool to open up the simcard slot. Great color, excellent camera. Upset that Samsung did away with the memory card and headphone jack

My S9+ stopped working so gave the S20 FE a try based on price without much research. If the following is of importance then this phone is not a good choice:
  1) The blue notification light is gone. Only way to see notifications if you are away from the phone is to unlock the lock screen and check. Really annoying
  2)The samsung health app no longer has pulse and an oximeter. Not sure why this was dropped
  3) No headphone jack. All bluetooth which is not much of a big deal except I have a bunch of earbuds of no use. 
  4) The screen timeout still has not been fixed when on a phone call. It just goes dark. This is a hold over from the S9
  
  All in all nothing to rave about hence 3 stars

Great price at 399$, at the beginning battery life and charging speed were terrible, almost to the point of wanting to return the phone, but I figured out that if you used the medium battery saving profile and use a quick charge 4.0 21w+ charging brick, both issues were solved and even with the dual screen on, battery life is great. 
  The dual screen usual an adapter that can get lost and does not give the max 21w, can be easily lost and disconnected, aswell as being difficult to find a replacement and expensive, but acceptable. 
  and the dual screen case is very fragile, aswell as glass screen protectors for it are very rare and expensive, ended up buying about 50$ worth of screen protectors because of this+8$ for the charging adapter. 
  Wide view mode is very appropriated, and can be unlocked to all apps through a third party app, which makes it much more worth it. 
  I enabled Tablet mode since I felt it works well with the dual screen by changing the DPI in dev options to 720. 
  All in All, owning the phone went from hating it, to liking it, to loving it. 
  My second option was the Samsung S10 lite, but it was 50$ more expensive on sale and after missing the sale went up alot, I wanted it for the 45W charging and better software, but in the end, I didnt feel I lost much since I loved the dual screen, also I bought it since verizon doesn't allow chinese phones, these would be my perfered, but for what I can get, this was good, last phone was a Razer Phone 2 for the same verizon reason, and that didn't turn out well at all with reliability, lets hope this one will last, I owned a LG G2, G5 and G7, had issues with all but the G7, but loved them very much. 
  Another thing, I attached Sugru to the dual screen case to make it more rugged, which worked great.

I've been using Apple since the Mac Quadra and use iMacs every day so you'd think the iphone was a good fit: WRONG. I tried iphones 7 years ago and ending up smashing mine in frustration.   I returned the SE, paid the $45 restocking fee, and bought a $150 Samsung. IMMEDIATELY it screen casted and the massive screen would have cost $1099 IF it were even available on the iphone. 
  
  WHY WHY WHY do people pay so much for Apple when they have an inferior operating system? I don't really CARE that the 12 has the "fastest processor ever" -- I do everything important on iMacs, not my phone! MUST BE A SOCIAL THING that I'm not privy to. I'll never understand why people are willing to fork over five hundred or a thousand dollars for a phone you can't even expand the memory in. Must be Apple's marketing.

At $600 the Galaxy S20 FE 5G is too much of a good deal to pass up. Sure, there are several very good mid-tier devices out there today, but for $600 you are getting a brand-new device that performs better (in almost any area) than many year-old flagships that used to cost more than $900. Here's what I can tell you based on my last 48 hours playing with the phone: 1. The cameras are outstanding (day or night), even when compared to state-of-the-art phones from less than a year ago. 2. The phone supports 5G, which works quite well with my current provider. 3. The screen, which is flat and great for screen protectors, is also flagship quality (120 Hz refresh rate) 4. The battery is great. 5. The phone has a top-of-the line processor. 
  
  OK, the S20 FE lacks a 3.5 mm audio jack; however, I can trade that for the ability to expand the phone's memory via a micro-SD card. 
  
  Again, there are so many good things packaged in this device that I'm happy it exists at this price point. In my opinion, and from an entirely pragmatic / techie point of view, the Galaxy S20 FE 5G is one of the best deals I've seen in a while. Grab your face mask and head to Best Buy for a demo, I think you won't be disappointed.

I've been using this phone for two months now and I've got to say that I really enjoy it. The dual screen functions work seamlessly together, and especially for the price that you pay, you really do get a great quality phone. The battery life is actually not that bad. I can go a full day of using it regularly without having to get a charge in until I go to bed. Trying to use the phone with one hand is definitely going to be a challenge so if that is you then this is not the phone for you. It is quite bulky so, although it does go into your pocket, it is definitely going bulge out quite a bit. 
  
  I often remove it from the dual screen case to use as a single screen phone for when I'm driving to attach it to a mount. This doesn't seem to affect the connectivity between the case and the phone over time. It's only been two months, but based on the quality of the build, I don't see it being an issue further down the line either. 
  
  Two things that I didn't like. One, there aren't any tempered glass screen protectors out there that fit the phone and the dual screen case. There are a lot of glass parts that are exposed very often. So I don't trust a normal film screen protector. So it's a shame that I can't get a tempered glass protector for every screen, especially the outside front screen and the ridiculously large cut out for the camera and the logo on the back. I imagine it was made this way to show the logo, but I think that was a huge oversight on LG's part. 
  
  Two, they provide a magsafe dongle to be able to connect a charging cable to your phone while it is still in the dualscreen case. It's nice that it was included, but it doesn't stay connected very well. You've got to leave the phone down and the cable with enough slack so that it doesn't fall off the phone. Didn't seem to take too much tension to snap it off the phone. Luckily, I had a wireless charger so I stopped using the dongle and use the wireless charger now. The wireless charging works through the dualscreen case, so that is a plus. 
  
  All in all, I really love the phone and don't regret switching over from a larger brand name flagship phone.

Being as I'm usually on the phone outside and it's just the start of winter (we haven't even hit extreme temps yet) this is going to be a problem. Has anyone else experienced this?

I think the product was good. My primary purpose with the device was to find a device that was not outdated, but up to date; and sleek, with easy user-ability. LG difinately hit the mark on that one. As far as OS goes they kept it simple enough, and classic with a twist on modern technology to 2019 standards, the triple screen case that was included. As far as drop testing the device, I did notice a little bit of a flaw. After the first attempt, and only attempt for that matter, it seemed like weight was a bit of an issue. The impact at 6 feet was to much for it. Opon normal, active standards, 6 feet probably isn't the best approach, but in my eyes, I want a device that can pack a mean punch on ram, and look amazing; but still deliver what's needed, if under intense situations. That's why I rated this device at a 4 instead of a five. The price was comparisingly good, and ram seemed like it fit the description. It was the perfect device for my fiancee, as her device speed standards differ from my own. She does forget to close out applications, and isn't aware of processes that run in the background, or how to stop or foreclose them. 
  Over all, LG did great in my book, and eyes; and gets my honest opinion from here on out! 
  
  -Michael

Two stars for the casing. The shape and smooth texture makes this extremely slippery. It will fall out of your hand easily. 
  
  Be sure to get a cover for it when you buy it or you might drop it the first time you pick it up.

In terms of the processor power and ram, this phone is near the top of the line. For my purposes, it is very quick and responsive. Colors are vibrant, and resolution is good. The size is similar to my old LG V20, and with the dual screen case the thickness is only slightly greater. It is noticeably heavier but still not bad. The optional dual screen is what makes this phone unique, and I'm still adapting to its uses. I'm not much of a multitasker which the dual screen in designed for, but perhaps I will learn to use the second screen in the near future. The price is way more than what I would want to pay for a phone, but YOLO. Probably not a bad value for 2 screens. The bifold design makes it easy to stand up for taking selfies, video chatting, etc. Cameras are fair, and the selfie camera is much better than my old phone. I like that it has wireless charging. The published specs said it came with Android 9.0, but to my pleasant surprise it came with 10.0 and a recent security patch. I popped in my Straighttalk (Verizon towers) SIM card from my old phone, and it was a seamless transition. I didn't even have to mess with APN settings this time. Transferring data like text messages from the old phone is always a hassle, but with the right apps, I got it done. Of course, I love that it accepts a microsd card to expand the memory. 
  
  As for its disadvantages, I suppose it is quite awkward to hold the phone with one hand and swipe with the thumb of the same hand that many people are accustomed to. It definitely requires 2 hands to use. The in-screen finger print reader, as others have mentioned, is not the best and sometimes requires several tries before it reads it. The stand-alone finger printer reader of the V20 was way more responsive. The magnetic charging adapter is kind of an annoyance to carry around, and it is for sure going to get loss. Try looking for a replacement, you'll be dumbfounded by the prices. Unlike the V20, the G8x does not have a replaceable battery, thus you eventually have to deal with a battery that doesn't hold a charge, but hopefully the phone will be replaced for other reasons before that happens. 
  
  I would give it 4.5 star if I could. The dual screen is a curse and a blessing at the same time, but I kind of knew that going in. It is a great phone (albeit no 5G capability) with great specs. I'm still learning to utilize the second screen, and I'm sure with time it will prove useful.

This phone replaced an iPhone 7 that had some weird unexplainable issues. Features that separate the SE from that are as follows:
  
  - Better battery life by 2-3 hours (from her usage pattern, not mine)
  - Wireless charging
  - Portrait mode (Made possible by the A13 Bionic chip)
  - An additional gigabyte of ram
  - Roughly 3x the CPU performance
  - eSIM support
  
  I used to play a few multiplayer games over the phone with my girlfriend and she almost always experienced lag on her iPhone 7. At times, games like Call of Duty Mobile was unusable for her, and lag spikes would transport her to random places on the map. Now she doesn't experience any of the same issues; we can both carry our team again! The iPhone 7 base model only had 32gb of storage, and that's not enough for most people. My music library would take up a quarter of that! The SE starts out at 64gb, but offers 128gb and 256gb storage tiers. For a $50 premium, I believe the 128gb tier offers the best value since it doubles the base storage. Before I gave her the phone, I quickly compared performance throughout the operating system on different websites to the 11 Pro I use. The SE offers similar performance in everything except battery life and multitasking, but for a $450 phone, it definitely holds its own. I'd even consider buying another as a backup (my first 11 Pro unit had charging, booting, and display issues within a month!). 
  
  
  
  **Now that the iPhone XR's price has been cut due to the release of the 12 and 12 Pro, it'd be wise to compare the two. The iPhone XR has an older processor, but it has an edge-to-edge display and face ID for $100 more. Those who frequently wear a mask may still benefit more from the SE since it is cheaper and has Touch ID.

While it's not great for anything that would heavily utilize trigger buttons, it makes gaming pretty solid on this device when not playing most free to play pay-to-tap mobile games. Even my wife, who is definitely not into tech and couldn't tell you an iPhone from a Motorola really loves this device and is planning on getting this or the newer models in the future. As a bonus there is virtually no bloatware on this device and I've only had to disable Facebook and instagram.

I bought the iPhone SE 2020 two months ago after I dropped my trusty iPhone 6s and shattered it. If I had a working mobile phone that I was replacing, I would have returned the iPhone SE. Why? It has absolutely horrific WiFi reception. I am not the only one experiencing this and strongly advise anyone thinking of buying this phone to first check out the Apple Support Community under the heading "IPhoneSE 2020 wifi painfully slow??" In my case, if I am very close to my router, the iPhone SE gets the fastest WiFi reception of any device I own. If I move a little farther out, other Wifi devices I own are getting over 250 mps while the iPhone is either getting around 6 mps or not connecting at all. (Usually the latter.) I have multiple Wifi devices which get reasonable reception on my porch but the iPhone 6s can't connect at all. I still give this phone 2 stars in my review as the phone itself is much faster than my old iPhone 6s and has a much better camera. If Wifi reception is important to you, I encourage anyone buying this phone to research the net for information on its real world Wifi performance before you buy.

  My SE would charge all night and die within FOUR HOURS of being off the charger, EVERY time. I thought maybe it was due to increase use from being home more often but that is not the case - the battery simply sucks. 
  
  If you love small iPhones, home buttons, and charging your phone every four hours - this is the phone for you. If you need to have your phone readily available and actually mobile at all times, go with the 11.

Good performance overall on games such as Genshin Impact and everyday use is mostly smooth and responsive. The plastic back is not an issue either. There are occasional stutters if I switch through apps very quickly which I expected to be better given that this is a 120hz display. The battery life could be better as well as he thermals. If you want a better telephoto lens you would be better off buying the S20 or S20+ which also has LIDAR. Normal lens and the ultra wide are fantastic even in low light. My main gripe with this phone is that sometimes the touch screen wont respond requiring a restart or in the inverse, it ghost touches. These issues are widely reported and I hope software updates fix them; the third one did not. If it is hardware related I hope their is a free repair or swift recall. If this is not fixed the phones rating must drop to a 2/5 as you cannot have issues with the main device input even on a midrange phone. I'd rather have a working Motorola E series.

This phone packs all of the hardware you need at a steal of a price. Same internals as the S20 flagship. Sub 6 and mmwave 5g, snapdragon 865, 6gb ram, and 128gb of UFS storage!! The best part is the 120hz refresh rate at this price point. Everything is smooth and silky and the interface is on point. And on top of that it has better battery life than the regular s20, s20+, note 20 and note 20 ultra! You can’t go wrong. The plastic rear looks beautiful and won’t shatter like glass. There’s really nothing else that you can ask for especially at this price point. 120hz, 5g, flagship specs, excellent camera with night mode, 128gb+ expandable storage, non crackable back and the icing on the cake... IP68 water and dust resistance. Buy this phone while it’s on sale and save even more!!! For $599 this is an absolute steal and is worth every penny for the years to come.

Pros:
  - For those who prefer small compact phones
  - Has the A13 chip, giving it the CPU horsepower of the current iPhone 11 series
  - Is water resistant
  - Wireless charging
  - Display looks great, despite older generation Retina display
  - No intrusive notch
  - Touch ID for those who preferred it
  
  Cons:
  - Old school bezels are back, for those who are fully entrenched in the (nearly) full screen display form
  - No headphone jack (obviously)
  - Design is dated and despite all the pros, the charm can quickly wear off if you're not already a long time fan of this design
  - 3D touch replaced with more mediocre haptic touch
  - Battery life is average at best
  - Camera is decent, but not for picture taking enthusiasts
  
  Most of my pros and cons sum up what I think of this phone, so let me get to that "However..." from the title. I bought this phone, having eagerly awaited the next iPhone SE, which had been rumored under names like iPhone SE 2 and iPhone 9. But make no mistake, this phone is essentially an iPhone 8 with iPhone 11 internals. 
  
  I waited a long time to finally see the next iPhone SE come to fruition and I even preordered it on day 1 once it was officially announced. I knew this would be virtually identical to the iPhone 8 and I didn't mind this. The idea of the CPU being as fast as the iPhone 11, the Apple ecosystem and the phone being comfortably small for my pocket is what sold me...until I actually got the phone. 
  
  Don't get me wrong, this phone performs as awesomely as one can expect and then some. Games are buttery smooth and with the right case, the SE stands on its own merits. Unfortunately, I was also hoping that the more power efficient properties of the A13 chip would result in (even somewhat) longer battery life. That...turned out not to be true. 
  
  The battery is easily this phone's weakest link for even moderate users. If I'm lucky, I'll still have 10% left by the end of the day. But when my days can range from typical to using the phone more heavily, that 10% is too small a margin to be left with when you can easily run out of battery completely before the day is over. That's just unacceptable to me and very disappointing, considering the long anticipation for this phone. 
  
  I ended up having to get an Apple battery case (for the iPhone 7, since none is available for the iPhone 8 or SE, but it works just as well on this iPhone SE) in order to have enough battery power with get through the day with the heaviest use. Thing is, I shouldn't HAVE to require a battery case to get through a typical day. Rather, a battery case should be the exception, not the rule. 
  
  After having this phone for a little over a week, I find myself deciding that as much as I love everything else about it, the weak battery life ended up being a deal breaker for me and will be returning it soon. I wanted to like this phone. And maybe for those who would only use this phone lightly, the battery is ample for them. But for me, the charm of this newest iPhone SE wears off fast once you realize that its battery life gets eaten up too quickly. 
  
  If you still wish to buy this phone, please keep the battery situation in mind when you do. If you're into gaming, watch lots of vids and stream lots of music through bluetooth, you're likely to end up draining the battery completely before you go to bed and will end up having to recharge sooner than you want to. Otherwise, the iPhone SE performs as excellent as its iPhone 11 counterparts, minus the lacking camera and the other cons I listed.

My previous phone was the LG - V20 (lasted me 4 years). I definitely needed a new phone, so as with every large purchase, I searched thoroughly and chose the LG - G8X ThinQ Dual Screen with 128GB. I made the right decision. 
  
  PROS:
  One of the main reasons for my choice was that LG kept the manual video feature that allows the user to manually adjust the gain, low cut filter, and limiter. I'm a musician, so this is useful for recording my rehearsals, and performances 
  
  The dual-screen comes in handy. However, I primarily use it as a phone case and to place the keyboard on the main screen (on bottom) while viewing the text on the second (on top). I'm sure I will use if more often as more apps support the dual-screen feature. 
  
  All cameras on the phone are incredible. I look forward to discovering all the features on the phone including the ASMR feature. 
  
  I highly recommend this phone to anyone involved in the art–musicians, photographers, videographers, vloggers, etc.
  
  CONS: 
  If the dual-screen, in manual video mode, could be used as a monitor as it can in the normal video and selfie modes, that would be awesome. 
  
  This phone (outside of the dual-screen case) is EXTREMELY slippery. I do not recommend handling the phone without a case. It can be easily dropped and it can slide off of ANY surface with the slightest angle. 
  
  The fingerprint lock is disappointing and often frustrating. It worked flawlessly on the V20, however. 
  
  I also wish that the dual-screen had a removable protector for the rear camera.

Be careful when purchasing this phone as Best Buy sales two variants of it. One variant has a microSD slot for expandable memory and the other has a dual SIM card tray. Before I walked out of the store with this phone, I specifically asked the guy behind the counter if this was the unit with the microSD slot. He didn't know. One could argue that they should know this information since they are selling you the product. But any ways, he couldn't find the answer online so he actually opened up the box and checked. He assured me that it did. Imagine my surprise when I got home and discovered that it didn't. Even with my old eyes I could clearly see that the tray said Dual SIM And of course this happened after the store had closed. I was fuming. I have stopped shopping at that particular location. This phone is a game-changer! It allows true multitasking - not just switching between full-screen apps or working on two tiny windows - two full-size screens for your apps/games, etc.
  
  Sure the case itself is a bit bulky with the Dual Screen attached, but it's the only way to currently achieve a reliable foldable form factor that won't be prone to creasing/breaking like the Galaxy Fold. 
  
  The phone's Qualcomm 855 is powerful and the battery is enough for a full day if you're careful with dual screen usage. Luckily, you can simply place it on a wireless charger to top off the battery if you don't want to bring the magnetic adapter with you (or pop the phone out of the case to access the USB-C port). 
  
  Obviously you can get real work done on both screens, but you can also play games on one screen and get work done on the other one. 
  
  The in-screen fingerprint sensor is actually superior to the Note 10+ but it's still not as good as dedicated fingerprint readers. LG had some of the best on their V-series phones. There is no face unlock, so I'm taking advantage of Smart Lock (stay unlocked when paired to a trusted device) more. 
  
  As a flagship-level phone, the price is amazing! This phone keeps the headphone jack, too!

I bought the S20 FE to replace my excellent S8, and to be honest I don't think it is an improvement in any way that I would notice, and in fact has a few issues that are step backwards from the S8. The first, and probably most annoying, is the reaction time of the proximity sensor when you are making a phone call. If you move your phone away from your ear even a little bit, and then move it back the phone is so slow to hide the display that you will frequently end up hitting buttons with your ear. I had several instances where I ended calls, or switched to that annoying "text while calling" mode just by touching the screen with my ear. This is even more annoying because of issue #2, the touch screen responsiveness - or more accurately, the lack of. This is most noticeable when using an app, but does even happen sometimes when you are trying to open one. I can't count the number of times that I have had to touch an icon 2 or 3 times to get it to react. #3, and not as big an issue, but still an annoyance, is the fingerprint scanner. With the S8 the scanner was on the back of the phone, and pretty much always read your print on the first try. The S20, not so much; you almost always have to move your finger a couple of time for it to read, and it seems like you have to hold it in place longer too. Other than those things, the phone has worked very well, but again I don't really see much advantage over the S8. All in all, if I had it to do over I would not have bought this phone.

Had it since middle of Oct. 2020. MY GRIPES: (1) As usual, I have tried 3 times to dictate this and I watch it flashing, then it stops and types NOTHING. (2) It FREEZES all the time, no matter what app I am in. (3). When I dictate period at the end of a sentence or comma somewhere, it spells it out. (4) I had to turn off Auto Captitalize because it was capitalizing 3 or 4 words in the middle of every sentence. (5) It repeats text! Once it repeated 3 lines of text 15 times. (6) The cursor is not stationary. It jumps up and types in the middle of a prior sentence. Or if editing somewhere, the cursor jumps down and starts typing in the middle of another sentence. (7) I have problems with the simple task of copying and pasting! Won't work sometimes unless I type 1 letter 1st, then the Copy option will appear. And, in reverse, many times I get no Paste option unless I type in 1 letter 1st. (8) It is always inserting multiple words I didn't even say that I have to erase. (9) WORST, is their Contacts app. Yellow head, white shoulders and an orange background. I just noticed it a week or so ago. When I clicked on All Contacts, it shows Phone, where I back up my phone to and Verizon Cloud. Almost all Contacts had backed up to my phone. It was a nightmare to fix and get added where I 2anted them to be. I had duplicates galore. When I tried to delete or merge the duplicates, IT ADDS THEM BACK AS A 2nd Contact of the same person THAT CANNOT BE ERASED! I don't know it it is because this phone has Linked Accounts at the end of every contact! I think that is the problem. (10) I set alarms at soon as I have an event but app that came with phone does not put them in date order, so they are all over the place. Sometimes they even disappear. I have to recheck event alarms every week. 
  
  I gave tried 4 times to dictate this to no avail. THIS PHONE HAS BEEN ONE MASSIVE HEADACHE AFTER ANOTHER. SAVE YOURSELF TIME AND TROUBLE!

I'm rating this 5 stars for the *value* you get with this phone. Especially since I got it at the pre-order price of $599 (which I believe may be the current price at the moment). 
  
  Prior to this, I've only bought Google branded phones since 2011 (though that phone was the Galaxy Nexus, which was made by Samsung, my last Samsung phone before this one). Then I had the Nexus 5, then the Nexus 6P, then the Pixel 2 XL, and now this. 
  
  Coming from pure Google experience phones, this took a bit to get used to. It's much heavier than the P2XL, but still feels good in the hand. 
  
  Basically, the phone is crazy fast, and has almost all of the latest tech you could want in a flagship, while giving up the most cutting edge stuff (that I don't notice, and many others likely won't), in order to bring the price back down to earth. 
  
  It has UFS 3.1 storage (as fast as you can currently get in an Android phone). 
  
  It has WiFi 6 (I don't have any WiFi 6 capable routers yet anyway). 
  
  It has a 120Hz display (which is awesome, but after loving that for a few weeks, I switched it to 60Hz, and I haven't regretted that move). The point is that it's your choice, and you can toggle whenever you want. 
  
  Cameras are very good (perhaps not Pixel quality, but they're definitely more versatile). "One Shot" mode is a ton of fun. 
  
  At $599, this is a no-brainer. At $699 (list), it's an exceptional value, but other phones at least enter the competition.

Got this this for my wife on Oct 31. After setting it and using the phone, it's is really worth the money. Even though it has a plastic back instead of a metal/glass back, it's still solid and wonderful looking. The refresh rate is amazing (120hz), the camera on it is as good as it gets for the money as it takes solid quality images. The focusing is super fast and responsive and the 3x zoom is something that most phones still don't have physically Although the screen is just 2400x1800 AMOLED not UHD 4K, you really cannot tell (tbh, unless you're a smartphone aficionado, you can't tell screens that small having great resolutions or not). 
  
  The battery size is great and unlike many flagship phones, it's bigger than most of them and it charges pretty fast. Bonus also that it has an expandable memory slot (1TB) which is located on the reverse side of the SIM card slot (first time I've ever seen that!). If I had one drawback for the phone is that this model could have used 8gig of RAM instead of six. I know this phone was made less expensive cutting certain features from the what's available on the other S20 models, but as cheap as RAM is, I think that could've been put in. 
  
  I have an S10 I got over a year ago, and it's just as good, even the camera is better and the FE has 5G with the 865 processor where my phone is max 4G LTE. The S10 is still more expensive than the S20 FE and it's screen refresh is at 60hz only. So, if you want an almost flagship type phone, and only have the bucks for the typical $500-$700 model today in that price range, this one is it!

I rate phones based on their sound quality, camera, and battery life. 
  
  Battery Life:
  It can last roughly 4-6 hours on 100%. It takes 30-45 minutes for a full charge. 
  
  Camera Quality: 
  Nice overall but somewhat expected more but worth it. 
  
  Sound Quality:
  If you play music all day, this phone works very well. I play music throughout the night in my sleep and the sound is just perfect quality. 
  
  Phone call quality: 
  People are not able to hear the background noise such as traffic or slightly loud noises. According to who I've called the sound quality is high there's no distortions. If there is its probably bad connection on either side of the call.

Unboxing: nothing special here the box contains the phone, a charger, sim removal tool, charging cable, wired headphones. 
  
  Set up:
  Coming from a Flagship Android device I thought it would be a very tough task to transfer data from my Android to this Iphone SE second edition. I was wrong! 
  once I started the iphone it asked me if I want to get my data from another device and gave me the option of transfer from Android. 
  asked me to download an app called MOVE TO IOS. I downloaded the app and then followed the instructions and the transfer started wirelessly and took about an hour or so. 
  
  I restarted the phone, created an Apple ID, added my fingerprint, and went about to install my apps and import my Google accounts, and downloaded the latest IOS updates. 
  Restarted the phone again and started using the phone. 
  
  Experience:
  The phone is very snappy and fast, although you will notice some tracing while scrolling menus due to the lower refresh rate but the phone performs very very well and I can say that with this price point, nothing can beat this hardware and software Experience:
  The IPhone SE 2 has the latest A13 Bionec Chip, an OK screen size and quality, and a very nice camera compared to other phones in this price range. 
  
  Build Quality and design:
  The build quality is solid. it took me less than 3 hours to drop the phone from the table on hardwood floor flat on its screen. I thought the screen was shattered. I was wrong again. 
  the design is very similar to the IPhone 8 with its rounded edges and the silver frame with a glass front and back. 
  although when tapping on the screen with my finger nails, it feels more plastic than glass compared to my other phones. 
  the power button is located on the right side, and the volume rockers are located on the left side. 
  this phone does not have stereo jack and instead uses a lightning port (Thanks Apple! ), and dual stereo speakers at the button of the phone. 
  this phone still has a physical button on the left side above the volume rockers to switch to silent mode if you want to. and the sim card slot is located on the right side under the power button. 
  the finger print touch is located in the center of the screen at the buttom. 
  the phone has a double chin that measures about a half inch at the top and buttom. and the screen size is 4.7 inches (usable but would love bigger one for sure). 
  The phone is perfectly balanced and feels good in your hand even if you have a smaller hand. it doesn't feel lightweight and cheap but it doesnt feel and look like a flagship either. 
  the frame of the phone is made of metal. 
  the camera has a slight bump, and has a single camera on the back with a sensor and a flash. the camera app has Portrait, panoramic, slowmo, time- lapse, video, photo out of the box. 
  you can change the quality and size of the photos and videos and you can record videos of up to 4K with 60 frames per seconds which will cost you a hefty 400MG per minute of recording. 
  after setting up and importing the necessities from my other phone I was left with less than 20 GB of the 64GB this phone comes with. not much considering i am just done with setup and havent actually used the phone yet. but you can always upgrade to the 128 GB version of this phone. 
  Battery life:
  after using the phone with everything on out of the box I was able to get about 9 hours of continuous use and wast still left with 37% battery life. not bad considering that the phone has wireless charging capability and comes with a fast charging cable (but not a fast charger!). 
  Sound quality:
  the sound quality of this phone is OK, not great but its just good. the same goes for the included wired headphones. you can use them for sure, but we all know you are going to upgrade to those nice wireless pro's. 
  
  final thoughts:
  The IPhone SE 2 is a great cheap smart phone in the $400 range for any IOS or Android user. 
  the A13 Bionec chip is the latest and fastest IOS chip to date, its the same chip used in the flagship Iphone today. 
  the smaller screen with the less refresh rate and the older looking design are not deal breakers considering you are getting the same flawless experience from Apple. 
  I switched from Android to Apple for a few reasons:
  1- there are apps I need for work that are not available for Android (these are custom made Apps that I need in my day to day work)
  2- Security features: although Android has great customization capabilities, but security is still and issue. Apple is superior when it comes to protecting your privacy and security. 
  3- Some gimmick features that I see everyone around me love and use like Facetime, and impressions in Imessage. 
  
  finally, I would totally recommend this phone for anyone who wants to buy an affordable phone with great features and support that will last at least 3 years from Apple. this phone is also a great entry to IOS for anyone coming from Android family. 
  
  Last point: if you are an Android user and want to make the switch but afraid that your most valuable apps wont work, rest assured that everything from Google is available on the apple store even Google Authenticator. if you are missing some of Apple features with Android, you can make this leap of faith and will be happy with this purchase.

I'm really enjoying this upgrade from an S9 to the S21.

It turns out these phones are not actually unlocked, they are universal but will end up locking to the first activated carrier! That means it will be difficult to switch providers later, which defeats the point of having an unlocked phone. Thankfully they let me return it, I plan on going to the apple store directly now to get a true unlocked device.

My heart hurt as I saw the writing on the wall for my first generation iPhone SE. When Apple announced the second generation SE, I was trilled. This phone has really got it all. (I'm sure that iPhone X or 11 or what have you devotee will be quick to take issue with my characterization. But I still maintain that for most people, this phone is every bit as good as another iPhone out there.) Really, for most people, all you're really "giving up" is keeping Touch ID instead of Face ID (which doesn't work anyways in the age of face masks).
This phone is fantastic. I got it for my wife and she loves it. Screen is sharp and very responsive.

Only had phone for 2 days, but I noticed the battery was draining super fast, especially on standby. I both restarted and reset the phone but the issue persisted. Maybe I had a lemon, but for me it was enough to return the phone. I was also a little frustrated the phone was stuck on the May security patch ... for a new phone in August, and for Samsung, that's unacceptable. I suppose they only support their Galaxy S and Note phones each month. Shame. 
  Also, I live in a major metro area, where 5G is live, and on T-Mobile my LTE speeds were faster than the the 5G capabilities on this phone...just goes to show you don't need to get a 5G phone just yet depending on where you are. If that's on your mind, think twice and consider where you live and what technology you have.

This is my 2nd smart phone. The last 2 years I've used a Moto G5 Plus which I loved! After reading multiple reviews, I decided to try this Apple iPhone SE. I planned to keep it for awhile so went with the 128 GB of storage. The smaller size was important to me. I don't use my phone for music or videos and text 1 to 5 times a day. 
  I figured the smaller battery size would be adequate. WRONG! The first 2 weeks I already noticed how quickly it drained, so I adjusted settings and apps to decrease battery drain. But yesterday I realized just how bad it was. I used navigation for 60 minutes and took 40 pictures and my battery went from 97% to 38 % in 3 hours. I stopped taking pictures, using navigation and deleted Facebook as that appeared to use a large percentage of my battery. Over the next 2 hours my battery drained to 10%. I finally shut my phone off so that I'd have some juice left in case of an emergency on my way home.

So once again, have gone through several steps with them turning controls off then back on. Then turning the phone off and back on, then going through to make sure the operating system is uptodate. Best Buy still seems to be selling the older box model of this unit (which is what I got store pickup), so you might get lucky and find yourself the proud owner of a pair of Earpods and power brick. Otherwise, iPhone SE boxes have gone the way of the 11 and 12 boxes - no Earpods, no power brick, just a single lightning cable.

I took advantage of some BB reward points, and purchased an open box SE2. It was in like new condition, and quickly was operational due to the smooth transfer process Apple has by putting your prior phone next to the new one to activate. 
  
  For basic needs (phone calls, texts, etc) the upgrade really does not seem any different than the 7. While there are noticeable improvements in opening up apps and web pages seem faster, since it uses the A13 processor, I doubt I would have upgraded the phone without the reward points, as I don't play games or use any apps that are heavily graphics oriented on the phone. 
  
  It also takes the iPhone 7 or 8 cases, so that was easy enough to put on the new phone. I thought of purchasing the iPhone 11, but the model 12 is rumored to have 5G support, so I hold off on getting a larger iPhone until 5G is actually a useable reality for Verizon in our area. 
  
  I don't use the phone for serious pics (have a full frame Canon mirrorless for that use). It takes decent snaps though. I am attaching a couple of shots to this review. I also added a comparison shot of the SE2 next to the iPod Touch 1G, which is typical Apple, still running strong.

My favorite phone of 2021 so far, the directors mode on the camera is awesome! This phone comes in a few colors, a little bummed about the no SD support but if you use the cloud properly 128GB should be more then enough.

For $399, this phone is unbeatably priced. I dropped my Pixel 2, which I loved, into a tank of whiskey and it eventually gave up on this life. I wanted something small and reasonably priced and the SE is perfect. The brand new operating system is the same as in the 11 Pro and Pro Max so it’s very fast, snappy, and the screen is beautiful. 
  
  The setup was easy. I’ve never setup ban unlocked phone before and I was finished in less than 10min. Just swap the SIM card with the included tool (or spend 30min searching your house for something small enough to use) and you’re good to go. All of my contacts downloaded straight from the google cloud so going from android to apple was not difficult. 
  
  My two main complaints about this phone are the camera quality and the screen size. I know it sounds weird to complain about screen size when I wanted a small phone, but the SE kept the overlarge black bezels on the top and bottom of the screen, which takes up space that could’ve easily been covered by more screen. I'm going to split the review in a couple of categories. 
  
  Aesthetics:
  
  The case is not completely clear. It has a smokey tint, but it does compliment my violet phone. I'm not actually convinced it might look well with white, for example. 
  
  I think that may have been done to avoid the "yellowing" effect that most clear cases suffer from. When you look at it from a certain angle and from a certain light, it does show some light reflection that looks kinda like a rainbow. I don't know of what the exact term for it is. 
  
  It might be my hand grease. But there you go. 
  
  
  Grip:
  
  The phone's back is ridiculously slippery. I do think that the rubber grip around the casing does compensate for it, however. I'm not sure if it's Samsung or just shortcoming of the type of plastic used. 
  
  Protection:
  
  I've dropped my phone face first the other day and my phone is still intact. I've also dropped it a couple of times and landed around the corner and the rubber "railing" around the case seems to be absorbing the impact very well. And of course it is raised a couple of mm so the screen isn't flush with the floor. That said, I don't think this is quite a mouse or otterbox case, but for what it is, it provides decent protection from everyday drops. I wouldn't be conducting any experiments like dropping it from a crane, or tossing it up like a volleyball serve. Specially since I paid for my phone out of pocket. 
  
  I think for it's price, $40 it could be better. I wouldn't pay anything above 25-30. Like I said, it isn't completely clear which kinda defeats the purpose of a clear case.

There is much to like about this phone: obviously the price, crisp speed and rich display. But in an apparent effort to simplify things, my user flexibility is reduced. Starting with and specifically, eliminating the 3.5mm jack for wired earbuds. One advantage of those earbuds is that I don't have to recharge them. Second, I can keep the phone on charge while talking. (Yeah, yeah, somebody said that's dangerous, but I've seen no evidence of that.) Next, while the DASH charger does deliver impressive speed, that means I have to carry the relatively large AC plug and, worst, its prongs don't fold down. Something most helpful when traveling. Equally bad is that the charging cord only works with USB C plugs on both ends, which means I can't easily jack into the standard USB connection in a car, airplane or bus so how are we to charge when traveling? Also, the charging system doesn't work with any magnetic connectors I can find, something that goes a long way to avoiding wear and tear on the female USB port in the phone. Finally, I find it very difficult to open the SIM card slot. Maybe it's unique to my phone, but frustrating nonetheless. So as I said, some impressive aspects, but I won't buy another (this 8T is a replacement for my 3T, whose battery is shot) until OnePlus starts to think and design for the breadth of users, not just the "gee, that's great and new" technologies.

I use most new phones when they come out as I like to switch phones often and can because I buy them outright. That being said this is a great phone for the price of 800$ and even more so if you do a trade-in with the current BestBuy offer. I paid 200$ for this phone after trading in my iPhone 11 for $650 which was a great deal overall. 
  
  Spec-wise the s21 is using slow DDR memory than the s20 was, Also the back of the phone is no longer glass on this model. The Snapdragon 888 is faster than last year's offering and now the 5G chip is no longer separate it is combined so you will get better battery life. If you need expandable storage also this is not the phone to go with because you can not use a micro-sd like you could with the s20's
  
  This phone is a great upgrade if you are going from an s10 or older but if you have an s20 I would wait till next year to get a decent upgrade. 
  
  I think with covid going on and poor sales for the s20 series Samsung decided to cheapen the phones a bit down so people would be more likely to buy them. 
  
  At this price you are still getting:
  120hz
  1440p res
  8gb of ram
  6.2 screen. 
  
  I over all would recommend buying this phone right now if you have something to trade in the current offers are great.

I owned Samsung phones from ~2013-2019, and transitioned to a Pixel in 2019. The transition took a little getting used to, but the UI was very intuitive and took about a week to adjust. When my Pixel broke, I wanted to get a Rokform case, which is only available for Samsung or Apple phones, so I decided to try the Galaxy S21. The case is great. The phone is not. 
  
  Transitioning back to the Samsung is not intuitive. It took multiple weeks to readjust to the Samsung UI, and after a couple months, I still occasionally use the wrong buttons or motions to try to do something. Screenshots work differently and seem more likely to accidentally change the volume. There is also no obvious way to turn the phone completely off when trying to save battery if spending the night outdoors away from a charger. 
  
  Related to the previous power statement, my 2 year old Pixel 3 had a longer battery life than my brand new Galaxy S21. It was even better when it was new. 
  
  Samsung filled my phone with a bunch of bloatware. Some were pretty obvious, like Samsung Health or their email apps. Others were less obvious, like their messaging app which uses an almost identical icon to Google's. I didn't realize that they had pulled a swap on me until all of my messages starting coming in broken last night. I called Google support and they suggested I update several apps, including Messages. Messages wasn't installed. Samsung had blocked it from transferring over when I copied all of my previous apps from the Pixel. I installed Google Messages, and everything was immediately fixed. 
  
  The fingerprint scanner only works about 1/4 of the time. I always have to scan multiple times, and get locked out and have to use my pin at least once per day. On the pixel, I might have had to rescan once a day, but I was never locked out. The Pixel would generally get it on the first scan, and occasionally the second or third. The Pixel's scanner is also much more conveniently placed on the back of the phone. One can scan a fingerprint and unlock the phone while pulling it out of the pocket instead of having to wait until you can see the phone and guess where the scanner is located on a blank screen. 
  
  This one is a bit more of a preference issue, but my thumb won't reach the entire keyboard. I can only type with both hands. The Pixel's screen was just slightly smaller, so I could still type with one hand if the other was full. 
  
  Lastly, although the Galaxy S21 says that it was designed to run on Google Fi, it doesn't seem to do this as well as the Pixel. Reception when out of wifi range was much more reliable with the Pixel. I have had several instances when out in a park or camping when I get zero signal with the Galaxy. This never happened with the Pixel. While I don't want to be glued to my phone when trying to enjoy the outdoors, I still want the option in cases of emergency...

I bought this thinking iPhones would be good. I was wrong. This is about the least user-friendly phone I have ever had the misfortune of owning. Ways in which it is inferior to my prior Samsung include:
  - Can't drag photos from computer files in the phone---you have to use iTunes (nice vertical monopoly there, guys). 
  - Can't remove unwanted shortcuts from your home screen (I had to create folder on my home screen labeled "Trash" and shove them in there). 
  - Can't add contacts to your home screen (there's a workaround, but it requires the contacts to use symbols rather than pictures and it still takes multiple clicks to call). 
  - Can't change the color of basically anything (calendar+dark mode=slasher movie). 
  - Can't schedule quiet hours for only certain nights of the week, presumably because, as the alarm app patronizingly says, "consistent sleep is the best sleep" (I'm sorry, but you elites at Apple do realize that not every job allows you to sleep the same hours every night, right?). 
  
  This last point brings me to my other issue: How horribly patronizing this device is. Apparently, Apple views themselves as some sort of aristocratic elites who will heroically save the rabble from themselves by micromanaging their lives for them. Aside from the demeaning (and tone-deaf) advice about "consistent sleep" (yeah, that would be a nice luxury to have), you also have the Health app as one of the unremovable home screen icons (because apparently the "rabble" needs a tech company of all things to manage their health for them). If this was just an option, it might be helpful, but having it as one of the mandatory home screen icons just reeks of a patronizing and controlling attitude. 
  
  In short, Apple's message is: Don't worry your little head thinking for yourself, let us do your thinking for you, and remember, always buy Apple. 
  
  I've had this phone less than 24 hours, and I'm already seriously thinking of trading it in for another Samsung (despite not having the time to do so). At least my Samsung actually put me in the driver's seat instead of trying to control everything itself.

Overall I think this phone is a great value for the price. It has a great camera, and enough RAM and storage space for most uses. I tend to have a lot of apps open at once, and so far I have yet to notice a slow down. I have definitely enjoyed this phone with a couple exceptions. The phone seems to be a little glitchy. One of the main problems I have had is when doing a google search, the search sometimes doesn't show any results unless I hit search again several times. Another small issue is when touching the onscreen fingerprint reader, the accidental touch protection kicks in and I have to swipe it away and try the fingerprint reader again. The only other thing is getting used to Samsung wanting you to use their apps (phone, text messaging, etc.) as well as their backup cloud. These can be easily changed, so not a serious issue, and I knew this when buying this phone. This phone is not water resistant, so if you're looking for that, look at the Galaxy "S" series phones. If you're looking for a great phone with a lot of high end features, without the high end price, this is a great option.

The recent I phone SE that I have purchased are JUNK. I bought an IPhone 8+ less than two years ago. It completely died- unrepairable in less than 2 years. 
  I bought the SE model July 30th- IMMEDIATELY upon plugging it in to start to download my info from the cloud, it started heating up. 
  There was no case. It was in shaded room (not that ANY of that should make a difference. Are you saying you can’t use your phone except in extremely favorable conditions ). 
  That issue continued- and by 30 days in, it was becoming so hot that it was locking the phone......just normal use AND the battery was draining unbelievably quickly. 
  I took it to Best Buy- they replaced it. 
  30 days later, exact same problems with the new one. The battery was dropping so quickly that it went from 100% to 80 % in 20 minutes—NOT DOING ANYTHING. Later, that day, it went from 45% to 0% in one hour just while listening to music. 
  
  That’s when I took it to the Apple store. 
  
  Now, I wanted to trade it in for a different model. I can’t do that- is what the rep said. 
  He went through the diagnostic stuff- told me it wasn’t the phone- it was how I was using it. 
  
  I was like, I’ve had TONS of Apple products- never had these issues. While we were in store he watched as my battery continue to drain. He turned off automatic updates- and then we continued to watch the battery drop. 10% drop in less than an hour. 
  They told me they’d have to reset my phone- erase and download again. 
  We did that. 
  As soon as he turned it back on without downloading any of my stuff—the battery dropped more. 
  
  At that point, he agreed to provide a new phone- now, he didn’t add all my apps- he just added my SIM card- so none of my apps/email, etc was loaded to the phone—I put the brand new phone on the charger in my car—30 minutes later- not using it AT ALL- just charging it, it was hot to the touch. 
  
  Oh and the associate told me that I couldn’t add Apple care to the phone now because this is my third (IN TWO MONTHS) replacement—and if it continues to fail, they will only replace it with the same crap product. 
  DO NOT GET THE SE PHONE.

Best buy return policy does NOT allow nearly enough time to learn how to use the phone and I have spent hours making the attempt. A BB geek even told me the battery will get better with time. I have a Galaxy S10 Lite. A so-called watered down version of the S10+. It is almost 1.5 years old. Like the Oneplus 9, it has a 4500mah battery that will last all day, and quite strong even during the watching of several videos. My phone, at just 50% brightness is brighter than the Oneplus 9 at about 60% brightness. Where the Oneplus 9 is brighter than my S10 is at 100%. But go ahead and put your phone at 100% brightness and tell me shortly thereafter how much battery you have left after, say, 5 hours of real world use, not just sitting on a table. On top of that, the 60 hertz refresh my phone has is actually faster than the Oneplus 9 at 120 hertz. As usual, paid video guys and girls are entirely wrong in their presentation of this unit. The one speaker at the bottom of my phone is almost as loud as the dual speaker system the Oneplus 9 has. It sounds nice, but nothing that gives off a wow factor. There is no way this phone should cost what it cost. Wireless charging is nice, I guess if that's your thing. And honestly, how many people reverse charge. It is still way in the infancy stage of technology. I am going to safely assume that Oneplus has come a long way, yes. But it will never frankly catch up to the top dogs in the business.

I wasn't expecting to like the Note20 5G as much as I do. I also love that the front camera is just a small circle for the lens on the screen unlike the iPhone which has a large and ugly notch that takes away from the display area. This phone is fast, and the battery lasts me for 2 whole days with medium usage and 8 hours of screen on-time. I also have a lot of notifications come in on my phone but it doesn't kill the battery like my old S7 Edge did. You simply can't go wrong with this phone. The only flaw is that the back is plastic but I personally use a case with all my phones so this is not a dealbreaker for me.

You have to try it for yourself. Forget about anyone's opinion, including mine. Why? Like anything in life, I have come to believe that reviews are SUPER subjective. You have to take into account that a review may be coming from a very young person that can be easily impressed and will give anything new 5 stars. It can be a snob that has to have everything perfect. It can be a person that received it as a gift and could care less about what anyone reads. Listen, it has a plastic back - SO! If it were glass, and dropped and cracked, the very person complaining about it having a plastic back will be most likely crying when they find out what it will take to repair a glass back. Is it slow? NO. You'll get someone to say it is. Is it snappy? YES. You will get someone to say it isn't. Do you need 120 hertz refresh? Give me a break. Moving fast in today's world is one of the reasons why so much in the world is screwed up to begin with. The speed at which you navigate any given website is MORE THAN ACCEPTABLE. Battery? You are going to get yet another person that says it won't last a day. SO! That very person probably lives on the phone and has forgotten there is a world around them. Standby time is excellent. Battery is super acceptable. The only adjustment I have made to the phone is lessening the brightness to 50% and it is still very bright. Calls are clear. Everything connects fast to it via bluetooth and stays connected. At the end of the day. If you need a good phone with a proven track record, and in this phone's case a stylus to make writing, typing, and keeping the screen as smudge free as possible, this is a great phone.

I had been an Apple user prior to owning this phone, but wanted to try something different this year. When doing my research on Android, I came across this hidden gem and I'm glad I did. The hardware is on par with other flagship phones of 2020. The fingerprint sensor on the power button is a nice touch, the shutter button makes taking pics a great experience, and while I don't personally use the Google assistant button that much, it's nice to have and doesn't get triggered accidentally very often 
  The display and 120 hz refresh rate are excellent. The audio (Dolby included) is top in class, plus a headphone jack. The battery life is phenomenal, and will easily last you all day. The only con I have is the selfie cam, it's just ok. I don't know why their main back cameras are so good, and yet the selfie camera is just passable. I don't take enough selfies for it to be a deal breaker, however. All in all, the Sony Xperia is a jack of all trades and mastered most of them quite well.

The cameras, the S-pen, the AMOLED screen quality, the 120 Hz refresh rate, the 5G data connection, the build quality, etc. are all top notch. This phone will probably hold the crown for best Android phone for a good while, and it has key feature bumps that made me especially want this phone--namely the 5G and the 120 Hz screen. 
  
  I would definitely recommend a solid case if you're planning to spend this much money on a phone. I bought a Spigen case which effectively reduces the camera bump on the back to allow the phone to sit flat on a desk. The IP68 rating means that it will be fine with water and dust, but drop protection is still a must. I saw a stat recently that something like 2/3 of people report incurring drop damage to their phone (for all phones not specifically this phone). 
  
  Other thoughts: I think it's interesting that most middle class people can afford the best phone that you can possibly purchase for a product that is in your pocket, everyday, all the time. You can't say that about cars, houses, clothes, but you could definitely swing buying the best phone that money can buy once every 3-4 years if it's important enough to you. For me it is, and I'm very happy with this phone. 
  
  Lastly: Google Pixel, 1+, Apple, etc. can only hope to match some of the features that this phone has to offer, but I highly doubt that they will exceed this phone's specs on yet to be release products. Just my opinion as a phone guy, but the best that they could hope to do is give you a better value on specific features. If you're somebody looking for the best value on a calling and texting machine, then this phone is not for you. This phone is for somebody that wants the best cameras, pocket computing power, & screen quality that money can buy you right now.

Two huge disappointments. First, they've taken away the option to set a global wallpaper in text messages. You can set a background for individual conversations. But I always enjoyed setting a main background for my text messages main screen and was really disappointed to learn that you can't with the N20. Second, the S-Pen is the whole reason I'm a Note user. It's my main buying reason. They moved the S-Pen slot from the right side to the left side of the bottom of the phone. Assuming most people are right handed, it is definitely more cumbersome to retract and replace the pen. I can't figure out the right place to put my left hand when replacing the pen - my finger hits the on/off button and closes the screen, or the phone rotates from portrait to landscape - very disappointing. Otherwise, the phone is fine and I do like it, but these are two key things for me and leave me really disappointed.

I'm angry and disappointed!!! 
  I purchased this as an open box in excellent condition online. I drove two hours for a round trip to pick it up from the store that had it in stock. Once I got home and opened the box, I noticed that the charger and headphone were missing. BestBuy defines an excellent condition to include everything original with no accessory missing. So obviously a waste of time and energy!!! Besides that, while I returned it to the store, the General Manager with a grumpy face gave me the feeling like I had stolen the charger and headphone. Unfortunately, in a situation like this, there is no way to prove yourself right, as it was already an open box and they can think you are lying because you can't claim such a thing for a brand new item.

I only buy unlocked phones to avoid the clutter and useless apps that carriers add. To my surprise Samsung done much worse than any carrier in adding so much bloatware to this phone. There was so much useless apps on here that the phone was sluggish and had a horrible experience. The phone is outdated in its software version and the screen had weird tint issues. But the thing that made me sell this phone was all the random ads Samsung would push as notifications from various apps. Even after disabling notifications from ALL Samsung apps they pushed another ad to my phone via the system UI and it was time to go. 
  
  If you want a clean fast phone with no bloat there is really only 2 options. Android = Google Pixel OR iOS = iPhone.

Feels like an improved version of the S10+ but it is a little more than that. 
  
  I upgraded from the S10+ and felt SOME difference - for the better of course. 
  
  Camera is better, in-display fingerprint is better, the screen itself feels and looks better, the whole arrangement feels better. 
  
  Ok, the front facing camera could be hidden by now, but I understand they have a schedule to do that - baby steps to milk our money every year... 
  
  The biggest difference for me was 5G. OMG! How have we lived without for sooo long?! (yeah yeah, Note10 had a 5G version but who cares? That thing was a tablet!) 
  I don't have tiny hands but the Note is WAAAAY too much to handle.... 
  
  In general, this is a better incremental improvement over last gen and now we have 5G - which is an absolute MUST HAVE in 2020.

This is not a review of the product, rather the buying experience at Best buy online. 
  
  I was told by the customer representative to apply for best buy credit card to get 10% in rewards. I applied and I got an instant approval. The funny thing is the credit limit was capped at $1000 for a phone price of ~1200. So, I could not use the card and I was made to apply for the credit card. 
  
  I don't think any bank would cap the limit at 1000 even for someone with lower credit rating. I have excellent credit rating 800+ and I believe the credit limit was purposefully capped to limit the rewards. So the lesson is don't apply for the best buy credit card unless the product you buy is < $1000.

I have been wanting a new phone for a while now, as I was running a LG V30 for sometime. Prior to that I had the old Nexus 5, which was a great phone for the day and I loved it then. I originally ordered a Pixel 4XL to replace the LG in hopes it would check the warm & fuzzy boxes like the old Nexus did for me. It didn't (no Ultra-Wide camera was a HUGE mistake!). So I returned it, and researched for a few months. Finally pulled the trigger on the regular S20 (unlocked). Sooooo glad I did. The feel in hand is terrific. It feels smaller in the hand than my LG V30, but you actually have more screen real estate. Just a terrific fit/finish and form factor here. I actually wanted a smaller, one-handed phone for convenience as I take a LOT of photos in my profession (home inspection). It is very fast, and the camera has been great so far. I have pretty much turned off all the Samsung bloatware I could and have it as close to Pure Android as I can, and it is terrific. I can see this being the daily driver for a few years and I recommend giving it a go!

Although I have recently gotten into the samsung game, this new phone is truly not what everyone is raving about. After looking through and finding out its functions I still feel like the s10 and samsung A70 still have a better camera. The photos although they come out crisp when zooming in the photos are still very pixalated and the auto focus doesn't really work well. Some of the plus that I have seen from this phone is just the surround sound, it really makes a difference when listening to music, watching videos, or playing games. I say the price is not really acurate with what you get.

After a week of use, I am enjoying the optical zoom, 5G coverage is decent in my area and the phone is much faster than my S8+. So I am happy with my purchase. 
  
  The drawbacks - the phone is a bit overpriced, and Samsung has started putting advertising in their apps which drives me nutzo. Use the music app? Every 7 days it tries to sell you Spotify, no matter that the app already includes Spotify and I have Spotify installed on the phone. Eew. That might be a reason for some to switch to Apple at a comparable price point.

Fine, I ordered the phone online & drove back to the store, they're closed. Seriously? Cancelled the order & made an appointment at Best Buy, where they actually let me in the store! The team was awesome, & I ended up getting the phone for less then Verizon was selling it. I also got free Samsung wireless earbuds. In the future, I would never buy a phone from anyone but Best Buy! With all the upgrades to the Android operating system you really won't miss the iPhone's interface. Wow. Just wow. One of my biggest frustrations with the iPhone is the absolute terrible cameras. The 8 was so much better than the X. The X is terrible. Now, here comes Samsung with the S20. Maybe I got a defective phone, but I didn't want to take any more chances and got the iPhone 11 Pro, which didn't disappoint. 
  This Samsung model also feels very fragile. I had Samsung 7, 8 and 9 and they took fantastic pictures right of the box, were way cheaper and felt steadier. Not sure why this model is so unconvincing and so overpriced...I was a Samsung fan for several years.

Long time iphone user here. My first smart phone was an iphone. I then had a galaxy for a short while, it didn't last long because this was when android was a little unstable. I went back to iphone and I've been getting iphones for 9 years now. Never had any complaints, they did just want I needed and I have other apple products, so the ecosystem worked great. However, in recent years, I started questioning some of Apple's business choices and I feel like iphones weren't changing enough. But I felt like I needed to make a change. I did my research and I knew Samsung had better specs, options, and they were running on android, an OS that would allow me to be in more control. I wanted to make the switch. But I was struggling to leave Apple's ecosystem. Around the time iphone 12 was revealed, I saw the S20 in the store and was amazed by the high quality screen, it's speed and responsiveness. I had to learn more. So I watched some videos on YouTube and did a ton of research, including what I'd be missing from not having an iphone and what I'd be gaining from an android. I found more reasons to switch. And here we are and so far I have no regrets.

Pros: I have enjoyed using this phone thoroughly since I purchased it. I love the screen size and clarity of the picture quality! It also has an all day battery that keeps up with me! Camera is also great, and installing an additional memory card was a cinch. I also enjoy 5G coverage in my area. For an average user, this is a great phone! 
  
  Cons: Not too sure about all the other benefits of ownership of this phone. However, there are some drawbacks. I miss the aux headphone port. Although it did come with some headphones that use the power-port to also transmit audio. Guess there's no avoiding this now! Also, when running on max settings, the phone tends to have about 50-70% of the normal battery life that I enjoy while running on lower settings. The phone was also a little pricey, and I'm having to reassess if the phone really is worth the premium price considering other options and the use of an "average" user. 
  
  Overall: Good phone, great quality build, very responsive. If you have the cash, go for it!

This is a lot of phone. The display is outstanding. The phone is fast and I get 5G around town most of the time. It is the slower implementation of 5G so not a big jump but this phone supports the faster 5G protocol when it finally gets installed. If you are a phone freak there are endless settings to tweak. My only complaint would be the same across the various brands of phones: the bloatware. There is a lot on this phone. It will give you so many notifications using the default setting you have to go in and weed out the silly stuff. The hardware is superb. My battery life is great although I am not a power user. The software is not bad, there is just too much of it. You're gonna love this phone.
