Upgraded from a galaxy s9. Don't get me wrong. This isn't a bad phone. But it does miss the mark in a few areas where I feel it counts. I'll start with the pros first. 
  
  - The camera: coming from the s9 I do see some improvements notably in the software. Features which appear to be exclusive solely to the s21 ultra do to it having 4 cameras. Also has laser focus. 
  
  - The display: As always, Samsungs displays never cease to impress me. Though if you want the WQHD, you'll need to shell out the extra cash for the s21 ultra. The s21 and the s21+ feature only 1080p displays. 
  
  - Overall build - the physical built overall is quite nice. The back is plastic but not cheap plastic. Not a finger print magnet like it's predecessors. Metal frame and a nearly bezzless display combined to make a quite nice, even sophisticated package, though not a wide range of colors at launch. But for me, as long as I have my black, I don't care. So I subtract no points. 
  
  - Processor: Each new phone typically boasts the usual "more powerful processor" claim. I haven't put it through benchmark tests but from real world use, the OS is quite snappy and moving from app to app and menu to menu has no lag at all. Overall a pleasant experience. 
  
  - Battery life: The s21 features a much larger battery the the s21 and s21+. Two days in so far and it seems to hold up to daily activities rather well (texting, some light gaming, facebook, etc...) 
  
  - S Pen: if you just so happen to have an S Pen from an old Note or Galaxy Tab, it will absoluty and finally work on the Galaxy S line of phones. Though there is no storage on the phone itself for the pen, but you can purchase a case that has an integrated S Pen holder. 
  
  Okay. Now for the CONS.... 
  
  - Camera: Now I know what you must be thinking. "But you said the camera was a PRO". Yes I did. However, even with the various software and hardware improvements, the image quality does not seem to be so strikingly amazing compared to my s9. Even when shooting in 108mp mode, the results seem only marginally better. Adding to this, I don't believe the sensor is truly 108mp, rather each mp is divided into 9 parts allowing the sensor to capture more detail and thusly produce an (in my experience) somewhat sharper image. Furthermore, I do not understand what the point is to put so many cameras into a phone. Sure you have your telephoto, for example, which should enable you to maybe get a nice shot of the moon. However, if lunarphotography or any other kind of long range shooting interests you, even an entry level DSLR will yield far superior results. My opinion: leave smart phone to the selfies and MAYBE wide angle. Leave everything else to actual cameras. It will make room for other things like my next point. 
  
  - 3.5mm Headphone/Mic input: The modern smartphones have become an especially handy and even accessible solution for vlogging. With the ability to shoot 4k and the s21 ultras 8k, you can yield some very acceptable results and very easily. But good video does not make up for garbage audio. And unless you are using a mic, garbage is what you will get. I don't care what smartphone you are using. The other reason the removal of the 3.5mm jack is problematic will become painfully clear if you're somebody who flies a lot. Once you put you're phone in airplane or flight mode, those Galaxy Buds Pros you just bought will be of no use to you. Now I'm sure there is a USB-C to 3.5mm adapter available, but my point stands and for this the entire s21 lineup loses 1 star. 
  
  - Expandable storage: Samsung have we not been down this road before? I know you guys know how much people value the option for expandable storage. Say goodbye to another star. 
  
  - No headphones or charge brick in the box: In an age where every single thing comes with a charge brick, I think this was probably a good move. We all have 500 of those kicking around at this point. But the lack of headphones is unacceptable. A decent pair of USB-C headphones absolutely should have been in the box. At the very least, a USB-C to 3.5mm adapter given that they removed the jack. 
  
  - Fingerprint sensor: Theres not much I can say other than that it has so far been nothing short of a frustrating experience. It was MUCH better on the s9 and when it was on the back of the phone as compared to under the display on the front. Maybe the next iteration will return to this design in lieu of featuring 75 different cameras. 
  
  I hope some of you find this review to be insightfull given that you will potentially be spending upwards of $1,000.00 or more on this phone. Again, I don't totally hate the phone but it feels as though there has been a bit of a departure from past years in terms of Samsung listening to the desires of the consumer. I think this will be something that will hurt them in the bigger picture.

This is my first time buying a high end smartphones. I usually go for cheap $100+ phone from Cricket but decided to get S20+5G in December for my wife and S21 Ultra 128gb 2 weeks ago for myself. I am not a fan of iPhone. I am impressed with the appearance and display in S21 Ultra but very disappointed that the phone did not come with a charger and did not realize that until I got home with the phone only to find a cable but no adapter/charger. Lack of expandable memory slot and headjack or wired earpiece was another disappointment. Flagship phone like ultra I guess should come with some basic things like charger, expandable memory slot and earpiece. Giving S21 Ultra four star rating because of no charger, expandable memory slot and earpiece.

Phone is extremely overpriced, it should be worth around $700 at most. There are also literal ads within some apps - imagine paying for a phone (especially over $1000), thinking you own it, and still having ads playing inside the phone - this is alone enough for me not to want to use this phone. 
  
  Some things people don't talk about:
  1. Cameras are good but the UI in the camera software is not that great (except for Pro mode, which is pretty nice). 
  2. The software experience overall isn't very intuitive. There are some settings which are buried deep within the Settings app. It's also not very friendly with Google Photos (for example, every time you want to delete a photo using Google Photos, it will ask you via prompt if you're really sure you want to give Google Photos access). 
  3. Google Maps access - this is one of the most infuriating & potential harmful issues. Typically you'd imagine that any navigation apps (Google Maps, Waze, etc.) would need access to the phone's GPS all the time by default. This is not the case in this phone for some reason. When you open up Google Maps, it will ask you via a prompt if you want to give Maps access to the GPS either only this one time, only when the app is open, or not at all. The option to give Maps access to GPS all the time isn't available unless you dig deep into the settings & grant the Maps app permission separately - this is such a stupid design especially if you expect Maps or other navigation apps to just work normally as they should. Granting the app access to GPS only when the app is open doesn't work if the app isn't in the foreground - for example, if you get a call while you're driving and Maps gets minimized and the Phone app opens, then GPS & route navigation will be lost - imagine dealing with that while you're driving trying to navigate. 
  4. Ads - this is another infuriating issue. Why are there ads in a phone that I paid full price for, and on top of that one that is unlocked fully? There is no option to turn off ads in the settings and Samsung has very predatory setup process when you first setup your phone - it will automatically opt-in for sending them personal data and showing ads. There is a very jank way to disable ads and it's not supported natively within the Settings of the phone - in other words, you're paying over $1000 for a smartphone that will have ads. This is absurd and absolutely unnecessary. 
  
  If this phone was $700 I would still be annoyed with all those things but slightly less. If this phone was $400, I probably wouldn't complain that much about most of these issues. But at over $1000, this is ridiculous at best and people should find these practices unacceptable.

Screen looks great, camera takes as good to probably better pics than my old galaxy S6. I bought the Galaxy A51 after my Galaxy S5 Active all of the sudden died (after at least 5 years). I did not want to pay $1K for one of the flagship Samsung phones, so I bought the Galaxy A51 outright (AT&T). 
  
  I was back & forth between the Galaxy A51 and the Google Pixel 4a (same price $349). After looking at both, I went with the Samsung - the Pixel 4a doesn't allow for a MicroSD card, and per reviews doesn't have a dedicated "back" button. Also, there's an obvious size difference. 
  
  
  Pros:
  - Supports a MicroSD card (the Pixel 4a does not) and the phone comes with a SIM/MicroSD card slot tool, for replacement. Which was a nice touch, not having to dig for a paper clip or thumb tack. 
  - Battery life -- I've seen some reviews critical of the battery life, but to me the battery has been exceptional. I get at least 24 hours on my battery (screen brightness at 30% which is well enough for me & have the "dark theme/mode" enabled, I also am not utilizing Samsung apps: Bixby/Free/Edge). And I'm on Twitter/Email/Slack constantly. 
  - Camera -- Great main camera... great resolution on regular pics & excellent zoom, great panoramic pics, decent resolution on videos. The front facing (selfie) camera is also good - good resolution & has easy selfie picture function. 
  - It does have an earphone jack (as does the Pixel 4a), which is a must for me. More on that below. 
  
  
  Cons:
  - No "hard" buttons at the bottom for: apps/home/back, like my previous Galaxy S5 Active had. For me personally, the soft/touch screen buttons will take some getting used to, but for others it's probably not a big deal. Just my personal preference. (To note: I've read reviews where the Pixel 4a does not have a back button, you have to swipe)
  - The default wallpaper and icons (phone/text/camera/pics) are quite "cartoonish" or childish looking (pictures attached). The app icons looked nothing like my 5 year old Galaxy S5 icons & wallpaper. There are free themes/wallpapers/icons you can download, but out of the box it's a disappointment. But, for a budget phone I can live with it. 
  
  
  Other observations:
  - Obviously, it comes preloaded with all of the Google apps, some Microsoft Office apps, which I use. And of course some of the Samsung bloatware apps, but that hasn't been a problem for my usage or battery life. I had to set Chrome as the default browser, instead of Samsung's native browser. 
  - On phone calls, unless you hold the phone close to your ear/face in "just the right way"... the touchscreen will re-engage - which could have the potential for your cheek to hang up on the call. It hasn't happened to me yet, but I've noticed it's very particular about how you hold the phone while on a call. 
  - The earphone jack is located on the bottom (versus at the top for my previous Galaxy S5 & the Pixel 4a). First phone I've had that had it at the bottom... but after some usage, I'm getting used to it - if you have headphones wired in & put your phone in your pocket "top down" it makes sense. 
  - I've already dropped the phone onto concrete from about 2 feet high, luckily no damage. I have the $20 UAG case from Best Buy, which is more firm rubber than the $30 UAG case. The $20 UAG case makes it a bit harder to press the volume & 'action' buttons on the side, so consider the $30 UAG case which is softer & should allow for easier pressing of the side buttons. 
  
  All in all, this is an excellent phone for the money. I would definitely buy again, and recommend to anyone not wanting to drop $1K on a phone.

The battery life is longer than my prev phones. In an average 8 hour work day of minimal usage (checking Instagram and making phone calls) I only lose 10 to 15% battery life and fast charging is pretty fast. I get 70% to 100% in 20 minutes which ain't bad. 
  
  I love the camera shot details. You can achieve focused shots, wide shots, panoramic shots and micro shots (very detailed) and the from camera is very sharp. 
  
  Overall I love this phone and I would recommend this to my friends though they are all iPhone people.

This device is gold. I sprung for the 256G option because there is no MicroSD support but the cost increase isn't great. In summary, the device is perfect fit for the hand, looks great, performs like a beast and makes minimal compromise. 
  
  Unboxing / setup:
  There is minimal in the box, a USB-C to USB-C cable, documentation, a SIM tool and the phone. Setup takes some time if you are porting from another phone but the Samsung Smart Switch app makes it pretty easy where all you have to do is transfer all software, log in to Google and Samsung and it will do the rest, it just takes time to do so. 
  
  Use: 
  Battery life was lacking in the first few days but once it learned my habits after three or so days, I finish the day with 20% battery and 4-5 hours screen on time with 5G T-Mobile service in my area. I watch a lot of YouTube, read books, message, social media and game though out the day. 
  
  What I was most impressed with is how well this phone fits in the hand. It is near perfect for small/medium hands. Most of the screen is reachable and one-handed texting is easy. 
  
  The plastic back is a non-issue for me since it still feels premium and I use a case anyway. The Phantom Grey looks much better in person than in the product photos. 
  
  The lack of Micro SD is a good move even if it is hard to swallow in my opinion. The reason I say this is the performance increase. Most faster Micro SD cards only read at 90 MBps whereas the UFS 3.0 built in provides 1748 MBps read, 756 MBps write which is outstanding! The price increase for the 128 GB is only $50 extra which is only a tiny bit more than a 128GB microSD card. I do understand the pain if you need more than 256GB though. 
  
  Performance was a little choppy the first day or two as I assume the phone was indexing the filesystem and cleaning up after smart switch, but in the week since, zero issues. Performance on benchmarks is not on PAR with iPhones but you wouldn't notice in day to day use as apps open even faster. 
  
  Camera:
  There is a bit of shutter lag, but if you can live with that, photos area AMAZING! I must disclose that the 3x camera is not optical in nature. It is a cropped 64MP sensor. Side by side to an S21 Ultra with an optical 10MP 3X, the difference is almost unnoticeable. The phone allows digital zoom up to 30x but I wouldn't go higher than 10x as it is unusable after that. There is no macro ability but if yo use the 3x, it gives you pretty close photos. 
  
  Sound: 
  Speaker quality is great! I can easily hear it playing music or podcasts while showering and it gets loud and clear. The phone supports all the big codecs via bluetooth and I recommend Samsung buds of any type as it supports a Samsung Scalable Codec. 
  
  Display: 
  I was worried about the 1080p display being too low, but it is an extremely good screen! It is bright, vibrant and detailed as the screen size is low. 
  
  Connectivity: 
  Calls are clear especially on HD calls. I have a Wifi 6 network and connection stays strong anywhere in my house. Switching from an iPhone 12 Pro, I noticed cellular signal on 4G LTE and 5G is stronger anywhere I am in comparison. I have got up to 650mbps via 5G midband as there is no mmwave in my area.

The good:
  -This phone does have a very nice feel and good size to it (don't listen to people misrepresenting it as "plastic", the finish and material feel to me exactly like my last phone, the iPhone 11 Pro)
  -It is very fast with a great screen, 120 Hz is snappy, 5G seems a little faster than LTE but not that much honestly. 
  -Battery life seems good so far. 
  -Software works well, UI is just as intuitive as apple in my opinion. With more customization options. 
  
  The bad:
  -No charger in the box, this is honestly an insult to someone who just switched from iPhone and needed a charger. What on Earth were the clueless Samsung folks thinking with this decision I'll never know. (Other than "oh let's do it if apple is doing it")
  -No headphone port. That was one of the reasons I was excited to switch back to Samsung, my old S8 had a headphone port which I was missing. Another insult to the consumer...how many people were actually giving feedback that they didn't want the port? Clearly they were just copying apple's anti-consumer behavior. 
  -Why not have a black color option for all models? This gray is not bad but you'd have so many more people switching over if you had a proper black option in the entry model. Not everyone wants a huge phone (which is the only reason I didn't opt for the plus or ultra...this is a huge wasted opportunity for Samsung to capture a larger audience)
  -limited to just 256GB if I want a phone I can use with one hand? Either offer a 512GB option or give the ability to put a microSD card in. This was also a very sloppy decision by Samsung too. 
  
  In general Samsung continues to throw away big opportunities to win over former iPhone customers. Get your act together Samsung, you have a chance to be better than Apple. I hesitated a lot before trying this phone...over things you could have easily fixed with minimal impact to your costs. And they would go a long way towards winning over hearts of consumers.

I've bought the latest Samsung phone every year since the Galaxy S3. I've also loved all of them except the S5 and the S20. 
  
  The only reason this is getting good reviews is because the other options on the market are so weak. The reality is that the Galaxy S20 is a terrible showing from Samsung, for the following reasons:
  
  - Battery life is overall abysmal - I suppose this is due to the 120 Hz screen and 5G...but it stands out so poorly after I was so happy with the S10 battery life which could go on for multiple days). Samsung, no one wants to keep charging their phone every few hours. 
  
  - The phone is heavier, bulkier, and looks awful compared to past Galaxy phones. (The extra bulk doesn't even get me better battery life as it normally would on other phones...see first point). The gorgeous curved screens of past generations are reduced too dramatically that it feels like they aren't even there anymore, the color choice is awful if you want the regular sized Galaxy phone, and it just looks more like my wife's iPhone now. Thank god at least they didn't adopt the notch. 
  
  - The lack of headphone jack - why are you forcing the dongle life on us? This is one of the biggest reasons even my friends picked Samsung over Apple the last few generations. Clearly that extra space for increasing the battery size has not provided any benefits. Some of us have nice headphones and considering the frequency you expect us to charge the phone (see battery life point) why should we have to buy dongles to listen to music while we charge the phone? This one is a real slap in the face by Samsung. 
  
  Again, the only reason this phone is getting good reviews is because other offerings on the market are pretty bad too. If you compare this Galaxy phone to past generations, this is arguably the worst phone offering ever from Samsung. Though the Galaxy S5 is giving it a good run for its money. As far as overall Samsung offerings, this is as garbage of a product as Samsung ARTIK. 
  
  One more spectacular blunder like this and Samsung has lost another long time fan. 
  
  Bring back the size, style, and performance of the Galaxy S8 please. That was a wonderful phone for the time.

I have been a fan of of the Samsung Galaxy S series for seven years now, having had five devices in the series starting from the Galaxy S3. My favorite new feature on the Galaxy S20 is the 120hz refresh rate; it makes scrolling and transitioning through pages and apps a seamless experience. The only downside, though, is that going back to 60hz will make the phone seem noticeably slower. However, I always keep my phone on 120hz, so I do not come across that issue. I find that using the 120hz refresh rate does not drastically decrease the battery; I use my phone moderately and have never had my fully charged phone run out of battery at the end of a day's use. 
  
  Camera: I upgraded from the Samsung Galaxy S9, and I noticed a significant improvement in the front-facing camera on the S20. Images and videos are more clear and crisp. The rear camera also appears to have improved, but not significantly because I found that the camera on the S9 was excellent. I do not use the more advanced features on the camera/video, so I cannot speak on those. 
  
  Build Quality: The S20's lightweight aluminum build feels great. The S20 is much longer than it is wide (it is a tall phone), so it can be a bit awkward for me to use single-handedly. However, there is a single-handed mode in the features, which helps. 
  
  Super Fast-charging: The fast charging is, well, very fast, and I love it. The phone charges from 0% to 100% in about an hour. The charging cable that comes with the phone is also very sturdy and durable. Previous phone chargers would wear out much more quickly. 
  
  Ultrasonic fingerprint reader: Coming from the S9, I like the fingerprint sensor on the S20. However, it took me a few tries to get all of the angles for my fingerprint so that the fingerprint sensor worked accurately at various angles. The fingerprint sensor on the S9 is faster and more accurate; I would hardly touch the sensor and the phone would unlock. I have to put a bit more effort into unlocking the S20 (a bit more pressure, angling my finger properly). 
  
  Customizability: Another thing that I love about the S20 is that it is highly customizable. When I got this device, I spent around an hour customizing the features on the phone.

Beautiful bright display, excellent cameras for photos and video. 
  
  It has a fun "Single take" feature that records a short video and snaps several photos as you pan your shot for about 15 seconds, then arranges the photos and short video clips in a collage that you can edit, keep, or delete as you wish. I wouldn't buy the phone just for this but it's a fun addition. 
  
  The phone's processor is extremely powerful. Even with multiple apps open there is never a glitch or slow down. Everything is fast, smooth and reliable. I use my screen in 120hz mode and videos, animations, and scrolling are the smoothest I've seen on any screen anywhere. Expert reviews say 120hz drains battery faster but I get through a full day of use with power to spare. If you're a super heavy user you can switch to 60hz mode to save power. It's still great but not quite as buttery smooth. 
  
  I'm not a gamer so I can't address that. Everything else I do on this phone is smooth and effortless. For example, Android Auto with my old Nexus 6P worked, but everything was laggy and sometimes glitchy. I thought it was Android Auto problem because 6P was a decent phone. Nope. Galaxy S20 runs it fast and solid with no glitches. My in-car experience is way better now. 
  
  The more I live with this phone on a daily basis the more I like it. It is a great tool that enhances my experience no matter what I'm using it for. 
  
  I agree the S20 line is very expensive, but if you don't need the huge screen on the plus or ultra (I actually like the smaller pocketable size better), the S20 cost is in line with other flagship phones and is a top quality product. 
  
  Watch for sales and promotions. This unlocked version was $200 off for a short time so I snatched one. Btw I use this on T-Mobile and it works great for cellular and 4g LTE. There's no 5g in my area yet so I haven't tested that yet.

I am a huge fan of smartphones in general. I’ve owned a ton of different ones. Honestly, Samsung used to be one of my favorite manufacturers of smartphones until the S5 came out and that’s where they lost me. Since then, I’ve owned almost every one they’ve come out with, hoping it would win me back from iPhone and Pixel. Their screen is always so enticing, but then the experience just lets me down. I usually end up selling them or returning them. But this year they didn’t disappoint. I actually opted for the smallest version because phones are getting so big and expensive it’s ridiculous! I’m so glad I did. I don’t feel like I’m missing out on anything at all with the S20, and I’ve even heard lots of bad reviews about the overly priced Ultra. It takes great pictures, has good battery life, and is very lightweight. Also, I’m so glad they got rid of that curved screen for the most part. I hated that. I can’t speak for everyone, but I feel like Samsung did a great job this year on the S20.

I cant comment on my new Samsung Galaxy S20 yet... it is not yet working. 
  
  The representative that i spoke to in deciding to purchase the phone gave me inaccurate information. 
  1. The representative made clear to me that activating this unlocked phone on my Verizon account needed only that i take the sim card from my old phone and put it in my new phone. I VERY SPECFICALLY let him know that i was upgrading from a Galaxy S5. He told me it should work. 
  
  The Sim card from the S5 does not fit in the sim card slot of the S20. 
  The Best buy rep was... 
  a) uninformed
  b) dishonest (wanted me to just buy the phone)
  c) not paying attention
  
  Take your pick... in the end I am just now ordering a new sim card from verizon, which he told me i would not need. 
  
  2. Samsung Smart Switch - I asked the rep if the phone included a [Samsung OTG Micro - USB to USB Adapter]. He said clearly that YES... it is included... Alas... NO... it is NOT included. 
  
  will update my review when (if?) i succeed in securing a new sim card and make my first successful phone call.

I'm not a "Team android or Team apple" guy, I just want my $1000 product to work on every level. The "phone" stuff is excellent, but unfortunately we live in a technical world. There are too many security issues on this phone, something as simple as call blocking almost doesn't exist on this thing. Apple put a feature on their phones that blocks all unknown calls, on android you have to either type in the number or receive the call then block them. Also, the app store is a mess. How are apps that are "play verified" fake? Also, I've had LG phones before (great phones, slow updates) and I've never experienced internet dropping on them. All my samsungs do that. Like I said, I don't care which "team" you are on or is the best. I just want something that costs $1000 to give me better value than a $430 LG phone.

Motorola missed the mark. The build quality of this phone and price puts it in the same class as decent mid-range device. With no VoLTE support using both a T-Mobile and AT&T post paid SIM, this is a crippled device. ZERO help from Lenovo/Motorola. Since Lenovo bought Motorola Mobility, the customer support has gone by the wayside. 
  
  Neither AT&T or T-Mobile officially support the device, but both provider level 2 tech support state the SIMs are properly provisioned for VoLTE, and the Motorola One updated to Pie which supposedly supports VoLTE, but all calls drop to the legacy HSPA mode. Attempts to get help from Lenovo/Motorola were a waste of time. Even posted questions on their forums and no response from anyone at Lenovo. 
  
  Battery life is also poor. Drains the battery in standby overnight with no apps running or installed down 50 percent. Returned it and bought a Galaxy S8+ unlocked and works perfectly out of the box with full network support and the battery lasts days even with moderate use. 
  
  Motorola isn't what it once was. Will be the last Lenovo/Moto phone for me.

I upgraded from my Note 9 to this (since my lease ends). My hand is average size. 
  
  Buying Decision:
  -----------------------
  S20 Ultra was too big and way out of my budget. 
  
  Debate was between S20+ and S20. I liked the smaller form factor of the S20, comfortable to hold one handed. Main differences between S20 and S20+:
  - Display Size : I was happy with S20 size
  - Battery : 4000mAh is good enough through a normal day
  - TOF sensor: I never noticed a difference in live focus when I tested. I don't use live focus anyways as its not perfect yet. 
  
  
  What I think so far
  -------------------------
  
  1. 120hz is smooth
  
  2. Better phone for small hands. I am still having difficulties typing coming from Note 9 though :). May be taking time to get used to
  
  3. If you want no-loss photo the reality is 3x zoom, more than that you lose quality considerably. 
  
  4. Enjoying the wide angle camera. 
  
  5. Punch hole still bothers me a bit, if I had owned my Note 9, probably would have waited another year for the under display selfie camera (I hope so)
  
  6. Pro video mode is awesome 
  
  7. Video Stabilization is not great
  
  8. In display finger print scanner can be improved 
  
  9. I miss headphone jack. 
  
  10. Samsung made right decision to go easy on the curve :)
  
  11. 5G is not quite there
  
  
  Overall I reckon S20 and S20+ are the go to S20 series. Size should be the main deciding factor. If you plan to buy now, I would recommend to wait to see what One plus 8 has to offer.

I wanted to love this phone. The size is perfect (phones are too big these days! It is fast, it supports low and mid band 5G (no MM wave). Signal strength was WAY better than my iPhone every I went. The screen is amazing and camera pictures are better than my iPhone as well. 
  
  I ended up returning it because I could barely get through a day on battery. I wouldn't bother with 120hz if you want to make it though a day. At 60hz it is much better but I leave the house at 530 am, I had to charge it as soon as I got home if I wanted it to last through to bedtime. 
  
  If you leave the house at 9am you might be gtg but for early risers, you either need to charge it mid day or look for the bigger models with better batteries. 
  
  Buy it on sale, it goes on sale regularly for about $200 off, I wouldn't pay the full $999 retail for it

I'm sorry, but I can't comprehend these five-star reviews. Let me put this phone into a digestible snippet for you:
  
  1) It's very heavy! Like, more so than ANY other phone I've owned. So heavy that you can't even put this thing in your jeans or shorts without it dragging them down. (I carried this in the front pocket of my favorite sleep shorts and almost caused a disturbance at Publix.) 
  
  2) Contrast. OMG. They have turned up the contrast levels so much on this thing that it becomes impossible to ignore! Scrolling through FB, every image is just bursting out at you in a skewed Willy Wonka fashion. You can't even look at the news without each and every image blasting you in the face. 
  
  3) The camera. Speaking of contrast...if you prefer taking pictures and having them look NOTHING like they do in real life, then THIS is the phone for you! I took multiple side-by-side pics with this phone and my old Google Pixel 2XL and the difference was day and night (or, as this phone's camera would say, 'super bright yellow and blinding white.'" What, I assume, they were trying to do with this phone was "punch up" all your pictures so you can share them instantly without editing. Instead, every picture looks face and overly saturated (see attached pic).

I bought this phone instead of paying a furtune of $ For a phone through Verizon. When I was shopping around I wanted to make sure activation to an already established line wouldn’t be an issue and was told I would have no issues activating this phone with Verizon. After hours on the phone with Verizon’s customer service and tech team, after many failed attempts to get phone to work (could get internet service to work, just no phone calls or texts) they told me it’s not a compatible phone for Verizon’s mobile service and that Best Buy has the list of what unlocked phones are compatible with each service provider. If you guessed the AndroidOne wasnt on Verizon’s list, you would be correct! Just about every other Motorola phone is on the list but that’s besides the point, this phone doesn’t work with Verizon and from all the digging around I’ve done in disbelief, I believe this awesome phone will work with T mobile or AT&T. Will be returning the phone just wish I could return my hours of lost time and frustration arguing with Verizon since I was told by Best Buy associate it would work!

Coming from the iPhone X to this phone is a real delight. My first favorite thing about this phone is SPEED! From 5G to the 120 hertz screen it is so refreshing. In addition I was feeling limited on iPhone from just the simple fact that Apple apps are the default. 
  
  The first thing I changed from a ease of use stand point for my self is enable gestures for home, back, and multitasking. The fingerprint scanner is so nice to have with COVID requiring everyone to wear a mask that makes faceID useless. A couple of years ago I couldn't say that my Android was as smooth as an iPhone. Now I have to say hands down the S20 has my iPhone beat in smoothness on the OS side to opening apps. 
  
  Customization is so nice to have as well. I love being able to tell google "Play music" and instead of playing apple music it plays Spotify. Or if a friend sends you a text with a link to a website it will open Chrome, Firefox or any browser I set it to! 
  
  I own a car with Apple Carplay and Android Auto. After using Android Auto coming from Apple Carplay Android Auto is just better. Google Maps is your default search for addresses. Which is nice. Because Google Maps actually knows where buildings are located along a street verses Apple Maps. Subjecting you to find address numbers the old fashion way looking for the number on the building.

Bought this phone at the Best buy store. I made sure to ask the sales person if it would be comparable with att. They assured me it would. 
  
  After many calls to at&t, and Motorola I find out that this phone does not have LTE bands 12/17 that are the main LTE bands that at&t uses. 
  
  You can only receive LTE through att secondary bands. But if you receive or make phone calls or go into an area where you have 3g service the phone will not switch back to LTE unless you manually force it to everytime. 
  
  Now after a week of owning the phone and finding out it's not comparable with at&t, I have to hope Best Buy will let me return it and not charge me the restocking fee.

I bought this for my wife recently since we were going on our own cell phone plan. We got the unlocked model incase we wanted to switch carriers. She loves it. It is a big improvement over the Samsung Galaxy A10 that she had before. The camera quality is very good , if not exceptional compared to the S9 which I currently have. I will eventually upgrade to this phone for myself when I can afford it. I played around with it and I notice there was no preinstalled carrier bloatware which was very nice (unlocked). I am sure the other ones that are carrier locked come with that stuff. 
  
  After playing around with the phone, it has a very similar feel to the S9 and S10. Volume buttons are placed on the same side as the power button, which is hard to get used to that. Setting up the fingerprint reader is pretty easy, only thing is if you have a crappy screen protector, it may interfere with that. Its very fast, start up time is quick. I am sure there are other features of the phone I have yet to discover, I will find those over time. 
  
  The only down side I see is that this does not have a headphone jack. I am not going to dock it point for that for that. Most phone manufacturers are going away with the 3.5mm jack (sadly). The headphones that come with use the USB-C connection where you charge your phone. Since this phone has better battery life, I suppose you would not need to use the charger as often when using headphones, but that would depend on the user. 
  
  The headphones are pretty good with sound quality. They are not bad, not the worst I have used. All in all, an excellent phone that I would highly recommend.

Let me start off by saying that I'm no power user/mobile gamer. I use this phone to listen to podcasts on the road, check social medias, and do normal phone things like call people. The speakers are surprisingly good after hearing those of the other phones in this price range. Screen is nice, clear and bright when needed. Cellular antenna is average. The phone (after a few weeks of use) hasnt locked up on me, and shows no signs of slowing down. To keep it short, this phone does everything it should, and everything I need it to. My one real complaint would be the battery. It's a shame to have a phone this well made and still have a sub 4k mAh lithium battery. It does run through about 4 hours of youtube/video play without charge, and I can still go at least a day of regular use, but I know this could become quite miserable to use in the future now with the lack of changeable batteries. All in all, if I had to score it, I'd give this phone an 8.5/10.

So for the last 10 years, I have been mostly an Apple user. However, my work phone has always been an Android. And I've always liked Android phones. My current work phone is a Galaxy note 9. And I like it. I decided I wanted to make a switch for my personal phone. However I did not want to buy a Galaxy note 9 as they are expensive. The employee in the store help me narrow down my choices and I decided to go with the Motorola One. 
  This phone is extremely beautiful. Has a iPhone X type of look. The first time I held it, I was really impressed with how easy it was to hold. I'm used to having to use both hands to hold a phone. So it was very refreshing to only have one hand to use this phone. The build quality is nice. It does not feel cheap at all. I have seen people complain about battery life, however, I have not seen issues with battery. I charge it overnight and wake up and go on with my day and by the end of the work day I still have about 40% left. So I am not sure what others are doing but I don't have that problem. I also like that it has expanded storage. I did buy an microSD card to upgrade my storage. 
  day-to-day performance is pretty decent. The reason why I gave four stars instead of 5, is that it does lag just a small bit when playing a game like words with Friends. Sometimes it's a little laggy when sending a text message, but not enough to irritate me. 
  call quality seems to be awesome. I have not had any calls drop. Crystal clear sound. The speaker is nice. The camera is a bit finicky. The selfie mode does it take the best pictures in the world. Definitely not good pictures in low-light. The rear camera is really nice. 
  overall, I would recommend this phone. If you want a nice unlocked phone at a pretty affordable price, this phone is really a good way to go. Motorola really upped their game with this device.

Upgrading from an S7 Edge, I can say that this phone is absolutely fantastic. I went for Cloud Blue and I was not disappointed with how this phone looked because it looks stunning. This phone has an absolutely beautiful 6.1 inch display which ought to be large enough for most people. Performance is snappy--I can say I rarely, if not never, experience slow downs on this phone. The 120 HZ refresh rate, while it does lower battery life, is so smooth that it is hard to pass up. Speaking of battery life, the battery can last two days which is good for me considering the fact that I use my phone relatively frequently throughout a day. The camera quality is fantastic and has many cool options--some of them being niche, admittedly, but still cool. Of course, being Android, you get a lot of customization features which I have been utilizing. You can really do what you want to this phone. Absolutely loving this phone!

I've tried a lot of phones in 2019/2020 and this one fits my needs perfectly. It's my favorite. 
  
  1. I have big hands but I'm sick of the overly large phones. This one is the perfect size for me and my pocket. 
  2. Love the power in this phone, 12gb of ram with the 865 is potent. 
  3. Because it's smaller, this screen is super crisp. 563 ppi ...enough said and with the 120htz refresh rate, clean experience. 
  4. Battery life is excellent for me. I've been around android phones so long I know all the battery saving tips. I don't need 5g with as fast as this phone is already so disabling it increases my battery life tremendously. Plus I don't play games on my phone or have a million notifications enabled. I use my phone a lot and I can stay off the charger from the time i wake up until I hit the pillow again at night (7am-11pm). 
  5. I found this phone open box and it was still new with untouched accessories, even still had the plastic on the phone for $600 ($400 savings). Winning. 
  
  If you have similar taste/needs this is a good pickup, that is if you can still find one at BB. It was hard tracking this one down. I'll be keeping this one for a long time.

If you want a top tier flagship, don't stop here. 
  BUT if you want a budget phone that can kick butt, take great pictures, and last all day? This. 
  Google's software makes this phone feel so much more than it is. It isn't the biggest baddest phone, it fits nicely in my smallish hands and is a big upgrade over my 2yr old phone. 
  I've gone back and forth between Samsung and Pixel devices since the first Pixel and I have to say, this is by far the happiest I've been with a new phone in a very long time. I've felt cheated out of money, disappointed after a few days with the new bells and whistles, and left wanting with battery life but not with this phone. I hope none of that changes. 
  Plus, I have this phone on Google Fi and my normally barely there service from a big company that claims best service has been absolutely blown out of the water. I can now make phone calls from inside of my house!!

Phone is awesome. The service wasn't but whatever.

I got this Pixel 5 to replaced my Pixel 2. So far, I like the simplicity of this phone. It has what I need for daily use with good camera. The price is not too expensive, and the design is good for my small hands. This sorta sage color got multiple compliments from my co-workers.

I was coming from an older Samsung phone, so this was a nice upgrade. I love the fingerprint sensor and the phone isn't overly large as some others are. I don't use all the features I could but functionality and response time are good.
Awesome device. Smooth UI and fast charge. Fits perfect in your hands

This is a solid upgrade from the Pixel 2. It's slightly bigger with almost no bezel and has lots more RAM and double the storage of my old Pixel 2. The software threw me for a loop right away defaulting to gestures, so I didn't know how to get to the home screen but Googling the issue identified an answer to the familiar 3-button navigation.
So far I love this phone. It has a phenomenal camera that uses the real color and doesn't really distort color negatively.
Impressive speed, easy navigation to access resource tools

I guess Google just did it again by keeping a low profile, sensible, user friendly and medium-high budget. 
  I've been using this phone for almost a month now and being an average user, one who doesn't play cgi or high end games, browses the internet, WhatsApp, Facebook, slack, emails kind of guy, I'm impressed. I bought this to replace my 3 year old Pixel 2 and have been delighted by the fact that - Wow! That's an awesome battery (goes for almost 36-40hrs+, where I've seen it do a 48hrs too), excellent camera (I actually loved the pixel 2 more than 3 (my wife has that)), pleasant refresh rate, great bluetooth and 5G connectivity (Google Fi) and all the other greatness of Google.

Great phone with wonderful camera. Great battery life. Great screen size while overall size of phone is very compact.

Great phone, no complaints , price could be lower though

I upgraded from a Pixel 2 XL to the Pixel 5 and I am very satisfied.

The phone has been very glitchy for me. It can't do simple things like auto rotate when turned on as well as tap and lift to check phone don't work. All troubleshooting steps google tried didn't work. They said wait for the devs to do something. Much like what they told me on the numerous Pixel 2xl camera issues they had. They never fixed them. 
  
  Outside of that the phone is ok. It's a decent size for single hand use. It's a medium size screen and the display is of decent quality. Its fast enough with slight delays in processing pictures or video. They omitted the neural core which helped previous models. 
  
  The phone is overpriced for what it is. This should have been no more than $599 because the competition has their mid-range phone at 699 but contain flagship phone chipsets.
too small. disappointed that they stopped making the xl versions of their phone. works fine but size does matter despite the rumors

Pixel 5 is actually better than I expected but I upgraded from a 3 years old phone. It has a very good battery life, wireless charging works great for me. I am still getting used to the finger scan at the back side because I used have it up front. Pictures are very good, speed for accessing websites and accounts is much better than my old phone. Very happy with it so far (after about a week)

I have been using Pixel Phones since the original came out. Some people may get caught up in the fact that this phone does not offer the highest-end 2020 CPU as Samsung or others do. I am here to tell you that Google does the best job in the industry in optimizing their phones and the user experience is fantastic without the high-end CPU. This keeps the cost of the phone down and much more reasonable than Samsung or Apple. Below are the highlights. 
  
  - Fantastic Camera as always with Pixel Devices
  - Battery life is amazing. Lasting two days under some circumstances. 
  - 5G connectivity
  - Size of the phone enables single-hand use
  - Fingerprint reader where it should be. No stupid face unlock. 
  - 3 Years of promised updates from Google
  - This model is unlocked. Use it with any carrier
  - Price is amazing compared to Apple or Samsung flagship offerings
  
  Cons:
  -The stereo speakers are not as good as the stereo speaker with the competition. But not bad either. 
  - Fast charging is nice, but not nearly as fast as some of the competitors. 
  
  If you are looking for a "flagship phone" without some of the meaningless features that Samsung and Apple want to make you THINK you need, then this phone is for you. The price is perfect versus the competition and Google's 3 years of monthly update support will not be matched by Samsung or Apple, I can promise you that.
This is my 1st pixel phone. Love everything about it and happy I made the switch.
3 years of guaranteed software updates. Nuff said.

Sooooooo I've been wanting a pixel since the pixel 3 but never made the jump because I've been a dedicated iphone guy since the iphone 4. I had the iphone x and didn't see the hype on the new iphone for $1200. I'm not a video editor or a professional protographer. I don't need the best phone out there. Anyways I bought a he dang pixel 5 and I couldnt have been happier. It doesnt really feel like android. It's very similar to iphone in regards to thumb gestures keyboard etc. The best thing about this phone are all the little features exclusive to the pixel. phone screening, google assistant holds for you calls, you'll find them if you get the phone. Ive had this phone for 14 days and only 1 issue. When texting my wife who has iphone her texts weren't coming threw. Restarted the phone and no issues since. I really recommend this phone especially at the price point. You have all the great features you want. 90hz screen great battery sleek design AMAZING camera. And the biggest thing for me was the weight difference from the iphone it's like a feather!! Just buy it. Guarantee you will fall in love 
  P.s. get the google pixel buds! And your still under the price of a new iphone 12 pro

Great overall phone, true Android experience with no bloatware. 
  
  Wish it was $599 retail, with $499 promos. 
  
  Bought it used - excellent condition on Best Buy and it was flawless. Guess some kid didn't like the tiny gap between the screen and the phone body, and returned it.
Best smartphone camera I've ever seen. Astrophotography is incredible.

The size is right, the battery is great with Extreme Battery Saver and 3 years of android updates should be a minimum of what Google gives for a $700 phone. 
  Unfortunately, this phone is not a good 5G alternative with plenty of other 5G phones for the same cost with better specs. 
  More importantly, Sub-6 5G is only a little faster than 4G LTE and mmWave is only in certain cities under a mmWave antenna. So if you live in a city where mmWave has been established by a carrier then great. If you rely on T-Mobile, Google Fi, or US Cellular then you'll be waiting for mmWave (the UBER fast 5G) to be turned on at your location. Why do you think Verizon is now selling home 5G? Answer: their 5G is not available unless you live in a city where they've installed it, and big venues like stadiums... 
  I don't knock the phone because it is good but if you NEED a new phone, not WANT a new phone then buy cheap like the Pixel 4a 5G at $150 less, the same phone with a 3.5 headphone jack. If you need a bigger phone then go Samsung since they've really stepped up their Android Update game. 
  Again, I'm not knocking the Pixel line, I own a Pixel 4 and wanted to try the 5G line and can confirm with other reviews here and elsewhere if you do your homework you'll find that the speeds for Sub-6 (slow 5G) that goes through walls is not much faster then what you currently receive without a 5G phone. Don't let all the hype be phone company's or providers fool you. 
  Then there's the reported gap in the screen that many people are noticing. Gap in a screen? sounds like a production issue we've all heard of with other phone companies? 
  
  I would recommend this phone to a friend but only if they lived under a 5G mmWave tower or spent the majority of their day in a 5G mmWave city working and what not...
Love my pixel 5. Ready to use Android. Everything android should be. Love the camera. Love that everything is compatible because google is mostly all I use.
Thought I'd miss the XL size from the 2 and 3 but I didn't. This thing is fast, gorgeous, and great priced. Get yourself one!

great pictures and sound quality, good functionality. ok battery life. my wife loves it

Solid phone. Battery is very good (not great). Seems fast. Can download all the apps I need. It's a bit smaller than other phones, which I like. I will say the finger print sensor needs to be cleaned alot. Often it wont recognize my finger but will once I have wiped down and cleaned the sensor.
No issues. Seems fine. I upgraded from a Samsung. I prefer the Google apps to the Samsung apps.

Google - Pixel 5 5G 128GB (Unlocked) - Just Black
  The Google Pixel 5 with 5G is an interesting phone. The black aluminum body looks and feels very good in the hand. I really like the simple layout of just a power and volume button. The display is OLED and is able to use a 90Hz screen refresh rate. It’s a 6” 1080p screen with HDR10+ and looks crisp and sharp. I found the screen to have very nice colors out of the box. I also like that it supports the always on screen. The phone uses a Qualcomm 765 Snapdragon which isn’t the fastest chip out today but I never found it to lack in my usage. I don’t play mobile games so that might be a consideration. The phone comes with 128GB of local storage and 8GB of ram and it is IP68 dust/water resistant. The phone supports Bluetooth 5.0 with aptX HD support so if you have this aptX support in your Bluetooth headphone you will get very high quality music. I do wish Google supported SD cards with their phones but this was dropped long ago. The phone has stereo speakers on the bottom and they did sound very good. This was also true for incoming and outgoing calls. The back fingerprint reader was easy to setup and is very fast in use. The phone supports fast wireless and wired charging including reverse charging in the event you ever need to top off another device. As is the case with Google phones the picture quality is excellent and includes an ultrawide lens. The phone supports video recording up to 4k@60fps and 1080p up to 240fps. The camera does an excellent job in most any lighting condition. The phone comes out of the box with Android 11 and the October 2020 security update. As is typical with Google phones this is pure Android at its finest and is a pleasure to use. In my testing as seen in the attached image T-Mobile 5G service is all over the map in my local area. On one street I could match my home cable connection, on the next it was no better than 4G. The quality of the 5G was directly related to the signal strength. Where it was strongest the speeds and ping were good enough to replace my home cable service. If only the signal was more stable. This might not be due to the Pixel since this is the first 5G phone I have been able to test. Verizon has a different type of 5G then T-Mobile so the results could be very different. My take is when buying a new phone today, having 5G is a good idea but I would not let it be my primary reason to choose one phone over another. However as more 5G service is built out I would hope the stability also improves. I do like the Pixel 5. I really like it's camera and clean Android. The 5G is still a question to me but I am glad it's here. The new phones available give you lots of choices. I am not sure Google has enough here to make the case that their phone is better than the competition. This is also true now that Samsung has announced 3 years of support for their current phones. This was one of the primary reasons to choose a Google phone. The Pixel 5 is a very nice phone and I enjoy it but I find it hard to make it a solid recommendation with the other options that are available.

Took some getting used to but a great upgrade from what I was using (iPhone XR). Physically, phone looks great: has a unique color and a unique, textured feel (back side). Love the touchscreen response, pictures look great, apps have been functioning intelligently for the most part. Only negative has been the fingerprint detector, which won't work if your finger isn't completely dry.

Extremely please with the Google Pixel 5 so far. Seems lightning fast, no unnecessary bloatware. Fairly intuitive to get set up and running. Camera is a big upgrade from older Moto phone. 
  Amazing battery life as well.

I recently took my Pixel 3 on a trip to visit family and at the gas...it fell out of my lap, the screen cracked fully in the middle and the corners were busted. I took it to a repair shop and got quoted $290.00 for both screen and USB port replacement. I am good...at that cost it was a no brainier. Look up and realize that there was a Best Buy store across the street. Walked in and walked out with a new Pixel 5 in my hand. 
  
  The Pixel 5 solved a lot of the issues that was plaguing the Pixel 3 and dealt with the battery issue that Google purposely did with the Pixel 4. There is just something about a Pixel phone that is hard to describe that my parents describe the way they use their iPhone. The thing is the phone works and it works well! I wasn't expecting the phone to keep up with my Pixel 3 in terms of performance but difference between having 8gbs and 3gbs of memory sureade the difference. Now instead of lagging right away when I have at least 5 or 7 apps open. That issue is no more. I've been using up to 10+ apps without knowing only to realize it when I'm closing them. My biggest purchase for the Pixel 5 is for my every day phone and of course the pictures. Everyone including myself knows that the pictures that comes out of the Pixel is usually a sure hit regardless of the model. The Pixel 5 ensured this by me testing several shots while on a camping trip and wow. The pictures are overall very pleasant and lovely. Initially I was a bit worried for action shots because with all of the update that my Pixel 3 was getting, the camera app definitely lagged quite a bit. It was usable but I wanted with certainty that this was a no issue. The Pixel 5 turned out to be more amazing than I had imagine. I really advised people to learn some of the tricks that allows the phone to take such photos. The biggest surprised and benefits of the Pixel is when you have it setup to a tripod...make sure you have 3 second delay and have it in night mode. If you're trying to do a star shot or light painting it's always usually the same. The light painting requires you to have someone in the background with a light stick painting the person you're trying to get a photo off. Keep an eye on the Pixel screen. The results usually shows within 10 seconds. The moment you see the result, press stop. Repeat this process till you get a good trip on how to get better with your subject and the phones ability. This also works with astrophotography and human subject. I usually do it within the first 10-15 seconds or let the phone run its 3+ minute course and have the subject enter the photo the last 20-30 second. This gives the phone plenty of time to clean the image and grab as many star as possible. For the individual... make sure you slowly shine a light left to right to keep the person in the image and have that subject light up and be present in the photo. All else wise, the Pixel is a fantastic everyday phone and the battery life is such a no brainier for anyone. It's no flag ship as far as specs are compared but specs alone does not speak for a phones worth. It's fluid and smooth, my every day use has not been any issue at all! Love my phone and hopefully Pixel 6 will come out with a killer camera spec and more storage! Come on Google!
Reliable and easy to use. Did not feel like a mid phone. Felt like it outperformed the iPhone 12 pro to be honest.
Its a good phone. Though i feel like the fingerprint reader is less responsive than on previous pixel models.
I love this phone. The Pixel is absolutely the best Android phone hands down.

Screen unlock is a little squirrelly. Has a fair amount of settings. The biggest advantage IMO with this phone is it's seemless integration with a Google eco-system. It's like a handheld remote for your google automation.
Great phone, extra long battery life. Purchased 2.
Worth every penny! Amazing software experience! Definitely recommended

Excellent phone for everyday use. No fancy hardware features. No fancy sensors. Just a typical phone perfect for a daily driver.

Very great phone had it for a few days so far the only thing lacking is the speakers are a little underwhelming due to the fact there is only one speaker on the bottom and the top speaker is behind the glass muffled.

Working great for my blind 31 year old son with talkback turned on and he loves the battery life.
Great camera easy to use, my whole family now has the google pixel.

I have been wanting the Pixel for the longest time now. I bought this one because I heard the battery life was better than Pixel 4. I have had it for 3 months now and I can testify the battery life is amazing. You get unlimited Google photos storage with this model. The Google assistant phone screen is also a great feature Apple does not offer. How it works is that when you get a call it will act like your secretary. It will automatically hang up scam calls and will ask non-scam callers what they are calling about then you can choose to answer or not. 
  
  The camera has a stabilizer, so you always know if you're taking your photos straight. The phone is big enough for me and the whole screen is the display similar to Iphone 10. This is also not offered on Apple camera. If you love Google apps like YouTube, maps, calendar etc then this phone is perfect for you. I also love this over iPhone because it's easy to share media content and easy to access your files.

I bought and gifted my mom the very first Pixel XL when it came out about 4 years ago. That phone had been holding up pretty well until now, no complaints. I got her the 64 gb version which started to max out, so it was time for the upgrade. She loved her Pixel XL so much that she didn't want to switch to any other phone and I didn't want to give her the older generation Pixel. Fortunately, Pixel 5 came out and it was perfect timing. So I got this one for her and she just can't thank me enough. It's a big upgrade for her from Pixel 1 XL to 5 without compromising on the size (pic of both phones side by side attached for comparison). She just loves it. The only thing that she's still getting used to is the lack of three virtual buttons at the bottom that Pixel 1 XL had. It will take some time but she will get a hang of it for sure. It feels so nice to hold the phone and is very lightweight. I immediately ordered a phone cover & a screen protector as I know all modern phones are so delicate that they can break even if you just dream about dropping them. Lol. 
  
  Since my mom isn't too much into tech, I had to set the phone up for her and do the usual data transfer. Surprisingly, it gave me bit of a hard time setting up/transferring data. Not sure what the problem was. It would get stuck at one point during set up process, just would not proceed and eventually give up. I tried 3 times and put it aside after failing every time. I then tried it again after about half an hour and it worked right away. It was walk in the park after that. I finished the setup/transfer and explored the phone little bit. I will admit, it's a great phone in comparison with the other Pixel that she had. My dad has a Pixel 4 and even in comparison to that, Pixel 5 seems a lot more upgraded. The only feature missing from Pixel 5 as compared to 4 is the facial unlock feature. Really, I'm not sure why you would remove one of the best features from your phone. I read somewhere online that according to Google, it's ‘a good trade-off’ to enable other premium features. I don't know about that but I do miss that feature. Hence the reason for deducting a star. 
  
  This phone is equipped with 5G capability but I was not much excited about this feature as we don't have 5G coverage in our area but it's a good to have feature that we can use in future. It has a 90 hz display which is wonderfully smooth. The phone feels incredibly responsive and the difference between this and the Pixel 1 XL screen is very noticeable. Gives you just as much usable space as the 1 XL, but with so much less weight/bevel. Camera is also good. Every photo blows me away and the portrait mode is so good. The lack of an absolutely bleeding-edge sensor does not negatively impact the camera at all. The lack of a separate chip for processing images means that the time it takes for a picture to be visible in perfect quality after you take it is noticeable. It's not a problem at all if you're taking three or less pictures or if you're not immediately checking to see what the picture looked like, but if you're taking a bunch at once, you may occasionally find yourself getting frustrated by the seconds it takes to actually be able to flip through all the pictures. Pixel phones are among the best, if not the best, for taking photos, hence you can rest assured that it's quite easy to take awesome quality photos, without putting in much effort. The dual camera setup, features the standard wide angle & an ultra wide angle sensor. The photo editing/touching up software that comes with the phone is pretty impressive and fast, there is the ability to change the lighting and shadows in the pic after its been taken. I have not had enough time to deep dive but the few things I've tried have worked well. Fingerprint scanner is fast and accurate, a definite improvement over Pixel 1 XL. Battery life is phenomenal. Each charge seems to last about 1.5 days of regular usage. Much better than the previous phone. Wireless charging & reverse wireless charging are super convenient with metal enclosure. Again, an added feature that Pixel 1 XL didn't have. Sound quality is nice but sounds tiny to me at high volume, this is because there are no speakers built in but uses a vibration technology to play sound through the phone. I'm not talking about midrange where most people are likely to use but at full blast. 
  
  This is the best choice for a modern android phone in 2020! It has great power-efficient specs, 90 Hz display, long-lasting battery, all-screen design (no notch! ), very responsive fingerprint reader (for those who cannot use face unlock). I would definitely recommend it.
So far so good I haven't had any issue with the phone.

If you like a slim phone, this is it! I had been using a Pixel 2XL for a couple years and it has taken a bit of time to get used to how much smaller this one is - including the screen. great phone. amazing camera which is much better than samsung I would say. minimal lag on the screen. love it
Wanted to love it, mostly did but the screen was just too small for me after getting use to larger phones. Make a larger model and I'm there. Stock Android is a joy

Perfect size! Good screen. Solid Battery. Great software and updates. Really good camera. 
  
  Two complaints. The phone is smooth for most things but gets a bit bogged down more quickly than phones with the highest-end processor. This results in the phone getting warm when it's working harder. Also, the under-screen speaker at the top of the phone is loud but tinny sounding.

Great phone, super fast and smooth operation. no issues at all. T-Mobile only sells 4a5G and not Pixel 5, was told by their store person that Pixel 5 may not get 5G on T-Mobile because it may be missing radio bands for their 5G (n25 specifically) . On the website I saw that they use n41 and n71 for 5G and will use n260 and n261 for mmWave in the future, Pixel 5 has all these bands so I checked and I get 5G icon showing up in my phone (you have to turn wifi off to see what you are connected to because wifi symbol hides 5G or LTE icon when wifi is turned on. In my experience, I do get 5G most of the time even though I live right on the edge of the coverage map where 5G ends in my area. Hopefully anyone else who has T-Mobile also can get the 5G also. Phone has some neat features too, Really like it!

Specs don't make a phone- this phone is a testament to that fact. Yes, there are much better hardwares from plenty of flagships this year, however the pixel 5 excels in giving you a smooth user experience and great useful features including an excellent camera. Ultrawide makes it a cut above Pixel 4a, and I found myself going to the Pixel 5 whenever my Pixel 4a couldn't capture the full frame from a short distance (in a mall for example). The screen is big enough and the android goodies baked into it makes it an absolute pleasure to use. Battery optimization is great, sound is good enough although not great. However, get pixel buds and youtube premium and it's a complete media powerhouse. Overall, a good move Google, now solve your hardware woes with using your own Pixel hardware that we hear are in the works, and we are ready to conquer the world!
This is such a great phone. The camera quality is excellent. We bought this for a friend and she absolutely loves it. Couldn’t be happier.

This is my 3rd Google Pixel.

  A bit smaller than Pixel 3XL, but plenty of options. The look and feel modern, fast, the apps and menues are more intuitive tha IOS. Face down silent mode works perfect (it didnt worked in my XR), and contacts works fine too.

I upgraded from a OnePlus 6T and I have to say I love the Pixel 5. Speed wise it feels slightly quicker and very smooth and the size fits me better for one handed use. The finger print scanner works a lot better and is perfectly placed. I finally have wireless charging and WiFi calling capability now on my network. The speakers are definitely louder than the OnePlus too. Battery life is great, lastng all day and you can't beat Google's UI. 
  
  Build quality is top notch on the phone as well.
Excellent phone. Battery life is significantly improved from the Pixel 3 I had before.
Not impressed with the size could be better but other than that great phone

Love the phone & really love the 5G service! The features are great, the screen is sharp and clear and the camera is the best I've ever used on a phone.

Being a Note 8 owner, I didn't feel like I was due for a major upgrade. But, with a kid on the way, I wanted to upgrade my camera and be able to use Gcam natively. I must say that the Pixel 5 is an impressive phone. All day battery life, snappy and fluid, Google Assistant (way better than Bixby ugh). Imo people tend to overblow the processor being "out of date", as long as the actual hardware implementation hold up well with the pure Android OS. Also, my mobile gaming has shifted to cloud services like Stadia or GeForce Now, where a powerful CPU is not needed (I've played 10+ hrs of Cyberpunk on this phone and it's better than consoles). I'm happy to have gotten the Sage color as well. It's an excellent phone for a realistic price, but if you really want a crazy powerful flagship phone, there are rumors of an early 2021 version.

I love the Google Pixel line and think the Pixel 5 is an excellent phone.

  The phone arrived with major scratches on it's screen.

  Yet, the customer support told me that the return policy was only 14 days. 
  I wasn't reimbursed in any way and am very frustrated by this purchase. 
  Last time I buy at Best Buy.
