I love this phone. I switched to the pixel when the 3a xl came out loved all the features on that phone and so I decided to get the pixel 5. I do wish it had the squeeze feature on the side like the 3 did but no biggie. The gestures took a little time to get used to from the 3 but it is easy to get used to and honestly like the 5 better.
My daughter loves this phone, Great camera and very fast. The price was the best we could find.
If you had a pixel phone before this is a continuation of the brand. I love the fact that the phone has no bloatware and I am not forced to have carrier or brand software on the phone. Solid phone.

This is a great phone. I have had three Pixel phones now and this is the best so far. The battery life is excellent! I can easily go the whole day with regular to heavy use and still have juice left. I have no worries about going the whole day without having to top off, which was a concern with my previous Pixels. The screen is clear and vibrant and I haven't seen any performance issues even though it's not using a flagship processor. It continues to have the best camera in the business, especially with point and shoot pictures. Highly recommend for those people who want premium features in a phone without a premium price

4.5 stars - I'm coming from the Pixel 3XL, and I have to say that this feels like an iterative upgrade. I like the increased storage, the added wide angle lens, and I'm getting used to the smaller size. Once I put a case on it it felt more secure in my hands. I'd say if you're on the 4XL and getting by with the battery life it's not worth the switch to the 5. Otherwise the Pixel 5 on its own is a solid phone that I'm quite pleased with. Especially for the modest price by todays standards.
I love the phone. But 2 years after the galaxy s10e and it feels inferior.

I upgraded from a Pixel 3, so I am thrilled that the 5 is very close to the same size but has a screen that is .5" larger (due to reduced bezels). Great screen, terrific cameras and camera software... love the "Night Sight" low light camera performance. Fast performance, great display... I love the "pure Google" approach with monthly security updates and quick updates to subsequent Android versions. I was happy with my Pixel 3 and, strictly speaking, did not need to upgrade to the 5... but I'm glad I did for the sake of the larger screen and speedier processor in the same form factor.

The Pixel 5 delivers on almost all fronts, but I find the battery life still peters out too soon. I conduct business on my phone, communicate via email, text, and phone calls. I was hoping to get through the business day without recharging, but that hasn't been the case. All other features of the phone are supreme.

I just upgraded from the Pixel 2 XL, which is a phone I happened to love. I am not a fan of the Apple platform and have had really bad luck with Samsung phones. I love my new phone and it is a nice upgrade from the 2. Will remain a loyal Pixel customer.
Excellent phone. Easy to use but the camera hardware is outdated. The software does improve the photo quality but it doesn't do it when we click pictures from inside apps like WhatsApp.

Went to this phone after my lg v60 thinQ stopped working. It doesn't have the power user features like the v60 but it's a solid phone with great software and I know it'll be supported for a few years unlike the v60.
Overall it’s a very good light weight phone the finger print reader is so helpful now since we all are required to wear masks out in the public

Well worth gift 
  Gifted to a friend and he absolutely loves it

Ever since I found the Google pixel i have been in love with it. I used to have iPhones and then when I found these i couldn't help but switch. And i haven't had any problems at all with the phone. Highly recommended.
I absolutely love this phone I'm so glad I got it. I've been wanting one for so long.

Can definitely tell this doesn't have a top tier precessor as the phone seems delayed at times when doing daily tasks. That said, still takes great pictures, has a nice display, and the battery life is solid. 
  
  If pictures is what you care about it is definitely worth saving money compared to other brand's flagship phones. 
  
  Overall good value for the price.
Speedy, no issues. Love the size compared to the 4 XL. Fits in one hand much easier. Screen super clear. Big fan of finger print scanner. Love that it is back.
I am very happy with my Pixel 5. The fingerprint sensor did not work after several attempts to set up. This was not a deal breaker. Other features are outstanding.
Great phone for an amazing price, would recommend to anyone looking to upgrade from their current device. Familiar for android users and refreshing for ios users. All around great phone!

Amazing phone. I've had the first pixel the third pixel and now the five. I thought I was going to switch to a Samsung s20 Fe and I did within a day of having that phone I switched back and waited for the pixel 5 to be available. Love this phone I wish to squeeze to open up the Google Assistant was still here but other than that it's great phone.
It’s a great phone, great picture quality, better than iPhone 12. I don’t think I’m going back to apple!

Amazing phone. This phone has a 6 inch screen but feels so much more compact and comfortable to hold than my wife's iPhone 12. The Sorta Sage color is very nice and the grippy coating over the glass back makes it a pleasure to hold. Cameras are amazing as always on Google Pixel products. I love that they went back to fingerprint scanner as face unlock is terrible during these covid-19 mask days. The 5G is fast and the snapdragin 765 is wonderful and smooth like butter. Great deal at $699. Works great with my Chromebook and Pixel Stand!
Excellent phone. Has 5G and awesome camera. I especially like the pixel experience where there are no bloatwares to slow down the phone.

Great phone to have for 5G. I upgraded from the Pixel 2XL since it did not get any more security updates. It was either this of the Pixel 4a 5G. This feels much better in my hands (I have smaller hands) and feels natural to call, text, and hold. The volume was a bit concerning since I am hearing impaired, but the volume is fine and does the job. If you like Android, this is the phone to have. It's a premium phone for less than the premium phone price.

This phone has the best battery life of any Pixel I've owned (I've owned three). I can go two days without charging, and that's with normal usage. That's insane. 
  
  Build quality is good, the software is acceptable. I don't see a marked improvement in the phone over my previous Pixel 3 XL. However, the 90hz screen is nice when watching UHD videos. 
  
  My Pixel 3 XL was dying a slow death so this upgrade was worthwhile. Best Buy took care of me on an open-box deal, so that made up my mind to go with it.

Great phone. I got it over the 4a 5g because of the water resistance and the wireless charging. The build control could be better as there is many, including my own unit that has a screen gap. Overall great phone.

Very happy with purchase. The phone was in excellent condition and the price for the open box version was fair as well. Would definitely recommend this phone as it is the best Google has to offer to date.
I didn't expect to like this better than my Pixel 4XL but to my surprise I actually do!

P1 & 3 owner previously. I knew the 5 wasn't much of a jump but it didn't even feel like an upgrade, let alone taking away the squeeze function I used all the time. 
  I tested it along side the OnePlus8t+ (both on TMO) and the 5G on the Pixel was consistently 20+Mbps less on both up and down. The OnePlus has its downsides (camera) but actually felt like an upgrade to me with better speeds (and a better deal).
Bought as a gift. Recipient loves it. Said quality is great.

Just a few days after switching from older Samsung. I enjoy how fast it is! Learning to use the camera to fullest. Close ups have been great. Miss having more than 2x telephoto. Call volume good. I like the size although a little slippery. Going to get a case.

I actually love this phone. It simply does everything asked of it. It has more than enough memory to load a reasonable number of apps and not get the dreaded low resources warnings that I used to get almost daily as updates moved apps from an sd card back to the main memory of my old phone. Battery life has been stellar. Even if I listen to streamed music all day, through the speaker, I'm never below 40% in the evening.

I have always wanted to own a google pixel, and I am very happy with my purchase. I am using it sI am coming to Pixel 5 after using Nokia 7.2 as my previous smartphone. Pixel 5 is an all rounder. The Snapdragon 765G is pretty efficient. No lag in regular daily use works well. 
  
  Pros
  Compact and Sturdy design
  Punch hole display with minimal bezels
  Amazing battery life
  Wireless and Reverse Wireless Charging
  Water Resistance
  Standard Pixel style photography
  5G
  
  Cons
  Old Main camera sensor
  Price - Will be a great deal for $600

I held onto my Pixel 2 XL until the security updates ran out. It was a great phone so I hoping the Pixel 5 would be at least as good. I haven't been disappointed and the added bonus of a strong 5G signal in my area makes it even better! I highly recommend!
I love the aesthetics of the phone and the quality !
Best android experience and best camera out there. The only downside is there is no XL size for this phone. Hope they release next year a bigger phone.
Great phone even better service. Buying experience was easy and enjoyable
Kinda confusing coming from a Samsung but I love google and don't know why I haven't got a Pixel sooner, very clean, get unlocked so you don't have to deal with phone carrier apps

I purchased this phone primarily to upgrade from 4G to 5G, and to have a phone with a wide spectrum of 4G and 5G band coverage. This phone has the widest band coverage of any that I've seen which makes it more usable for international travel and justifies (for me) the premium price. 
  
  Plusses: Battery life, quick charging (and aftermarket rapid chargers that work for this phone are fairly inexpensive), storage capacity. Battery charge seems to hold up well and the rapid charging does charge rapidly. 
  
  Minuses: A bit smaller screen size than what I had hoped for, for the money, single SIM (my previous phone had a dual SIM, which was great for international travel). 
  
  Otherwise, the phone performs as I had expected it would. I've not run into any issues with the quality of manufacture or the functionality. Android 11 seems pretty solid.
Loving my new Google pixel 5. The 5G is amazing on Metro by T-Mobile
Nice staff. Helped order my new phone. Couldn't use my Birthday 10% towards it, but needed a new phone.

Probably the best purchase I've made at BestBuy. Coming from a Pixel 3a, this is a no-brainer! Smooth AF! Solid camera (compared to other flagships)! Great small size! Killer battery! 
  
  I'm honestly in love with this phone.
Solid product. Pure Android is nice. On Google Fi so 5G where available without having to upgrade my plan.

I would say this is probably the best Android phone I've used in many ways. My favorite aspect of this is easily the design. I'm NOT talking about aesthetic/looks. I'm talking about how it FEELS in the hand and how the screen looks. It's the kind of phone you absolutely do not NEED a case for. Some might op for one to make it look better (ps don't get green; only the black looks half-decent). But you don't need it! Because of the metal frame it's sturdy, solid feeling, and you don't get scared dropping it. The texture on the back is great too. Grippy without being cheap-feeling. As far as the screen, while it may not measure up to iPhone-level colors and brightness, it makes up for it with the edge-to-edge design only interrupted by the hold-punch cutout from the selfie-cam. Cameras on this are not as good as iPhone-level but they get the job done and back-cam CAN crank out some impressive stuff with the right light. Performance isn't anything to call home about, but it's good and does the job you need it to. Battery life is really good. 
  Overall I'd say this is a great phone for someone that refuses to buy an iPhone for whatever reason (though I still recommend iPhone for most people). FAR better than any previous Pixel phone which I simply couldn't recommend. Much better than gambling with a Samsung phone. OnePlus is the only brand that could pry give this a run for its money (I have yet to try the latest series) but I'd still give the Pixel the edge simply cuz of the camera and fact that google makes the hardware & software here.

Very nice, no bloatware, extremely intuitive, love the spam call checker. Smallish size perfect for my shirt pocket at work. 
  Upgrade from Samsung s7.

Absolutely blown away with the performance and battery life on this phone! I didn't think I would care about the 90 hz refresh rate but after just a few minutes of it I can't go back. Although the cpu is smaller than the other phones of this year, that's how it keeps a great battery life and I think it will probably last longer because of the downsizing as well. I never reach below 40% battery life in a day.
Just great value. It is smooth as can be, especially for the price. One could notice differences between this and more expensive ones but they'd have to be right next to each other..
Had the Google Pixel 3a and LOVED IT! got replaced with this pixel5 5G and I'm in deeper LOVE with google. Forever Loyal!!! Keep the good products rolling Google!
It's an average phone. Nothing special. I was not amazed, Mayne for $450 I'd say it's worth it.

I"m all Apple (iMac, Airbook, Mac Pro, etc) and had an iPhone since inception (2007) and around the 5 and 6 they got progressively worse, so after a year of research I switched to the OG Google Pixel and it was THE best phone I ever owned (except for the magnitude of the OG iPhone of course). 
  
  But then after "upgrading" to the Pixel 3XL, I had a ton of problems, terrible battery, Android auto issues, Pixel buds issues etc. So I went back to the iPhone (11 Pro). What a mistake, Siri sucks with terrible dictation where I'm constantly fixing text messages or emails, spam calls bug me all day (they don't with the Pixel), the night camera absolutely sucks (in comparison to Google's nite site) among other things. 
  
  When I heard about the Pixel 5, I had to start my research again, and since I don't allow inferior products in my life, I bought it and all I can say is thank you Google, it is once again the best phone I've owned, with even better features, it's light and wicked fast, great battery life, amazing camera (yes at night too) superb dictation and the hands down best AI for $700. 
  
  It's simple, it just works and that's what matters.

My first order was not delivered, i contacted best-buy customer support and told about it. The representative promptly sent me another phone. Good customer support experience. 
  
  Experience from slightly bigger Pixel 3XL to Pixel 5 is flawless. Great camera and fast responsive phone that you can operate with one hand is great advantage.
Great phone and awesome interface. Using Android and Google is great.
Smaller than I thought, (previous iPhone 7plus user) and still bigger screen. Very nice camera. Satisfied so far.

I can't believe I finally went with a Google Pixel... First time I heard from then was from a friend in Brazil back in 2016. He is a tech guy and said how much he wanted the Pixel 3 (top at the moment). Last year I was drawn to the Pixel 4 due to its Astronomical camera (I'm an astronomer), however money was short and my iphone X still worked fine. 
  
  My old phone screen suddenly stopped working when I was watching a video, so I decided to buy the new Pixel 5 as a Christmas treat for myself, I paid cash for an opened box which was $615, but I could tell the phone hasn't been used, someone bought it, put the SIM in it and for some reason they returned the phone, lucky me there was only one LOL. 
  
  It was love at first sight. The phone transfered all the data from my iphone (didn't know I could cross data like this on different soperatiinal systems). Af first it was kinda slow because it was installing so many apps, but as soon as it finished OMG you have no idea how high this phone can fly. The camera is just unbelievably AWESOME, I use night sight even at day time since in my opinion makes the photos so much better. The screen is so vivid, beautiful and smooth. Honestly, I am never going back to apple. 
  
  Google Pixel is the way!

Pixel 5 is a great phone. Yes it doesn’t have the latest chip set but Googles software makes up for it and it runs so smoothly. Cameras are great as always on a Pixel device and you always get the latest and greatest from Googles software. 
  I would say it is priced a bit higher then it should be but if you can get it on a discount you’ll be extremely happy with it.
Great mid range phone for the price. Not a lot of bells and whistles but a great pure Android experience

Honestly the worst experience with retail I've ever had, workers were so rude and apathetic, lied straight to my face and then didn't offer to help or even act like they cared. Never going back to best buy for anything ever again, left the store in tears because I had store associate delete pictures of my deceased loved ones off of my phone without my consent.

Great phone & obviously great software. 
  
  The size is perfect and the screen is crystal clear. I miss the front facing stereo speakers but still sounds just as good when laid down.

About what you expect from Google. Hardware about what you expect for the cost. Touchscreen is not very sensitive which is annoying with gloves on as it usually doesn't work. Great camera mostly due to software post processing. Rest of software is buggy as hell as one would expect from Google. Mind boggling how they've not been able to figure out screen rotation that works reliably but that's Google. One gets the feeling they really don't care all that much.

The Google Pixel 5 is a great all around phone that is more budget friendly than the latest and greatest phones out there. At $650 the Pixel 5 is more appealing to budget minded people, yet the phone doesn't compromise much. I'm sure it is one of the more affordable 5G phones out there. 
  
  In the package with the phone is a 5v/3A + 9v/2A charger, USB-C cable and a USB-A to USB-C adapter. The adapter and USB cable are used for transferring files and settings from your old device to the Pixel. This worked surprisingly well. One note, since my old phone had a USB-C port also I thought I could just connect the two phones with the included cable and transfer that way. However the phones didn't recognize each other. Instead, when I used the A to C adapter with a different USB-A to USB-C cable, the phones recognized each other and the transfer was made. There must be some sort of circuitry in the adapter that makes the transfer possible. 
  
  The screen is fantastic. I love that the phone is so thin and the screen goes right up to the edges. The screen is slightly larger than my old phone, but slightly smaller in overall size. 
  
  Swiping, motions and tasks operate smoothly. The processor is actually a step down in processing speed from many newer phones, but you'll never notice the difference and everything works as it should. 
  
  For the camera, Google opted for a two lens system that is more suited to wider shots than "zooming in". The camera and video camera work very well, even in low light conditions, but don't expect to zoom in and get good photos. There is noticeable noise when zooming 2x. Having said that, the camera works well close up. 
  
  4K video at 60fps? Pretty amazing. I'm not a videophile but the features of the camera are great and work well. I enjoy taking panorama shots and those look great. There are options for taking slo-mo and time lapse video that also worked great. I'm pretty happy with the image and video performance of this phone. 
  
  Minor annoyances:
  Google did away with facial recognition unlock. At first I was rather annoyed by this as I've become accustomed to unlocking my phone this way, but the fingerprint scanner works really well and is located on the back of the phone so that as soon as I pick up the phone and tap the fingerprint scanner it instantly unlocks. 
  Also, there is no LED indicator light for notifications. Notifications will pop up on the screen but only for a few seconds so if I miss that notification I have no way of knowing about those notifications unless I unlock the phone. Also, there's no way to increase the time the notifications stay visible on the lock screen. I wish I could change that. 
  
  Overall I'm very happy with the Google Pixel 5.
Very happy with the Pixel 5. It has an all-day battery, quick start-up, great user interface. The camera is excellent and people definitely noticed when I sent them pictures. So far, so good!

It's a device meant for regular users. I have enjoyed the spam call detection feature. While it took me a while to adjust to this from my old samsung but it's definitely worth it. I wish they could fix the YouTube music app though. But every other google app is great.
Navigation using the touch screen doesn't work as well as it did on my Pixel 3a. I haven't used the camera yet.

Love Love Love it!!! Replaced a Samsung Galaxy 8 which was nice but pales in comparison to this! Great features, SUPERB camera and lots of fun things! Nice size, not too obtrusive. Only wish it had extra memory storage. No card slot! Would be 5 stars with that. No headphone jack but I don't think anything has those anymore, although they come in handy! At $595-$649 NICE price also!!!
Pretty nice device. Battery life has been stronger than expected. The whole experience has been a plus so far. Early on in ownership to truly test and rate durability, but otherwise excellent.
Initially when picking up my device they struggled to locate it so it took extra time to wait for them to find it. Outside of that, everything went nicely and the phone operates as expected.

I upgraded from a pixel 3 to this phone and it feels like a huge upgrade. There's only two noticable downgrade - the front camera and the speakers - but I don't take a ton of selfies so it wasn't a deal breaker for me and I never listen to music on my phone speakers. 
  
  There's a lot to love about this phone. The battery is impressively good, I regularly get between 7.5 to 8.5 of screen on time. The cameras take nice pictures as you'd expect, the bezel-less display looks much more modern than my pixel 3. I love the textured rubber on the back of the phone, no case needed! Then the nice things like the 5G, 90 Hz display, and reverse wireless charging. I notice that the phone is much better at multitasking too, probably thanks to the extra RAM this phone is running. The addition of a wide angle camera is great too! You can fake digital zoom, but not wide angle. 
  
  Now for the noticable downgrades from the pixel 3. The front camera is less sharp than the camera on the pixel 3 and there's only one, rather than the wide angle plus normal selfie camera. It's also a fixed focal length rather than autofocusing which makes pictures appear much more soft. But this isn't a big deal, the selfie camera isn't anywhere as important as the main cameras. The lack of stereo speakers are also a disappointment, but not a deal breaker again since I'd rather have an edge to edge display than slightly better phone speakers.

Extremely poor service. Phone I received was not reset properly. It ask for the previous owner pin or email and password associated with the previous account. Was told by online CS I had to bring phone back to store to get it settled. Took me a few hours of watching youtube videos to settle it myself. Terrible amd irritating experience.

I'm a die hard pixel fan. I'm currently using a pixel 4xl and it's a great phone. I decided to buy the 5 because I bricked my rooted 4xl and wasn't sure if I could fix it. I ended up fixing my 4xl a few hours after buying the 5. I think the main drawbacks are the size of the phone (it's tiny) and it feels cheap. 
  The midrange processor still worked fine and the screen was great. 
  Probably a great phone but it's just not a top tier phone anymore.
Switched from iphone to this due to not being able to get an unlocked iphone. I love this phone and has the same features as the iphones for a lot less.

The google pixel 5 is an awesome phone. I love it. No issues at all. Taking pictures is good. The picture comes out so clear. Also I play the game a lot and I also have no issues with it being laggy. This phone was made well. Its worth the money

Great phone so far. Replaced my Pixel 2 XL, and I am enjoying the smaller size of this one. I'm impartial to the swiping updates....I don't like it any better or worse than having the home/back buttons at the bottom of the screen. Great sound quality.
Great phone. Perfect 1 handed size. Amazing battery life. Plenty of power. Usual clean software. Terrific camera. Truly the best pixel as the iPhone of Androids.
Great phone great pics took a little getting used to. The way you navigate home, back,and open apps is way different but you can set it back to the 3 button way
Big improvement over Pixel 2XL. The screen is just as big, but the phone is much more manageable with 1 hand. Battery life so far seems very good
Love this phone. Easy to use and no useless apps pre installed.
Excellent phone. Smaller than Pixel XL 3 but very fast.

This is my first ever google phone. 
  Looks: it looks like all the other popular phones on the market. 
  Feel: it feels super light. Like to the point I’m fumbling it and dripping it. Need to get a cover for better grip. It’s like a feather compared to others. 
  Function: from the start it reminded me of any other google product. Crisp and fast imaging. On T-Mobile I don’t notice any lag in service. 
  Pros: it does what you need it to do if you are a phone call, text, social media and picture taking person. Customizing it to look your way will have you feeling at home quick. 
  Cons: I absolutely strongly dislike the finger recognition on the back. That is where I naturally put my finger when scrolling on my phone and it randomly pulls down notifications and it’s frustrating. Once I get used to putting my finger elsewhere I will have a perfect phone bc during the pandemic not being able to do face recognition is troublesome as well.

It is nice, a good size and very average. 
  
  I came from iPhone thinking this would be a good switch...I was wrong. It stutters and freezes up when doing the most basic tasks. The camera is 'ok'. 
  Google's implementation and software is great and flows fluidly, the only issue is the under powered processor that lags behind similarly prices phones. 
  Google dropped the ball here. 
  I traded it back in after a few days and ate the $45 fee. I now have the s20 FE and I couldn't be happier.
Small phone sad there is no xl model its too small for me

The phone is just the right size for my liking. There are many different applications and functions to learn. Transferring data to the new phone was quick and painless, the phone handled the switch pretty seamlessly. So far, I'm liking it!
Love the phone and the price! Takes great pictures and enough power for what your daily tasks.

This phone is perfect for the everyday user. It has enough memory because your photos will be stored in the Google photo storage area. So it doesn't take up room in the phone, that leaves room for apps and other things. Cameras graat can't complain, I like that it has a wide angled camera, and it's Google see you it's only going to get better. It's a really nice size if you don't like really tall phones this is a great phone. Only thing I would complain about is the color choices.

Android without all the bloat. I always buy unlocked phones. And I'm an android kinda guy. No complaints yet. Battery is nice compared to my old pixel 2xl. Getting used to the smaller screen. Very pocketable
Amazing camera. Fits great in my hands. Went from a Samsung to this google pixel and I love it.
The service was great and I was given the basic instructions. I was very fortunate that they took the time to transfer all the data from my old phone to this one.

Upgrading from a pixel 2, The screen is fantastic and the battery life is amazing plus the pixel experience makes it a great option. I truely miss the active edge, hopefully they will bring it back. Highly recommended.

We have given you 3 stars all because of the store representative who worked with us. We ordered a green phone but a black on was shipped. We ordered a phone case but it was the wrong size. We ordered a screen, and it was correct. We took the shipment to the local store and discovered discrepancies. Milton Smith went out of his way to make things "right" for us. When he tried ordering the correct case, we saw where the stores provisioning system had data entry errors. Milton was attentive, understanding, efficient, and exhausted all possibilities to right the wrongs. Without him, Best Buy would have received a "D-" in our eyes. He was attentive at the original sale and when we returned to set the phone up. He did not rush or make us feel an inconvenience. While Best Buy needs to focus on its provisioning processes, hiring Milton Smith was something Best Buy did very well. He is clearly an asset to the Tysons Corner store. 
  Sincerely,
  Karl & Karin Ritchey

I know some people would be like what ??? Isn't it slower ? Missing features ? No and yeah some but also you gain a lot in battery life and a phone that's possibly more durable than the last one which was pretty durable. The phone is advertised as a weaker processor but the overall experience is pretty smooth and fluid. I don't notice any lag or hang ups ever, and I can even play fortnite on the thing. The all day to two day battery totally makes the experience overall very nice.

The Google Pixel 5 has a sleek design, extremely long lasting battery life, and feels great in the palm of my hand. It's very lightweight but still solid. The OLED display is absolutely gorgeous, and I'm able to see everything clearly even when in sunny areas outside. The screen is very responsive to every touch and the fingerprint sensor unlocks my phone instantly without any issues. Since my Pixel is unlocked it didn't come with bloatware so I have more storage space for the things I actually want to have installed on it. The camera takes clear, high quality photos, even is low lit areas. The only downside I could find is the speaker quality isn't all that great. Overall, this is a great affordable future-proof option for a 5G Smartphone. 
  
  Pros:
  Long lasting battery life
  Lightweight
  Fits perfectly in the palm of your hand
  Extremely responsive 
  Beautiful screen display
  Does not come with bloatware 
  Future-proof, affordable 5G
  Fingerprint sensor works perfectly 
  Camera 
  
  Cons:
  Subpar speaker quality 
  Does not include headphones in the box

I love this phone so much. The only thing is I wish there was a back button to go back and arrows.. buttons at the bottom. I'm still learning how to use it but I love Google ( I call her googalina). So far so amazing..
This my third Pixel and I love it. I would buy another the next upgrade I need.
I love my Pixel 5, it's fast and quick to access. Especially enjoy the finger print sensor.
Nice phone, easy to use, and the price is pretty reasonable

This is an excellent phone for user experience. This phone specs might not look attracting but there are features that you might want to get this phone. 
  
  Features that I like:
  1. google Assist
  2. google assist for holding phone for customer service representative. (Use Hold for me). 
  3. Finger print scanner in the back. 
  4. Finger print scanner is also used for gesture to view notifications
  5. Camera Quality is very nice. It might take some processing time but shots are really nice. 
  6. Phone build quality is very nice.
Battery life, gaming performance, and cameras are once again top notch. I'm coming from a Pixel 3.

For me it lands in the ideal spot. Pure Android phone experience, wonderful camera, excellent battery life, otherwise just a phone that does exactly what I want without distraction. The best thing I can say about it is the best thing I can say about any device: it is utterly transparent. It vanishes in use the way any great tool vanishes. It is a *rational* phone.

Screen cracked easily with the thin glass 
  
  Camera quality and options reduced from pixel 4a
  
  Plastic backing feels cheap for the price 
  
  Storage is very good this is the last phone in pixel line to get the free unlimited google cloud thinh
The Pixel 5 works much like my older Pixel, but most features work better or faster. I'm happy with the product. I'll probably keep this phone for a while.
Love this phone. Wonderful camera and easy to use. Would buy again.

Not happy. Purchases this open box phone and when on speaker I can't be heard. Also occasionally the bottom left of the screen stops working. I reached out 2 days after the return date as I was moving and traveling a cross the country.
Best android experience you can get. Amazing camera and battery life.
Fantastic phone, bought for my brother, he loves it. Worth the upgrade.

I’ve been using a Samsung S20 Ultra for almost a year now and the one main thing that I don’t like about the phone is that it’s huge, I mean huge “as phones go” and decided I wanted a smaller, more economical phone that would fit my budget “way overspent on the Ultra”, and when I saw Google was coming out with the Pixel 5 I had to give it a shot. 
  
  Unboxing:
  The Pixel came in a nice company logoed box, and inside was the Pixel, Charger, USB Cable, USB to USB C adapter, sim card tray ejector tool and paperwork, “no headphones are included. The screen was covered with a protective opaque plastic film, “there’s no factory screen protector installed”. 
  
  Initial Impressions:
  I was “am” amazed at the size of this Pixel, it’s so small compared to the Ultra but still has a 6” screen. There are barely any borders around it and the top, bottom and sides are all uniform this time, nothing uneven here. Turning around the back is a textured finish that I really like, sort of a very very fine sand paper feel to it, “think 3000 grit” which also makes it very grippy, “I still put all my phones in a case though”. There’s a dual camera setup and the rear fingerprint sensor makes a comeback. The right side has the power button “top” volume controls below it, and then the SIM tray is on the opposite side. On top there is a microphone hole, and the bottom has two slits for the speaker/microphone and a USB C port. 
  
  Setting up:
  The first thing I did after unboxing was to charge the phone, “arrived at 75% full”, I then began the setup procedure after installing the sim I had taken out of the Ultra, “we use Mint Mobile here”. it has the normal Android setup so if you’ve set up an android phone you’ll pretty much know how that works. 
  
  During the setup it asked if I wanted to transfer everything from my old phone so I went ahead and that that by connecting both together with the dual USB C ended cable that came with the Pixel. This process made it very simple to bring all my apps over from my old phone “and most of my settings”. Also depending on your carrier you may have to set up the APN for that carrier and that information is found on their website. 
  
  Use:
  Now that everything was transferred and setup to my liking I made some test calls. Due to me having hearing problems I always have to use a headset to hear properly, but I was actually surprised that I could hear pretty good without the headset, not perfect but good enough for a quick call. I set up the multiple Bluetooth headsets I keep around and I was very surprised that all the headsets actually sounded better than the Ultra, and callers on the other end said they could hear me clearly, so that’s pass for calling. The Bluetooth distance was similar to the Ultra with all the headsets and I really didn’t notice a difference there. 
  
  Luckily Mint here in W Phoenix supports 5g and the Pixel connected to that immediately on channel 66, “the Ultra connects on the same channel”. I ran a few speed tests on each one for both Wi-Fi and 5G and the results surprised me. The Ultra on band 66 was getting -106db for signal strength, with an average of 24.3Mbps down and 3.59Mbps up. On Wi-Fi the Ultra got 144Mbps down and 10.51Mbps up “our internet speed here at home is capped at 150Mbps”. Now for the Pixel 5, “also on band 66, sitting in the same location in our home office”, it was getting -108db for signal strength with an average of 33.3Mbps down and 7.57Mbps up. With Wi-Fi the Pixel 5 got 144Mbps down and 10.2Mbps up. These numbers sort of surprised me as I ran multiple tests on each phone and the Pixel 5 on 5G beat the Ultra, and was almost identical using Wi-Fi. The doubling of upload speed is what really got me. 
  I didn't test any other bands as 5g connects and works fine around this area. 
  
  Camera:
  I haven’t used the camera a lot, but from the pictures I’ve taken they are really good for a cell phone and does keep the Pixel reputation as one of the best phone cameras. Would I say it’s as good as the Ultra? , well the regular cameras pictures look every bit as good, and the night shot pictures look better. There’s no optical zoom with the Pixel so I really can’t compare it to the zoom on the Ultra “but there’s also a big price difference between the two”. The wide angle lens may be a little less than the Ultras but looking at shots taken from both on the screen they both look really good. 
  
  Short videos I’ve taken look really good and I mainly shoot at 1080p as 4k just takes up too much room. The slow motion and time lapse settings work really well and are very comparable to the Ultra “just in a lot smaller package. I do have a GoPro if I want to shoot a lot of 4k video so I don’t shoot a lot of videos with a phone anyway. 
  
  Conclusion:
  I really wanted a smaller phone as I was tired of lugging around the huge one and was always afraid I was going to drop it, especially when attempting one handed use. The Pixel 5 is a good bit smaller and I have no problem using it one handed and don’t worry as much about dropping it, “especially with a metal back “only the screen is vulnerable and I'm putting a glass screen protector on it. 
  
  The screen is plenty bright and the added 90mhz refresh rate really helps when scrolling through a webpage or text. Battery life is great and where the Pixel really shines, the first day I fully charged it, set it up, installed apps, took test photos, ran multiple speed tests and still had over 40% that night. 95% of the time I use a wireless charger and that option works perfectly. 
  
  Phone call quality is outstanding, and the phone with Mint does support Wi-Fi calling without any problems. Signal strength were we are located with 5g is comparable to the S20 Ultra, and data speeds were surprisingly stronger. 
  
  The Pixel 5 is a great mid-range phone, it’s a much cheaper option that the high end phones of other manufacturers and if you don’t want to spend that much on a phone than you should be very happy with the Pixel 5

I've been an avid flagship phone buyer for the past 20 years and consider that I know the general in's and out's of phones more than many. In other words I'm not a noob to working cell phones and am reasonably tech savy; I build computers, do some programming in Linux, etc. This Pixel 5 is simply a nightmare of a phone. Yes, it has long battery life, probably explained to the fact that it basically does nothing. It also can take great pictures when it decides to let you. Otherwise good luck expect your vacation or other pictures to be there when you go back to look for them. I search online will bring up "top 10 ways to solve photo problems on pixel," all of them complete run-arounds from what should be a given; take picture then be able to look at it. Working with other documents can be a simlar experience, sometimes they are there, sometimes they aren't. My experience with Gmail has been the final straw, need to communicate important information to family members, for 2 days and trying a dozens "solutions" (readily available online from other disgruntled users) I simply cant send some small PDF files via Gmail. Nevermind that it took some 3rd party apps to dig through my phone to find those PDF's in the first place, because apps in the phone wouldn't communicate when sharing between each other. This is going in a drawer and I guess I'm out a lot of money and will just buy 3 generation old Samsung s8, which performs WAY better than this phone. Google, never again.

I absolutely love this phone... Also I've only had this phone for about a week. I will update this review if anything changes. 
  
  It's a great looking phone. I love the texture on the back of the phone. It's like what reviewers on YouTube say: it feels like stone. I wouldn't say it feels like some crude stone that you would find out on a hike or something. It feels like a fancy, smooth stone that you would buy to decorate your home. I've been at home most of the time so this phone has been without a case. I actually prefer it without it. 
  
  Form factor is much smaller than a lot of phones, but the screen makes up a large portion of it due to the small, uniform bezels. I liked the screen
  
  The phone is really fast imo. I've never used anything else that has a better processor (Samsung S20, Pixel 4, etc.) so I don't have anything to compare it to other than my Nexus 6P. I haven't encountered any lag, especially in games. I usually don't play games on the phone, but I wanted to test its power. I played Gwent on the Pixel 5, and it was as smooth as butter. The battery life is phenomenal. I had about a little over 6 hours of screen time one day and there was still above 30% left. About 2/3 of 4/5 of that screen time was attributed to Gwent. 
  
  Stock Android feels cleaner than ever. I've been stuck on Android 8 for the past 4 years so this definitely feels like a major upgrade for me. There's so many new features, but to name a few that I use A LOT are Bedtime Mode and Focus Mode for sleeping and studying, respectively. 
  
  There were quite a lot of complaints on the sound of the Pixel 5. I'm not sure how well it works in places with a lot of noise since I've been home most of the time. In my opinion, I think the sound is between good, but it's not excellent. I would consider my Nexus 6P to have excellent sound quality because there were grills and a dedicated space for my speakers. By no means though, is the Pixel 5 sound horrible. I think there's a bit of a over exaggeration on the sound being bad. I don't mind I only use the speakers most of the time for watching shows or videos (and talking to people on the phone); it works well for all those. If you listen to music on your phone a lot through the phone speaker, then maybe it might not be to your quality. The audio sounds less punchier than my Nexus 6P which has great sound, but it still sounds alright. It's not a deal breaker for me because it sounds decent enough (also I use headphones or earphones to listen to music).
Went back and forth between this and the new samsung that was heavily discounted. No regrets at all

Got this phone on a whim as my other one was a few years old. I have been surprised by some features and let down on others. Here is my breakdown. 
  Likes:
  Battery life is incredible. I have gone 2 days with wifi, location, and bluetooth running 24/7. The battery modes are a godsend. 
  High rez screen with excellent color and speed. 
  Screen refresh is a game changer with 90hz refresh that makes videos so smooth to watch. 
  Loud system sounds, which is good for me, as I mostly have it in my pocket at work. 
  Strong vibration on silent mode. 
  Icons can be changed to your liking (themes to be more exact). 
  Smaller size is more comfortable to carry in pocket ( mine other phone is a XL sized one)
  Camera is same as previous versions of Pixel, but the added lens and night time mode makes it much better for daily use. 
  Case is slightly textured already, so holding it is easier. 
  Metal body with rear cutout (you can't see it) for wireless charging. 
  Reverse charging is epic, With the ability to charge my headphones in case they need it but setting them on top of phone. 
  Google OS 11 is a wonder to behold with all the added features and tweaks for this phone to use. 
  Dislikes:
  Although it is a small body phone, it is not easily useable as a single handed phone. 
  New OS takes the home, back and running program listing off the bottom part of display and you have to use a gesture to use them. You can change this is the settings, but until you do, just be prepared for some frustration. 
  No headphone jack ( I like them, some don't)
  Speaker is not at top exacly, but under the glass. Which is fine for some, but I keep trying to get nearer to the speaker when I am talking to someone. 
  Speaker (2) not being at top and under the glass, lets everyone in the close area around you hear your calls. 
  Text size is to vast in difference to be good. I had a hard time reading under the normal setting and used medium. It works until you go into something like messages and then it is way too big. Can't find a happy in between. 
  Sides are too sensitive. so if you are playing a game and touch the sides, it will pause the game, or close it. 
  Side squeeze to activate assistant is gone. 
  Case is needed. Otherwise you might not be able to hold phone to ear without the possibility of dropping it . 
  When screen shot is activated, it will minimize the screen and take a picture. However, it will also cut off the bottom portion where the screen capture option is. Thus not capturing the whole page or picture. 
  
  I am glad I got the phone for many reasons. However I am tempted to go back to my older phone since I had all the settings the way I liked them and it was easier to hold.

A week in, I really like the Pixel 5. It's fast, the oblong form factor works, and the battery life is insane. I expect it to be pretty good for the first month or two but it's really, really fantastic. I like the textured back, and the camera isn't just good, it's fast. It seems to do a good job of connecting to 5G in my area but honestly my data needs are pretty modest, I might turn it off if it's better for the battery. 
  
  Once change in Android, swapping the virtual buttons for gestures, I thought I was going to hate, but I absolutely love. Really there's only three gestures, for home, back and active apps, and they're very easy to remember and use, and they work 100% consistently. That's one of my biggest iOS gripes, that back isn't consistent between applications, and sometimes works differently within the same application (I'm looking at you, Facebook). 
  
  If I was going to change one thing, I'd make the rear fingerprint sensor easier to feel by touch.

It's a solid phone but a bit overpriced. I like that it's stock Android, but it should be $500-$600, not $699.

Not very user friendly. The first one I purchased was defective and I had to exchange it. I purchased it to be used with Google Fi for my husband that is traveling overseas and Verizon International Plan did not work but Google Fi does.

I also didn't realize how much I would enjoy having a smaller phone again!

  I would definitely recommend getting this phone if you want something that preforms well won't cost you over $1000!
This phone is AWESOME it's light weight! It is asy to figure out and it's just a great phone for the money!

Great phone, but needs to have a bigger screen. I enjoyed the ease of use and the clean install of Android without all of the extras. The only complaint is the price, for the same price you can get a Galaxy s21 with better specs
I bought this for my wife to replace her Google Pixel 2XL. She seems to like it much better, and is a worthy upgrade if you have an older Pixel.
I upgraded from the 3xl and i love it. Great for the cost and good photo quality.
Extremely fast phone, simple, with a great camera!
Unlocked is the way to go. Google Pixel 5 is worth the investment.
Nice n durable!!!! Once you use to it you would never want to put it down...

I'll be upfront: I am not a phone power user. I watch a ton of youtube, browse the internet while pooping, and maybe get suckered once or twice a year with a "free" game. 
  
  I bought this phone because I had a pixel 2 that finally started to get battery issues. I really like stock Android over the Samsung shell and I've never had an LG, OnePlus, etc. 
  
  As for the pros, the upgrade was seamless. Swap sim, download apps, profit. The battery life has this far been incredible. 1 full day is all I hope for with a phone. I listen to spotify or podcasts for 8-10 hrs a day a work, the occasional phone call, some texts, email, and a few videos. Somehow this guy gets a day and a half. For my needs, this is the selling feature. I don't always have access to a charger and the longer I can get, the better. It's waterproof and initially durable as it still works after being dropped in a pot hole puddle. Screen looks fine as mobile youtube has never looked better. My pictures of spreadsheets have never been so clear. The size is also remarkably close to the pixel 2 so many accessories and cradles have been compatible. 
  
  The cons: With a bezeless screen, it's harder for me to one handed type. The front facing camera, while not a notch, is still noticeable and sometimes makes my brain think there is something on the screen. With the screen being slightly larger, it's harder to high score frantic tapper games. 
  
  If you're after an ol' reliable and are coming from an older phone, this is a great product. The battery life is stupid good, and it does everything else a normie might want to do. The price point is acceptable to me because I know what I'm getting. You won't wow your friends and you'll still be the awkward color bubble in imessage, but get past that and this looks like a phone I keep for another 3 years.

This is a pretty solid phone, but lacks in some areas. I noticed a lot of stutters when scrolling, camera isn’t an upgrade over previous Pixel devices. Phone does have outstanding battery life and the screen looks solid.

Upgraded from a Pixel 2 to this Pixel 5. I have been wanting a new Pixel for quite some time now and I am glad I waited for the 5G version. Im pretty close to 100% 5G uptime in my area which is quite nice. 
  
  The 90hz screen is very smooth and it just makes the phone feel more responsive overall which is a HUGE plus. 90hz should be standard going forward. 
  
  The color is a little washed out compared to that of the Pixel 2 I had, but I got over it quickly. 
  
  Takes great pictures, video looks great and it's all around a solid phone. And since it is a Google device, I get updates for my device when google releases them instead of me waiting months or years like with other phone makers.

I'm a long-term Pixel user, having previously owned Pixel 1 and 3. The Pixel 5 is easily the best Pixel phone to date as it finds the right balance between hardware and price. Fantastic screen (90hz refresh rate and bezel-less screen is a game-changer), bioresin/metal construction makes it feel durable, and the battery life is nothing short of amazing (truly all-day batter). And while I had some initial concerns about the mid-range Snapdragon 765G processor, trust me, it's just as zippy as phones twice the price. Pixel phones have always had the best software experience for Android, and this phone is no different. Also, the camera remains best-in-class. Can't recommend this phone enough.
The only way to go when it comes to to Android Google the way it was meant to be. Excellent phone and silky smooth software features.
looks and works as it should very fast and has a very good camera
This is a really great phone - super fast, awesome camera, powerful battery, and just the right size.
Very good the only issue is when closing out messages sometimes it archives them versus closing app.
Super zippy. I like the new gestures. and the size
This is a great phone, wonderful camera and great looking screen.

I’ve owned Google Pixel 5 for over 3 weeks now and I should say it’s amazing phone , especially for the price! The battery last long , the quality of the video is stunning, the accuracy of the colors is much better than iphone 11, i would say perfect. The phone is a bit light for me, but that’s not an issue, i just have a feeling that I’m not holding it . I would recommend it without hesitation.
I like this new 5g phone. Works well on Verizon. Fits well in my hand.

great phone without all of the extra stuff. 
  
  I had been a Samsung user for the last 10 years, and grew tired of their keyboard, their web browser, having to sign into some smasung account, I just wanted my phone and my G suite; and making the switch was the right move! I got the unlocked version so I would have carrier flexibility, giving Google Fi a shot; I appreciate the savings over verizon, however the coverage isn't quite up to par; so I may be switching back, with this phone I have that flexibility.

Great phone, but should have been priced lower for specs considering most features are the same on the Pixel 4a 5G, which is sold for a lot less (and adds back in a headphone jack too). 
  
  Great phone overall, but for the asking price, and considering that the CPU is slower than last years Pixel 4, this should have been priced lower. Don’t get me wrong, for most people the CPU on this Pixel 5, is very solid, and most people will not notice a difference, especially if they do not play android games. While I am a big gamer, android games themselves are not for me. They do not compare to console game experiences. Luckily we now have Xbox Game Pass on Android which are cloud based streaming game services. I can report that the Google Pixel 5 works and fits the Razer Kishi controller perfectly for those that might be wondering. 
  
  I am coming from a nearly 3 year old LG v30 phone, and the Pixel 5 is just way snappier, no doubt due to it having double the amount of RAM, Pixel 5 has 8gb of RAM. I have noticed no lag switching between various apps, and have not even rebooted the phone in the more than 6 days I have been using this phone. While the CPU is a bit slower than other phones in this price-range, it seems Google has done this to conserve battery power. And let me tell you this is the best phone I have owned, ever, in terms of battery power. I can start the day at 100 percent battery charge, and use the phone for calls, texting, even watching videos on youtube, and streaming, and 8 hours later, still have over 50 percent battery life. There is no headphone jack on this phone, but luckily, this phone has Bluetooth 5.0, and defaults to using the excellent quality AptX audio codec if you headphones support it. I also noticed that the bluetooth range with this device is so much better than my LG v30 ever was. With my LG v30, all my smartwatch would always disconnect if I went anywhere more than about 20 feet away from my phone, same with any bluetooth headphones. I now can go more than double that range with my smartwatch. 
  
  Probably the best thing about this phone. The operating system!! NO BLOAT!! Pure android 11. This is probably the best version of Android I have seen. Way better than LG and Samsung. Those phones try to do too much, and in the process slow your phone down in my experience. Android 11 will take a little getting used to, it took me a good day to get used to using what they call “gestures”, getting away from using “virtual buttons” like other manufacturers have been doing in the past. The OS is just plain SNAPPY and RESPONSIVE!! Even though it might have a slower CPU than other phones in this price range, you would never know it switching between apps, etc. 8gb or RAM is likely how this is done. 
  
  Do not buy this phone if you are looking just to get on the 5G service. I am on T-Mobile with my phone, and in all the testing I have done, it is barely faster than 4G service. Even when I am in sparsely populated areas where I have 5G connectivity, it was hardly different than 4G at all when I measured using speedtest.net. 
  
  Screen size, coming from a “larger” LG v30. I was initially not sure about how I would feel coming from a larger phone. Because google has a great design here, and have hidden away the speakers under the screen, and have a “pin-hole” camera, this phone’s screen is just about bezel less. So even though the phone might be physically smaller than a previous “larger” phone, it fits nearly the exact same screen size in smaller physical device. I really am happy with this. Less bulk in my pocket. Oh, and another great thing.. This thing has a beautiful OLED screen. To my eyes, it is better than my LG v30. 
  
  Speakers. They are not great, my old phone sounded better, but I cannot complain at all for things like listening to podcasts. Even music isn’t bad. Google went with a “under the screen” speaker, and it works, but it kind of gives you muddy sound for middle and bass tones. Again, it isn’t bad, and as for my personal use, it is fine. Gets just as loud as my old phone speakers. 
  
  Phone calls are great with this phone, whether via bluetooth headset, or speaker phone. No one I spoke with via any method of call had any issues hearing me. 
  
  “The gap”. Some people have them, and for those that do have a gap, some gaps are larger than others. There have been widespread reports, globally, that people are receiving Pixel 5s, with a slight gap between the screen and the body of the phone, most often, the gap is not uniform, and just in one corner of the phone. I unfortunately received my phone with this small gap in the top left edge corner of the phone. Google has stated that this gap is by “design”, but this more likely is just the result of during manufacturing, the adhesive used to seal the screen to the phone is just not holding down enough. Most people will not even notice the gap, but I was getting lint and dust stuck in that gap, while using the phone for the first couple of days before I moved along to a case for my phone. People on reddit have mentioned that after using the phone in a case for a few days, and the phone heating up, and pressure being applied by the case on to their phone gaps, that the adhesive likely is heating up again, and then applied with a good amount of pressure for the screen to seat down properly, as all phones should have come from the manufacturing line. I have found that this worked for me too! I cleaned out the dust and lint using a small plastic tool, and then put the phone in a case, and a day or two later, took the case off, and my top left corner gap is now gone. I really wish that google had better quality control at their manufacturing company, as this is something that should never have left their factories. After watching some breakdown videos, it seems highly unlikely that water or dust could have entered the internal sections of the phone, but when you are going to spend this much money on a device that is advertised as IP68, it is hard to see how this got back quality control on their assembly lines. 
  
  Fingerprint sensor only on this years Pixel 5 model. Face unlock has been removed from last years Pixel 4, and personally, I prefer having a fingerprint sensor. It just works, and due to the current global pandemic and mask wearing, THIS IS A HUGE plus!! You don’t have to fumble around pulling down your mask if you are in public. Pixel 4 did not have a fingerprint sensor at all. The fingerprint sensor generally works fine nearly everytime, but I did notice I had to change how I applied my finger with my third party case. Once I figured that spot out with the case on, it worked pretty much as well as with no case at all, which I would say is near perfect. 
  
  Cameras:
  These are awesome, and to be expected on any Pixel phone, and this phone is no different. Great photos from this phone, especially it’s night sight mode, and astrophotography modes! Setting photos to “portrait” in the camera app will also allow you to edit the lighting back in google photos on the phone, you can change the lighting, and even the bokeh blur in your photos this way. 
  
  Overall:
  Again, a great phone. I don’t need the fastest CPU in the world. If you don’t game directly on your phone, you probably don’t either. What you will most likely appreciate more is that slower processor will extend your battery life during the day, something that is more useful if you ask me. I know there were a bit of dings on my review of this phone, but hopefully going forward with future hardware manufacturing runs, google can improve quality control to make sure all phones out of the box do not have a gap. They have publicly said that this “gap” was there by “design”, but given that most people that do have a “gap”, it is not uniform all the way around, I am not so sure this is accurate. So I guess if that is true, by google’s own logic, if you have one with no “gap” you have a defective phone? Most people do not have a gap if you read various threads across the internet, and youtube videos. And even those that do, the gap for most is very small. Mine sealed up after having it in a case for a few days.
It’s a great phone with that price. Battery can use more than one day. Pixel’s camera is always the best!

Coming from OnePlus 8, pixel 5 is awesome. Dedicated fingerprint sensor doesn't fail like the in screen one on OnePlus phones. Plus android 11 runs smoothly and updates frequently. Did open box and saved a lot. Phone is as good as brand new

I like this phone! If you like small phones and want to experience that one hand use than this is the phone for you. I like the specs, the smoothness, the pure android experience and the all google apps that comes with this phone.

I really like this phone. I had the Pixel 3xl and this is a great step up for me. With this phone I am also able to update this keep all the new softwear that will come out for the phone in the next 3 years.

The phone is stable and full screen the hardware is a little less than what you would like but works for what I want. I do not game or need the best camera since it fits for my need and reliable with no bloat ware.

  The camera is a little old hat now, having not changed from previous phone iterations, but still provides solid shots with great software aide. The phone is a little pricey for the specs, but the device is optimized and glossy smooth in use.
Great phone for the money! Excellent camera and battery life. Small size sharp display.
Not what I was looking for. Smaller and hard to hold. Speaker in the wrong location and couldn't hear very well.
Really nice phone with a lot of bells and whistles. Battery life is great and seems to work better than my iPhone 12
Very pleased with my purchase. This is my second as I broke the first one. Smooth and fast enough for my every day routine.

I had a Pixel 1 XL for 4 years and it finally died on me. After having a Samsung A51 for two weeks and the screen shattering ( with a glass cover on + case ) I had to find something new. I am glad I went with the Pixel 5. It is just an overall great cellular experience, very slim and modern feeling, yet elegant at the same time.

Very good phone I have had other pixels and really enjoy them. What keeps this phone from being great is the under glass earpiece not being that good. I work in a noisy environment so it may not affect everyone.
Very good quality phone and better than Samsung in this price range.
Great phone, battery beast, perfect size, no complaints. Definitely loved upgrading to this device coming from a Samsung galaxy 9 plus.

Good phone, not the best but not the worst either. I like the design, screen, battery life and smoothness of it. Speakers are awful. If you don't need a phone right away, maybe wait for the Pixel 6 to see what that offers.

I'm used to having a Motorola phone, and have always had an Android. My last Google phone was the Nexus 6, and I loved it. That was one of the largest phones, at the time, with a big 6" screen. My previous phone before this Pixel 5, had been the Motorola Power G. Of all of the phones I have had, this pixel 5 seems to be the one with the most power packed into it. The display is great, as it is FHD+ (1080 x 2340) Flexible OLED at 432 ppi. The 90 hz makes it extremely smooth, while playing games. The Qualcomm® Snapdragon™ 765G 2.4 GHz + 2.2 GHz + 1.8 GHz, 64-bit Octa-Core also plays a key role in the fantastic performance. 
  
  The rear camera has a 12.2 MP dual-pixel camera, which is not the highest resolution out there, but the quality of photos in the dark is amazing. 4K video, at 30 and 60 frames per second is crystal clear. The front camera has an 8 MP at 1080p camera on it, which is really good for being a front camera these days. I am most impressed by the overall quality of the photos taken, especially with the focus and blur effects. I've always known iPhones to have great cameras, and Motorola was more of a budget photo camera, but the pixel 5 is just amazing to me. The included software to modify photos is a great addition. I haven't been always using snapseed, which is a Google product, but this new edit software allows for many more things than I'm used to. There's an option where you can pretty much add an additional light source or add Shadow direction to someone's face if you want. It's a nice when you have something that is not lit up like you want or add dramatization to the photo. The ability to adjust focus, blur and depth changing, post photo, is truly next level. It does not delay photos, nor does it make me choose if I want to select a specific style before I take the photo. in my other phones I always had to choose if I wanted the depth feature or not. But I felt like I would always miss the photo moment by having to adjust the focus prior to taking the photo period with this phone I just tell it I want to take the photo and then I can adjust it after the fact, like raw images in a DSLR camera. There's also a feature that allows you to make it look like the slow pan of professionally shot movies, and is really cool. There's a wide angle type lens that allows you to do 0.6x zoom. It is slightly distorted, but any wide angle lens zoom does that, so it's not a fault cover just something you would notice. After you take the photo on the bottom right area is a quick sharing, that you can click to share that photo to your Facebook or Instagram account, or whatever you would want. The HDR quality is out of this world. My phone camera does is go to quality as my DSLR does. 
  
  Charging this phone is actually quite quick, if you use the right charger. Well at my computer, I plugged it into a USB port on my monitor, and it charged extremely slowly. It's not a fast charger by any means, but I thought it would charge faster than it did. Plugging it into my monitor USB was basically not charging it. The provided phone charger is a USB type-c cord on both ends, and a USB type-c outlet plug, that charges it rapidly. I was really amazed at how fast it charged from really low level two nearly charged a short period of time. The battery has lasted me well over a day, with more than normal use. The only time it ever came close to dead, was when I gave my phone to one of my kids and they watched YouTube kids on it for a long time in the car ride. It still did not go to zero yet, in any day, so far. The lowest it seem is 9% level. 
  
  This may be a feature with Android update, but there's live caption in a settings option. It allows for captions on my screen for any video or video conference call. Thought that was a unique feature. In the settings when you swipe down from the top, it has a screen record feature. I had never seen that before, and it may be a Android operating system update, but it's really neat when trying to share something out with someone else. 
  
  
  I had never used the dark mode feature before this phone, and I never thought I would be a fan of it, until I tried it. I like that it uses less power and gets me through the days where I need to use it more often, but won't sacrifice battery life for using it. 
  
  For a home screen there is the top section that I cannot figure out how to remove or replace with home screen icons. It's like a heads up notification area for your next upcoming appointment or time and weather. The bottom section is also a Google Assistant search bar and both are required to stay, whereas my other phones I could use it for icon locations. When I tried setting up my phone for the first time I wanted to remove it but that did not happen. I'd rather use the swipe from the corner to call Google Assistant than have it show up on my screen taking up icon space. The swipe feature for the home screen previous and window selection took some time getting used to. I'm still not used to it after a week now. There's a little slider bar on the bottom screen that allows you to swipe from left to right and it goes to the previous screen. Pressing on the bottom and swiping upward and then still holding while toward the center of the screen, allows you to pull open the other windows. At that point you can swipe left and right on the windows to select your preference. If you want to eliminate that window then you would have to swipe up and it removes it. I'm used to a one button touch to pull up the windows and swipe away quickly, and this takes a little more time. I would always want to remove existing running Windows to free up ram, but this phone has not delayed on anything and I've had a lot open. I still get caught up sometimes swiping left to right in the center of the screen as the back button. Especially when I'm reading emails and I want to go back or forward. That's when it gets really tough and it will go to the next or previous email, when I want to go back to the previous view. Same thing goes for websites. 
  
  The only thing I miss with my old Motorola phones are the Moto actions where I can chop or twist to access the camera or turn the light on without turning on your phone. If I could somehow get those two features into this phone, it would be the best phone of all time for me. The still is the best phone I've had, but it would just be checking off every single box I would want in a phone. 
  
  On the back of the phone is a fingerprint sensor, that is very convenient. I've had them on the back and side, and don't have a preference as to which one is better. I do find that this sensor is a little bit more accurate than my other ones have been. Many apps use biometric fingerprint scanner to log in, and this one seems to have had only one time or didn't read my fingerprint correctly. My other phone seemed to be every 8-10 times I had to retry. 
  
  When I set up my phone initially, the cord that was provided, it allowed me to copy directly with a cord rather than download via Wi-Fi or the cloud period; it was extremely fast, and copied over my text messages and phone call records as well. In the past I had to always download a third party app to do so, and took forever, and several failed attempts to transfer, due to the size. This setup was probably the easiest I've had so far. With my Google account, it logged in and downloaded all my apps on my previous phone. It was probably because I switched from Motorola to the Google pixel 5, but my icons in my old phone were not transferred over to my new phone. Going from Motorola to motorola, they would, but not going from Motorola to Google pixel 5. I think that's just due to brands. In the box you also get a adapter if you have a USB type a phone, so you can still use the cord and connect them directly if your old phone is not a USB type-c connection, which is actually smart on their behalf. I'd say many people despise setting up new phones, and this takes a way that difficult step. 
  
  Depending on your area and reception, this has the capability to have 5G Network signal. When downloading anything on a 5G network, it's lightning fast. I've used the hotspot capability for my computer, my son's Nintendo switch, and my old phone for my daughter to watch in a car ride, and everything was great. I don't know if it was due to signal or not, but they lost connectivity from my hotspot when the phone was on a call and connected to Bluetooth in my car. As soon as I hung up then they got there internet signal back. It's unofficial but it happened twice coincidentally, I'm not sure. I haven't been able to find any information about downloading and phone calls at the same time. For those of you who have poor reception in your area, this phone also allows for Wi-Fi calling. If I'm in my basement, in certain areas, I get a lower signal, so the Wi-Fi calling really helps out in that scenario. 
  
  As far as sound quality, I did a comparison to my previous phone, and noticed while watching the exact same portion of a movie, the Pixel 5 sounds a little more muffled than my other one, but it also had a deeper sound to it. My other phone seemed more treble, where this one sound like it was slightly different speakers. My wife said she couldn't really tell the difference but I could. It's nothing that you would notice and say oh this is not good. The sound comes from the top and bottom of the phone, while I was playing a movie, and I think it was from the back as well, at least that's where it sounded like it was coming from. When I tested my first phone call, it sounded like the sound was coming from inside the top third of the phone and not necessarily just through the earpiece speaker on top. I feel like the sound may carry more, and others around me could hear it. 
  
  I'd give this phone a 99/100, and would highly recommend it!
I love this phone! It's fast, has enough storage space for what I need, and works well. It also has the stock Android experience I've come to expect from Google, which is why I buy Pixel phones.
